tuv.seg: Ðe Nèzãa Mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo Nyuiea?
Do You Use Digital Technology Wisely?
Videofefewo ƒoƒo zu numame na Jenni.
Jenni is hooked on a video game.
Egblɔ be: "Meƒoa videofefewo gaƒoƒo enyi gbe sia gbe, eye nye ŋutɔ mekpɔe be ezu kuxi sesẽ aɖe nam. "
"I’m playing it for eight hours a day now, " she says, "and it’s become a real problem. "
Dennis tee kpɔ be yeanɔ anyi kwasiɖa ɖeka elektrɔnikmɔ̃wo kple Internet mazamazãe.
Dennis tried to go seven days without his electronic devices and Internet access.
Gake gaƒoƒo 40 ko wòte ŋu wɔ.
He lasted just 40 hours.
Menye sɔhɛwoe Jenni kple Dennis nye o.
Jenni and Dennis are not teenagers.
Jenni nye vidada si si vi ene le eye wòxɔ ƒe 40.
Jenni, a mother of four, is 40 years old.
Dennis ya xɔ ƒe 49.
Dennis is 49.
ÈZÃA mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwoa?
DO YOU use digital technology?
Ame geɖewo alɔ̃ be yewozãnɛ, eye naneke megblẽ le eŋu o.
Many would answer yes, and for good reason.
Elektrɔnikmɔ̃wo wɔa akpa vevi aɖe le dɔwɔnyawo, hadomegbenɔnɔ kple modzakaɖeɖe me.
Electronic devices play a prominent and useful role in employment, social life, and entertainment.
Gake abe ale si wòle le Jenni kple Dennis gome ene la, ame geɖewo zãa mɔ̃ɖaŋunu siawo dometɔ aɖewo fũu akpa.
However, like Jenni and Dennis, many people seem overly attached to some uses of technology.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Nicole si xɔ ƒe 20 gblɔ be: "Etena ɖe dzinye be magblɔe, gake nyateƒeae nye be nye asitelefon ye va zu xɔ̃nye vevitɔ.
For example, 20-year-old Nicole says: "I hate to say it, but my cell phone and I are best buddies.
Mekpɔa egbɔ be ele gbɔnye ɣesiaɣi.
I make sure it’s close by at all times.
Ne mele teƒe aɖe si asitelefon mele dɔ wɔm le o la, metsia dzodzodzoe eye ne gaƒoƒo afã va yi la, medina vevie be makpɔ ɖa be ame aɖe ŋlɔ nane ɖo ɖem hã.
I go crazy if I’m in an area with no cell coverage, and after half an hour, I can’t wait to be able to check my messages again.
Eɖi kokoe vie! "
It’s a little ridiculous! "
Ame aɖewo tsɔa mɔ̃ɖaŋunu aɖewo dana ɖe wo ɖokui gbɔ tsɔ nɔa nyatakaka yeyewo xɔm le zã me.
Some people even check a device for messages and updates through the night.
Eye ne woƒe mɔ̃ɖaŋunua mele wo gbɔ o la, woƒe lãme mekɔna o.
They may experience withdrawal symptoms when they are separated from their digital companion.
Numekula aɖewo yɔ nɔnɔme sia be numame, ate ŋu anye be mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo katã alo internet loo alo asitelefon deŋgɔwo zazãe zu numame na wo.
Some researchers describe this type of behavior as an addiction whether to digital technology in general or more specifically to the Internet or a particular device, such as a smartphone.
Ame aɖewo medina be yewoayɔ nɔnɔme sia be "numame " o, eya ta woyɔnɛ boŋ be kuxi alo dzodzro si nu sẽ.
Others hesitate to use the term "addiction " and prefer to describe such behavior as problematic, compulsive, or obsessive.
Eɖanye ŋkɔ ka kee numekulawo yɔ na mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo mazamazã nyuie o, ate ŋu azu kuxi na ame.
Regardless of what it is called, unwise use of digital technology can be a problem.
Le go aɖewo me la, enana be ƒometɔwo megakpɔa vovo ɖe wo nɔewo ŋu o.
In some cases, it has created a barrier between family members.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ɖetugbui aɖe si xɔ ƒe 20 fa konyi be: "Fofonye meganyaa nu siwo me tom mele le agbe me o.
For example, a 20-year-old girl laments: "My father doesn’t know about anything going on in my life anymore.
Enɔa anyi ɖe asadzi nɔa e-mail ŋlɔm na amewo hafi nɔa dze ɖom kplim.
He sits in the living room and writes e-mails while he is talking to me.
Metea ŋu daa eƒe asitelefon la ɖi o.
He can’t put his phone down.
Anɔ eme be fofonye tsɔa ɖe le eme nam ya, gake ɣeɖewoɣi la ɖeko wòwɔna nam abe ɖe metsɔ ɖeke le eme nam o ene. "
My dad probably cares about me, but sometimes it just doesn’t seem that he does. "
Numamenutsiƒewo
"Digital Detox "

Woɖo numamenutsiƒewo ɖe dukɔ siwo nye China, South Korea, United Kingdom (Royaume-Uni) kple United States (États-Unis) me be woatsɔ akpe ɖe ame siwo mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo mazamazã nyuie zu numame na ŋu. Le teƒe siawo la, wonana be ameawo mezãa internet alo mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo o hena ŋkeke geɖewo.

To help deal with misuse of technology, lands such as China, South Korea, the United Kingdom, and the United States have established "digital detox " centers, where a person is denied access to the Internet and digital devices for several days.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ɖekakpui aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Brett gblɔ be ɣeaɖeɣi va yi la, yenɔa internet-dzifefe aɖe ƒom gaƒoƒo 16 sɔŋ gbe sia gbe.
For example, consider Brett, a young adult who says that at one point he was playing an online game for up to 16 hours a day.
Egblɔ be: "Ne mele internet-dzifefe sia ƒom la, ɖeko wònɔna abe gbekuie meno ene. "
"Whenever I went online, it really was like getting high on a drug, " he says.
Kaka Brett nava yi numamenutsiƒe be woakpe ɖe ye ŋu la, dɔ ge le esi, megaléa be na eɖokui o, eye exɔlɔ̃wo hã ka le eŋu xoxo.
By the time Brett checked himself into a digital detox center, he was unemployed, had neglected his hygiene, and had lost his friends.
Nu kae nàwɔ be nublanuinya sia nagadzɔ ɖe dziwò o?
How can you prevent such a sad outcome?
LÉ ŊKU ÐE ALE SI NÈZÃA MƆ̃ÐAŊUNUWOE ŊU.
ASSESS YOUR USE OF TECHNOLOGY.
De ŋugble tso ŋusẽ si kpɔm mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo zazã le ɖe wò agbe dzi la ŋu.
Determine the impact that technology has on your life.
Bia nya siwo gbɔna la ɖokuiwò:
Ask yourself such questions as the following:
Ðe metsia dzodzodzoe alo doa dziku gɔ̃ hã ne nyemekpɔ internet alo mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo oa?
Do I become unduly agitated, perhaps even temperamental, when I cannot access the Internet or use my electronic device?
Ne meɖo game aɖe ɖi na internet alo mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo zazã la, ɖe megbɔa gamea dzia?
Do I keep using the Internet or device long after the predetermined time I have set to stop?
Ðe menɔa nu siwo amewo ŋlɔna nam xlẽm kaka doa kpo alɔ̃dɔdɔa?
Am I losing needed sleep because I cannot stop checking for incoming messages?
Ðe mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo zazã wɔe be nyemegatea ŋu kpɔa vovo ɖe nye ƒomea ŋu oa?
Is my use of technology causing me to neglect my family?
Ðe nye ƒomea alɔ̃ ɖe ale si maɖo nyabiase sia ŋui la dzia?
Would my family members agree with my answer to this question?
Ne mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo zazã wɔe be mègakpɔa vovo ɖe "nu siwo le vevie wu " siwo dometɔ aɖewoe nye wò ƒomea kple agbanɔamedzi bubuwo ŋu o la, ehiã be nàtrɔ asi le nɔnɔmea ŋu fifia.
If your use of technology is causing you to neglect "the more important things " including your family and other responsibilities now is the time to make changes.
(Filipitɔwo 1:10) Aleke nàwɔe?
(Philippians 1:10) How?
ÐO ƔEYIƔI SI SƆ LA ÐE EZAZÃ ŊU.
LEARN TO SET REASONABLE LIMITS.
Ne wovu ɖe nu nyuitɔ kekeake gɔ̃ hã ŋu akpa la, etea ŋu gblẽa nu.
Too much of even a good thing can be harmful.
Eya ta eɖanye dɔmenyawo alo modzakaɖeɖe tae nèzãa mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo ɖo o, ehiã be nàɖo game ɖe wo zazã ŋu eye nàwɔ ɖe gamea dzi pɛpɛpɛ.
So whether you use digital technology for business or for pleasure, limit how long you will do so, and then stick to that limit.
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo: Anyo be nàna wò ƒometɔ alo xɔlɔ̃ aɖe nakpe ɖe ŋuwò.
Tip: Why not enlist the help of a family member or a friend?
Biblia gblɔ be: "Ne ame le eve la, enyo wu ame ɖeka, . . . Elabena ne wo dometɔ ɖeka dze anyi la, evelia afɔe ɖe tsitre. "
The Bible says: "Two are better than one, . . . for if one of them falls, the other can help his partner up. "
Nyagblɔla 4:9, 10.
Ecclesiastes 4:9, 10.
Mègaɖe mɔ vivisese na wo zazã nawɔe be woava zu "numame " na wò o
Do not let attraction lead to "addiction "
Mɔ̃ɖaŋunu yeyewo wɔe be nyatakakawo ɖoɖo ɖa kple wo xɔxɔ va le bɔbɔe wu, gake ɖikeke mele eme o be wo mazamazã nyuie ƒe kuxia hã ayi edzi anɔ dzidzim ɖe edzi.
As new devices make it easier and faster to access and transmit data, the unwise use of technology will no doubt grow.
Ke hã mègaɖe mɔ vivisese na wo zazã nawɔe be woava zu "numame " na wò o.
But do not let attraction lead to "addiction. "
Ne èwɔa wò "ɣeyiɣi ŋu dɔ le mɔ nyuitɔ nu " la, àƒo asa na mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo mazamazã nyuie ƒe kuxia.
By "making the best use of your time, " you can avoid misusing digital technology.
Efesotɔwo 5:16.
Ephesians 5:16.
Lãwo
Animals
Lãwo wɔa akpa aɖe le mía dometɔ ɖe sia ɖe kloe ƒe agbe me.
In one way or another, nearly everyone’s life is affected by animals.
Ðe míabu akɔnta le ale si míewɔa nu ɖe lãwo ŋu la ŋua?
Are we accountable for the way we treat them?
Aleke wòle be amegbetɔwo nawɔ nu ɖe lãwo ŋu?
How should humans treat animals?
NYA SIWO AMEWO GBLƆNA
WHAT PEOPLE SAY
Ame aɖewo susui be amegbetɔwo ate ŋu awɔ nu ɖe lãwo ŋu ale si wolɔ̃.
Some people believe that animals may be used in any way that humans see fit.
Ame bubuwo hã bunɛ be ele be woawɔ nu ɖe lãwo ŋu abe amegbetɔwo ene.
Others feel that animals should be treated in much the same way as humans are.
Lãwo ta ʋlila xɔŋkɔ aɖe gblɔ be ele be woana "gomenɔamesi lãwo hã eye masɔ be woabu wo be woli na zazã kple dzadzra ko o. "
One prominent animal-rights activist argued that animals should enjoy the "basic right not to be treated exclusively as resources or economic commodities. "
Egblɔ be: "Mele be míanɔ lãwo bum abe nunɔamesiwo ene o. "
He adds: "We should stop treating nonhuman animals as our property. "

Le nudzɔdzɔ aɖe si ame geɖe bu be egbɔ eme gome la, wogblɔ le gatɔ gã aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Leona Helmsley ŋu be egblẽ domenyinu si nye Amerika dɔlar miliɔn 12 ɖi na eƒe avu eye wòŋlɔ agbalẽ da ɖi be ne avua ku la, woaɖii ɖe ye xa.
In what many view as an extreme case, billionaire Leona Helmsley left a $12-million trust fund to her dog and willed that the dog’s remains be placed next to hers after its death.
Bu nya sia ŋu: Aleke nèsusu be woawɔ nu ɖe lãwo ŋui?
To think about: How do you feel animals should be treated?
NYA SI BIBLIA GBLƆ
WHAT THE BIBLE SAYS

Nu gbagbewo Wɔla Yehowa Mawu gblɔ na amegbetɔwo be: "Mikpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe ƒumelãwo kple nuwɔwɔ siwo dzona le yame kpakple nu gbagbe siwo katã ʋãna le anyigba dzi la dzi. " (1 Mose 1:28) Eya ta esɔ be míaƒo nya ta be Mawu bua amegbetɔwo be wokɔ wu lãwo.

The Creator of life, Jehovah God, told humans to "have in subjection the fish of the sea and the flying creatures of the heavens and every living creature that is moving on the earth. " (Genesis 1:28) It is reasonable to conclude, then, that God views humans as superior to animals.
Nya vevi aɖe si dze le mawunyakpukpui si do ŋgɔ teti na esia me la ɖo kpe nyataƒoƒo sia dzi.
This conclusion is reinforced by a significant statement made just before the scripture quoted earlier.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Mawu wɔ ame ɖe eƒe nɔnɔme nu, Mawu ƒe nɔnɔme nue wòwɔe ɖo; ŋutsu kple nyɔnu wòwɔ. " 1 Mose 1:27.
The Bible says that "God went on to create the man in his image, in God’s image he created him; male and female he created them. "
Esi wowɔ mí amegbetɔwo ɖe "Mawu ƒe nɔnɔme " nu ta la, míawo koe tea ŋu ɖea Mawu ƒe nɔnɔmewo, abe nunya, dzɔdzɔenyenye kple lɔlɔ̃ ene, fiana.
Genesis 1:27. Because humans were created "in God’s image, " we are unique in how we display godly qualities, such as wisdom, justice, and love.
Vovototodede nyui kple vɔ̃ dome kpakple mawusubɔsubɔ ƒe ŋutete hã le amegbetɔwo si.
Humans also have an innate capacity for morality and spirituality.
Ŋutete siawo mele lãwo ya si o, elabena womewɔ wo ɖe "Mawu ƒe nɔnɔme " nu o.
Animals lack such human abilities because they were not created "in God’s image. "
Eya ta womesɔ kple amegbetɔwo o eye Mawu meɖoe hã be woawɔ nu ɖe wo ŋu abe amegbetɔwo ene o.
They are inferior and not intended to be treated in the same way as humans are.
Ðe esia fia be esɔ be amegbetɔwo nanɔ ŋuta sẽm le lãwo ŋua?
Does this mean that humans have the right to mistreat animals?
Ao.
No.
Mawu gblɔ le Se si wòtsɔ na Israel-viwo me be woana lãwo naɖi ɖe eme, woana nuɖuɖu wo, woakpe ɖe wo ŋu ne woɖo xaxa me eye woakpɔ wo ta tso afɔkuwo me.
In his Law to the Israelites, God ensured that animals would be given rest, food, help when distressed, and protection from injury.
Exodus 23:4, 5; Deuteronomy 22:10; 25:4.
"Ŋkeke ade nàwɔ wò dɔ; ke mègawɔ dɔ le ŋkeke adrelia dzi o, ale be wò nyi kple wò tedzi naɖi ɖe eme. " 2 Mose 23:12.
"Six days you are to do your work; but on the seventh day, you are to cease from your labor, in order that your bull and your donkey may rest. "
Ðe wònye nu gbegblẽ be woawu lãwoa?
Exodus 23:12. Is it wrong to kill animals?
NYA SIWO AMEWO GBLƆNA
WHAT PEOPLE SAY
Adela kple tɔƒodela aɖewo wua lãwo ɖe modzakaɖeɖe, vivisese na adedada alo lãwo wuwu ko ta.
Some hunters and fishermen kill animals for sport, thrilling in the chase or the conquest.
Ame aɖewo hã ada asi ɖe nya si Russiatɔwo ƒe ŋutinyagbalẽŋlɔla Leo Tolstoy gblɔ be lãwo wuwu kple wo ɖuɖu "mesɔ kura o " la dzi.
Others would agree with Russian novelist Leo Tolstoy, who wrote that killing and eating animals is "simply immoral. "
NYA SI BIBLIA GBLƆ
WHAT THE BIBLE SAYS
Mawu ɖe mɔ be woawu lãwo faa atsɔ akpɔ ame ɖokui ta alo atsɔ awɔ nudodowoe.
God allows people to kill animals to protect human life or to provide clothing.
(2 Mose 21:28; Marko 1:6) Biblia gblɔ hã be amegbetɔwo ate ŋu awu lãwo aɖu.
(Exodus 21:28; Mark 1:6) The Bible also says that humans may kill animals for food.
Wogblɔ le 1 Mose 9:3 be: "Nu gbagbe siwo katã ʋãna la nanye nuɖuɖu na mi. "
"Every moving animal that is alive may serve as food for you, " says Genesis 9:3.
Yesu ŋutɔ hã kpe ɖe eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo ŋu woɖe tɔmelãwo va ɖu.
Even Jesus helped his disciples to catch fish that they later ate.
Yohanes 21:4-13.
Ke hã Biblia gblɔ be Mawu léa "fu ame sia ame si lɔ̃a ŋutasẽnuwɔwɔ. "
Nevertheless, the Bible says that God "hates anyone who loves violence. "
(Psalmo 11:5) Eya ta eme kɔ be Mawu medi be míasẽ ŋuta le lãwo ŋu alo awu wo ɖe modzakaɖeɖe ta o.
(Psalm 11:5) So it stands to reason that God does not want us to harm or kill animals merely for pleasure or for sport.
Biblia ɖee fia be lãwo ƒe agbe xɔ asi le Mawu ŋkume ŋutɔ.
The Bible indicates that God places a high value on animal life.
Biblia gblɔ be le nuwo wɔɣi la, "Mawu wɔ gbemelãwo le wo ƒomeviwo nu, kple aƒemelãwo le wo ƒomeviwo nu, kpakple lã siwo katã tana le anyigba dzi le wo ƒomeviwo nu.

The Bible says that at the time of creation, "God went on to make the wild animals of the earth according to their kinds and the domestic animals according to their kinds and all the creeping animals of the ground according to their kinds.
Eye Mawu kpɔ be enyo. " 1 Mose 1:25.
And God saw that it was good. " Genesis 1:25.
Biblia gblɔ tso Yehowa ŋu be: "Eyae naa nuɖuɖu lãwo. "
The Bible says of Jehovah: "To the animals he gives food. "
(Psalmo 147:9) Mawu wɔ anyigbadzinu gbogbo aɖewo siwo nana lãwo kpɔa nuɖuɖu kple mlɔƒe.
(Psalm 147:9) God created an ecosystem that provides more than enough adequate food and shelter for animals.
Israel-fia David do gbe ɖa be: "Oo Yehowa, èxɔna na amegbetɔwo kple lãwo siaa. "
King David of Israel said in prayer: "Man and beast you preserve, O Jehovah. "
(Psalmo 36:6) Le Tsiɖɔɖɔ si xɔ anyigba katã dzi me la, Yehowa kpɔ ame enyi kple lã ƒomevi vovovowo ta hafi tsrɔ̃ ame vɔ̃ɖiwo.
(Psalm 36:6) During the global Flood, for example, Jehovah preserved eight individuals and all kinds of animals before destroying the wicked people.
1 Mose 6:19.
Genesis 6:19.
Edze kɔtɛe be Yehowa kpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe lãwo ŋu eye wòdi be amegbetɔwo nawɔ nu ɖe wo ŋu nyuie.
Clearly, Jehovah approves of his animal creation, and he expects humans to treat animals with due regard.
"Ame dzɔdzɔe léa be na eƒe aƒemelãwo. "
"The righteous one takes care of his domestic animals. "
Lododowo 12:10.
Proverbs 12:10.
Ale Si Nànɔ Te Ðe Akogotsitsi Nu
How to Deal With Loneliness
KUXIA
THE CHALLENGE
"Xɔ̃nye nyɔnuvi eve aɖewo li, wowɔa nu ɖekae eye wogblẽam ɖi.
"I had two girlfriends who would do things together and leave me out.
Wonɔa ale si wokpɔ dzidzɔe la gblɔm ɣesiaɣi mesena.
I constantly heard about what a great time they had.
Gbe ɖeka esi meyɔ wo dometɔ ɖeka la, evelia hã nɔ egbɔ ɣemaɣi. Ame bubue va ƒo nu kplim le telefon la dzi, gake esime nye kple amea míenɔ nu ƒom la, mese xɔ̃nye eveawo nɔ dze ɖom henɔ nu kom.
One time I called my friend’s house while the other girl was there, and when someone else answered the phone, I could hear the two of them in the background, talking and laughing.
Woƒe dzidzɔkpɔkpɔa ko mese, eye esia na megase le ɖokuinye me geɖe wu be metsi akogo! "
I only got to hear the fun, which made me feel even more lonely than I already was! "
Maria.
Maria.
Èse le ɖokuiwò me kpɔ be wogblẽ ye ɖi yetsi akogoa?
Have you ever felt left out and lonely?
Nenye nenemae la, Biblia me aɖaŋuɖoɖowo ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò.
If so, the Bible has advice that can help you.
Gake na míabu nu ʋɛ aɖewo siwo wòle be nànya ku ɖe akogotsitsi ŋu la ŋu gbã.
First, though, consider a few things you should know about loneliness.
NU SI WÒLE BE NÀNYA
WHAT YOU SHOULD KNOW
Ame sia ame kloe tsia akogo ɣeaɖewoɣi.
Nearly everyone feels lonely at times.
Ame xɔŋkɔwo gɔ̃ hã tsia akogo.
That includes people who seem to be popular.
Nu ka tae?
Why?
Elabe zi geɖe la, menye xɔlɔ̃ agbɔsɔsɔme si le ame si ye nana be wotsia akogo alo wometsia akogo o, ke boŋ xɔlɔ̃ si ƒomevi le ame si gbɔe wòtsona.
Because often it is not the quantity of friends but the quality of friendships that determines whether a person feels lonely.
Xɔlɔ̃ gbogbo aɖewo ate ŋu anɔ ame xɔŋkɔ aɖe si, gake xɔlɔ̃ vavã aɖeke manɔ esi o, esia ana wòatsi akogo.
Someone who seems popular could constantly be surrounded by people but have no real friends and therefore feel lonely.
Akogotsitsi ate ŋu agblẽ nu le wò lãmesẽ ŋu.
Loneliness can be hazardous to your health.

Numekula siwo lé ŋku ɖe numekuku 148 aɖewo siwo wowɔ la me tsonuwo ŋu la ƒo nya ta be ame siwo medea ha kple ame bubuwo ale o la tea ŋu kuna kaba, eye nu si wògblẽna le wo ŋu nu sẽ "teƒe eve wu nu si lolo fũu gblẽna le ame ŋu " eye "wòsɔ kple nu si sigarɛt-ti 15 nono gbe sia gbe gblẽna le ame ŋu. "

Researchers who analyzed the results of 148 studies concluded that low social interaction is a predictor of early death and that as a risk factor, it is "twice as harmful as obesity " and "equivalent to smoking 15 cigarettes a day. "
Akogotsitsi ate ŋu agblẽ nu le ŋuwò.
Loneliness can make you vulnerable.
Le nyateƒe me la, akogotsitsi ate ŋu awɔe be nàlɔ̃ faa adze xɔlɔ̃ ame sia ame ko.
In fact, it could cause you to settle for anyone who would accept you as a friend.
Ŋutsuvi aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Alan gblɔ be: "Ne ètsi akogo la, ànɔ didim vevie be amewo natsɔ ɖe le eme na ye.
"When you’re lonely, you may be desperate for attention, " says a young man named Alan.
Àte ŋu agblɔ na ɖokuiwò be, xɔlɔ̃ aɖe nɔ ame si la nyo wu ɖeke manɔ ame si, elabe afi aɖe kpɔkpɔ nyo wu yamekpɔkpɔ.
"You could begin to think that any attention is better than no attention.
Gake esia ate ŋu ahe kuxiwo vɛ. "
And that can lead to trouble. "
Mɔ̃ɖaŋunuwo meɖea akogotsitsi ɖa ɣesiaɣi o.
Technology does not always cure loneliness.
Aƒenɔvi aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Natalie gblɔ be: "Nukutɔe la, metea ŋu ŋlɔa nu na ame gbogbo aɖewo to asitelefon alo kɔmpiuta dzi gbe sia gbe, gake megatsia akogo kokoko. "
"I could text or e-mail a hundred people a day and still be incredibly lonely, " says a young woman named Natalie.
Sɔhɛ aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Tyler hã se le eɖokui me nenema.
A teenager named Tyler feels similarly.
Egblɔ be: "Nuŋɔŋlɔ na amewo to asitelefon dzi le abe numeɖenu ene, gake dzeɖoɖo kple amewo ŋkume-kple-ŋkume le abe nuɖuɖua ŋutɔŋutɔ ene.
"Texting is like a snack, whereas face-to-face contact is like a meal, " he says.
Togbɔ be numeɖenu vivina ŋutɔ hã la, ehiã be nàɖu nu ŋutɔŋutɔ hafi ate ŋu aɖi ƒo. "
"Snacks are great, but you need a full meal to feel satisfied. "
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ
WHAT YOU CAN DO
Susu nyui nènɔ asiwò.
Assume the best.
Tsɔe be xɔlɔ̃wòwo yi kplɔ̃ɖoƒe aɖe evɔ womekpe wò o eye nèva kpɔ fotoawo le internet dzi hahokadoƒe si dzi wodaa fotowo ɖo la dzi.
For example, suppose you go to a photo-sharing Web site and see pictures of your friends at a gathering to which you were not invited.
Nyataƒoƒo evee dze ŋgɔwò, àte ŋu aƒo nya ta be ɖe woɖoe koŋ gbe ye kpekpe na kplɔ̃ɖoƒea alo àgblɔ na ɖokuiwò be ɖewohĩ menye susu vɔ̃ aɖeke tae o.
At that moment, you have a choice either to conclude that you were deliberately snubbed or to adopt a more positive outlook.
Esi màte ŋu anya susu si tututu tae womekpe wò ɖo o ta la, nu ka tae nàbui be ɖe woɖoe koŋ gbe ye kpekpe?
Since you cannot know all the factors involved, why assume the worst?
Ðe manyo boŋ be nàdze agbagba abui be ɖewohĩ manye susu vɔ̃ aɖeke tae oa?
Instead, direct your energy toward thinking of a better explanation for your being excluded.
Zi geɖe la, menye nɔnɔme si me nèle lae nana nètsia akogo o, ke boŋ ale si nèbua nɔnɔmeae.
Often, it is not the situation but your outlook that brings on feelings of loneliness.
Biblia ƒe mɔfiame: Lododowo 15:15.
Bible principle: Proverbs 15:15.
Ƒo asa na nya siwo menyea nyateƒe ɣesiaɣi o gbɔgblɔ.
Avoid sweeping assertions.
Ne ètsi akogo la, ate ŋu adzɔ be nàgblɔ be: "Amewo mekpeam gbeɖe o " alo "Amewo melɔ̃a hadede kplim ɣeaɖekeɣi o. "
When you are lonely, you might think, ‘I never get invited anywhere’ or ‘People always avoid me.’
Gake ɖeko nuŋububu alea ana be nàgase le ɖokuiwò me geɖe wu be yetsi akogo.
But those sweeping assertions will only make you sink deeper into the quicksand of loneliness.
Eye esia ana nàse le ɖokuiwò me be wogblẽ ye ɖi, esia awɔe be wò ŋutɔ nàɖe ɖokuiwò ɖe aga, eye ne èɖe ɖokuiwò ɖe aga la, àtsi akogo, eye akogotsitsia ana nàse le ɖokuiwò me be wogblẽ ye ɖi.
Such thoughts can create a vicious circle: You feel like an outcast, which makes you isolate yourself, which makes you lonely, which makes you feel like an outcast.
Biblia ƒe mɔfiame: Lododowo 18:1.
Bible principle: Proverbs 18:1.
Lɔ̃ faa nàdze xɔlɔ̃ ame siwo tsi wu wò.
Be willing to befriend those who are older than you.
Biblia ƒo nu tso David ŋu. David mekpɔ xɔ ƒe blaeve ɣemaɣi o esime wòdo go Yonatan, ame si tsi wui abe ƒe 30 ene.
The Bible tells of the life of David, who was likely a teenager when he met Jonathan a man 30 years older than he was.
Togbɔ be Yonatan tsi wu David sãsãsã hã la, wo ame evea wova zu xɔlɔ̃ veviwo.
Despite their age difference, David and Jonathan became close friends.
(1 Samuel 18:1) Esia ate ŋu ava eme na wò hã.
(1 Samuel 18:1) You could have the same thing happen in your life.
Kiara, ɖetugbui aɖe si xɔ ƒe 21 la gblɔ be: "Nyitsɔ laa hafi meva kpɔe be xɔlɔ̃dzedze ame siwo tsi wu ame ɖea vi ŋutɔ.
"Recently, I’ve come to appreciate the value of having friends who are older than I am, " says 21-year-old Kiara.
Xɔ̃nye vevi aɖewo tsi wum ƒe gbogbo aɖewo, mekpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe ale si wobua nuwo ŋu nyuie eye woli ke nyuie la hã ŋu. "
"I have some very dear friends decades older than I am, and I really appreciate their mature view of things and their stability. "
Biblia ƒe mɔfiame: Hiob 12:12.
Bible principle: Job 12:12.
Kpɔ vi siwo wòɖena ne wò ɖeka nèli la dze sii.
Appreciate the benefits of solitude.
Ame aɖewo sena le wo ɖokuiwo me be yewotsi akogo ne woawo ɖeɖe woli.
Some people feel lonely as soon as they face a moment of privacy.
Gake mehiã kokoko be nàse le ɖokuiwò me be yetsi akogo ne eva dzɔ be wò ɖeka nèli o.
But simply being alone need not make you feel lonely.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Yesu dea ha kple amewo, ke hã edia ɣeyiɣi eya ŋutɔ ɖeka nɔa anyi.
For example, Jesus was sociable, but he also appreciated the value of solitude.
(Mateo 14:23; Marko 1:35) Wò hã àte ŋu awɔ nenema.
(Matthew 14:23; Mark 1:35) You can do the same.
Le esi nàbu wò ɖeka ƒe anyinɔnɔ be enye akogotsitsi teƒe la, zã ɖoɖoeziɣi ma boŋ nàtsɔ ade ŋugble le yayra siwo su asiwò la ŋu vevie.
Instead of seeing your being alone as a disadvantage, use quiet time to reflect appreciatively on your blessings.
Esia ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàzu xɔlɔ̃ si ƒe nu nyoa ame ŋu.
That can make you an even more desirable friend to others.
Lododowo 13:20.
Proverbs 13:20.
MAWUNYAKPUKPUI VEVI AÐEWO
KEY SCRIPTURES
"Ame si le fu kpem la ƒe ŋkekewo katã nye vɔ̃, ke ame si ƒe dzi le dzidzɔ kpɔm la tua aglo ɣesiaɣi. "
"All the days of the afflicted one are bad, but the one with a cheerful heart has a continual feast. "
Lododowo 15:15.
Proverbs 15:15.
‘Ame sia ame si ɖea eɖokui ɖe aga la tsia tre ɖe nunyawo katã ŋu.’
"Whoever isolates himself . . . rejects all practical wisdom. "
Lododowo 18:1.
Proverbs 18:1.
"Menye ame tsitsiwo gbɔe nunya tso aƒe ɖo oa? Eye menye agbe didie hea gɔmesese vanɛ oa? "
"Is not wisdom found among the aged, and does not understanding come with a long life? "
Hiob 12:12.
Bo
Bo
BO
BO
"Mekpɔe be sɔhɛ geɖewo tsia akogo, gake woɣlanɛ.
"I think many young people are lonely but try to hide it.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne woŋlɔ nu na amewo alo do ka kple wo le internet dzi hahokadoƒewo la, esi esia menye hadede kpli wo ŋkume-kple-ŋkume o ta la, ate ŋu awɔe be woatsi akogo. "
For example, if they text people or communicate through social networks, all those ‘friends’ aren’t really with them and that can make a person feel lonely. "
Abigail
Abigail
ABIGAIL
ABIGAIL
"Xɔlɔ̃wo le mí katã si siwo ʋu dzo le míaƒe nutoa me alo míegasea wo ŋkɔ o le susu aɖewo ta.
"We all have friends who have moved or perhaps for some other reason lost contact with us.
Edzɔa dzi nam be manɔ dze ɖom kpli wo nenye be wole didiƒe hã.
I find it’s good to keep in touch with them, even if they live far away.
Dzeɖoɖo kple xɔlɔ̃ xoxo aɖe ɖeɖe dzaa ate ŋu ana nàkpɔ dzidzɔ manyagblɔ aɖe. "
Just talking to an old friend can give you a tremendous boost. "
DUKƆWO KPLE AMEWO
LANDS AND PEOPLES
Tsaɖiɖi Yi Honduras
A Visit to Honduras
Honduras ƒe anyigbatata
A map of Honduras
HONDURAS gɔmee nye "Gogloƒe " le Spaingbe me. Ðewohĩ Christopher Columbus ye zã nya sia tsɔ ɖɔ tsi siwo le Atlantik-ƒuta.
HONDURAS means "Depths " in Spanish, a word Christopher Columbus may have used to describe the waters along this land’s Atlantic Coast.
Ame aɖewo gblɔ be afi mae Honduras kpɔ eƒe ŋkɔa tsoe.
Some say that this is how Honduras was given its name.
Hondurastɔwo dea asixɔxɔ gã aɖe nuteƒewɔwɔ na ame ƒe ƒometɔwo kple nuwɔwɔ aduadu kpli wo ŋu ale gbegbe.
Hondurans place high value on family loyalty and collaboration.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, zi geɖe la, srɔ̃ŋutsu kple srɔ̃a siaae tsoa nya me ɖekae le nya veviwo abe ga siwo woazã atsɔ akpɔ aƒea dzi kple ɖeviwo ƒe sukudede ene la ŋu.
For example, major decisions such as those regarding household expenses or the education of children are often made by both husband and wife.
Hondurastɔ akpa gãtɔ nye Mestizowo, si fia Europatɔ siwo ɖe anyigba ma dzi tɔwo ƒe viwo.
Most Hondurans are mestizos, a blend of European and indigenous peoples.
Honduras vidzidziwo ƒe to aɖewo me tɔwo gakpɔtɔ li, wo dometɔ ɖekae nye Chortí.
Some indigenous groups still remain, such as the Chortí.
Honduras vidzidziwo ƒe to siwo dometɔ aɖewoe nye Garifunawo gblɔna be teƒe bubu aɖee yewo tɔgbuiwo tso va tsi afi ma.
Other native Hondurans, such as the Garifuna, trace their ancestry elsewhere.
Garifunawo ƒe hadzila aɖe le ʋu ƒom
A Garifuna musician plays the hardwood drum
Garifunawo ƒe hadzila aɖe le ʋu ƒom
A Garifuna musician playing the hardwood drum
Garifunawo nye Afrikatɔwo kple Karib Indiatɔ siwo nɔ St. Vincent ƒukpo dzi la ƒe dzidzimeviwo.
The Garifuna are descendants of Africans and Carib Indians who resided on St. Vincent island.
Le ƒe 1797 me lɔƒo la, Garifunawo va ɖo ƒukpo siwo woyɔna be Islas de la Bahía (Bay Ƒukpowo) la dzi.
About the year 1797, the Garifuna arrived at Islas de la Bahía (Bay Islands).
Emegbe wova tsi Karib Ƒutawo le Titina Amerika ƒe duwo me.
Later, they settled along the Caribbean Coast of the Central American mainland.
Garifunawo tso afi ma kaka ɖe Titina Amerika kple Dziehe Amerika ƒe akpa vovovowo.
From there the Garifuna eventually spread throughout other parts of Central and North America.
Garifunawo lɔ̃a ɣeɖuɖu dzidzɔtɔe eye wonɔa ʋuwo ƒom.
The Garifuna enjoy lively dances performed to the beat of hardwood drums.
Woƒe dekɔnuwo dometɔ aɖewoe nye awu siwo le amadede vovovowo me, glitotowo kple nuɖuɖuwo abe ereba (enye abolo gbadza kpabɛ aɖe si wotsɔa agbeli wɔna) ene.
Their culture also includes brightly colored traditional garments, storytelling, and foods such as ereba (a large, thin cake made from cassava root).
Yehowa Ðasefowo ƒe hame 400 aɖewoe le Honduras.
There are some 400 congregations of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Honduras.
Wowɔa kpekpewo le Spaingbe, Eŋlisigbe, Garifunagbe, Honduras Tokunɔgbe, Chinatɔwo ƒe Mandarin kple Miskitogbe me.
Meetings are held in Spanish as well as English, Garifuna, Honduras Sign Language, Mandarin Chinese, and Miskito.
ereba

Ereba, enye abolo gbadza kpabɛ aɖe si wotsɔa agbeli wɔna
Ereba, a large, thin cake made from the cassava root
NU ÐEDZESIWO
FAST FACTS
Dua me tɔwo: 8,111,000
Population: 8,111,000
Fiadu: Tegucigalpa
Capital: Tegucigalpa
Dziɖuɖu: Demokrasi
Government: Democratic republic
Gbegbɔgblɔ: Spaingbe
Language: Spanish
Yame ƒe nɔnɔme: Anyigba xɔdzo, yame mexɔa dzo fũu le tonutowo me o
Climate: Subtropical, milder in the mountains
Anyigba: Dua ŋutɔ ƒe akpa 75 le alafa me nye tonutowo.
Land: Over 75 percent of the mainland is mountainous.
Dua ƒe ƒutawo nye togbɛwo eye eƒe akpa aɖewo hã nye ƒukpowo
There are also low coastal plains and islands
Vihehe Si Nyo Wu
Discipline That Works
ENYE nyateƒe be vihehe mele bɔbɔe o.
UNDENIABLY, parenting is hard work.
Gake ne womehe ɖeviawo ale si dze o la, ɖeko wògblẽa nyaa ɖe edzi.
But holding back discipline when it is warranted makes the task even harder.
Nu ka tae?
Why?
Elabena ne womena hehe ɖeviwo o la, (1) ɖeviwo yia edzi nɔa aglãdzenuwo wɔm si nana agbea tia wo dzilawo, eye (2) dzilawo ƒe nyawo megatoa mɔ ɖeka o eye wònana ɖeviwo tɔtɔna.
Because without discipline (1) children continue to be unruly, which exhausts the parents, and (2) parents give inconsistent direction, which confuses the children.
Gake vihehe si me lɔlɔ̃ le eye wòda sɔ la kpena ɖe ɖeviwo ŋu wosrɔ̃a ale si woabu tame kple ale si woanɔ agbe nyui.
On the other hand, loving, balanced discipline can train a child’s thinking and shape his moral character.
Enana ɖeviwo sena le wo ɖokuiwo me be yewole dedie ne wole tsitsim.
It also helps children feel secure as they grow to responsible adulthood.
Gake afi kae míate ŋu akpɔ mɔfiame adodoewo le atsɔ ahe ɖeviwo?
But where can you find reliable guidance for disciplining your children?
Biblia Ƒe Mɔfiamewo Nyo Na Vihehe
The Value of Bible Principles

Yehowa Ðasefowo, ame siwo nye magazine sia talawo, xɔe se be Biblia me nyawo nyo "na nufiafia, na mokaka, na ɖɔɖɔɖo, na amehehe. " (2 Timoteo 3:16) Mɔfiame siwo nyo na vihehe kple esiwo akpe ɖe ƒomewo ŋu siaa le Biblia me.

The publishers of this magazine, Jehovah’s Witnesses, believe that the Bible is, as it claims to be, "beneficial for teaching, for reproving, for correcting, for disciplining. " (2 Timothy 3:16, footnote) The Bible is far more than a mere parenting manual; its principles provide realistic guidance for families.
Bu eƒe kpɔɖeŋu aɖewo ŋu kpɔ.
Consider some examples.
BIBLIA GBLƆ BE: "Bometsitsi bla ɖe ɖevi ƒe dzi ŋu. "
THE BIBLE SAYS: "Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a child. "
Lododowo 22:15.
Proverbs 22:15, footnote.
Togbɔ be ɖeviwo tea ŋu wɔa nu nyuiwo hã la, wowɔa bometsinu ɣeaɖewoɣi.
Although children can be delightfully thoughtful and kind, they are also inclined to do foolish things.
Eya ta ehiã be woahe ɖeviwo.
Therefore, children need discipline.
(Lododowo 13:24) Ne dzilawo kpɔ esia dze sii la, akpe ɖe wo ŋu woahe wo viwo nyuie.
(Proverbs 13:24) Acknowledging that fact will help you fulfill your responsibility as a parent.
BIBLIA GBLƆ BE: "Mègagbe tohehe na vi o. "
THE BIBLE SAYS: "Do not hold back discipline from a child. "
Lododowo 23:13, etenuŋɔŋlɔ.
Proverbs 23:13, footnote.
Vidada aɖe le to hem na via nyɔnuvi
A mother and daughter laugh together
Mele be nàvɔ̃ be hehe si da sɔ nana viwòwo agblẽ nu le wo ŋu alo ana woava lé fu ye ne wotsi o.
You need not fear that balanced discipline will damage your children or cause them to resent you later in life.
Ne èhea to na viwòawo lɔlɔ̃tɔe la, ana woasrɔ̃ ale si woabɔbɔ wo ɖokuiwo awɔ ɖe aɖaŋuɖoɖo dzi ne wogbe nya na wo, eye woava hiã nɔnɔme sia ne wotsi gɔ̃ hã.
When lovingly administered, discipline will help your children learn to accept correction humbly a skill they will need even as adults.
Hebritɔwo 12:11.
Hebrews 12:11.
BIBLIA GBLƆ BE: "Nu si ame ƒãna la, esia kee wòaŋe. "
THE BIBLE SAYS: "Whatever a person is sowing, this he will also reap. "
Galatiatɔwo 6:7.
Galatians 6:7.
Dzilawo dina vevie be yewoakpɔ yewo viwo ta, eye esɔ nenema hã.
Parents naturally want to protect their children, and rightly so.
Ke hã, ehiã be woada asɔ.
Again, however, balance is needed.
Maɖe vi aɖeke na viwòwo ne èxɔa nya ɖe wo ta ne wowɔ nu gbegblẽ alo ʋlia wo ta ne woƒe nufialawo alo ame tsitsi aɖe gblɔ woƒe nu gbegblẽ si wowɔ la na wò o.
You do your children no favors by "rescuing " them from the consequences of their errors or by defending them when a teacher or another adult brings real misconduct to your attention.
Bu ame siawo be wonye yeƒe kpeɖeŋutɔwo boŋ.
Instead, view those people as your allies.
Ne èwɔe alea la, ke èle viwòawo fiam be woade bubu ame tsitsiwo ŋu, eye woade bubu wò ŋutɔ hã ŋuwò.
In so doing, you teach your child to respect authority including yours.
Kolosetɔwo 3:20.
Colossians 3:20.
BIBLIA GBLƆ BE: "Vi si womekpla o la dea ŋukpe mo na dadaa. "
THE BIBLE SAYS: "A child left unrestrained brings shame on his mother. "
Lododowo 29:15.
Proverbs 29:15.
He viwòwo le lɔlɔ̃ me, wò nya neto mɔ ɖeka, eye nàda sɔ
Be loving, consistent, and reasonable
Mele be dzilawo nasẽ tagbɔ le wo viwo ŋu o, gake ehiã be woakpɔ nyuie hã be yewomewɔa vi na wo o.
While parents should never be abusive, they also need to avoid the other extreme that of being permissive.
Agbalẽ aɖe (The Price of Privilege) gblɔ be: "Dzila siwo wɔa vi na wo viwo la menana ɖeviawo kpɔnɛ be ame tsitsiwo tee wòle be yewoanɔ le aƒea me o. "
"Children of permissive parents have little sense that the adults in the house are the ones who are in charge, " says the book The Price of Privilege.
Ne mèle wò ŋusẽ ŋu dɔ wɔm nyuie o la, viwòa ate ŋu asusu be yee kpɔ ŋusẽ le aƒea me.
If you do not assume your authority, your child may well assume that he is at the helm.
Eye godogodo la, ava wɔ nane siwo ado nuxaxa na wò kplii siaa.
Inevitably, he will make unwise choices that will cause him and you grief.
Lododowo 17:25; 29:21.
Proverbs 17:25; 29:21.
BIBLIA GBLƆ BE: ‘Ŋutsu aku ɖe srɔ̃a ŋu, eye wo ame evea woazu ŋutilã ɖeka.’
THE BIBLE SAYS: "A man will . . . stick to his wife, and the two will be one flesh. "
Mateo 19:5.
Matthew 19:5.
Le Biblia ƒe sedede nu la, ele be ŋutsu kple nyɔnu naɖe wo nɔewo hafi adzi vi eye woakpɔtɔ anɔ wo nɔewo gbɔ ne wo viawo tsi dzo le wo gbɔ.
According to the Bible, a man and woman should be married before children are conceived and should still be together after the children are grown and gone.
(Mateo 19:5, 6) Le gɔmesese ma nu la, srɔ̃tɔnyenye ƒe agbae xɔ nɔƒe gbãtɔ hafi dzilanyenye ƒe agba kplɔe ɖo.
(Matthew 19:5, 6) In that sense, you are a spouse first a parent second.
Ke hã ne wotsɔ dzilanyenye ƒe agba va ɖo nɔƒe gbãtɔ la, ana ɖevia nabu "eɖokui ŋu wu ale si dze. "
If your priorities are reversed, however, your child could come to "think more of himself than it is necessary to think. "
(Romatɔwo 12:3) Ne srɔ̃tɔwo tsia dzi ɖe wo viwo ŋu wu wo nɔewo la, woƒe srɔ̃ɖeɖea mali ke o.
(Romans 12:3) A "child-centered " family also weakens the marriage relationship.
Nu Si Akpe Ðe Dzilawo Ŋu
Help for Parents
Be dzilawo nate ŋu ahe wo viwo nyuie la, ele be woahe wo wòasɔ ɖe mɔfiame siawo nu.
For you to accomplish your goal as a parent, your discipline should adhere to these principles.
He viwòwo le lɔlɔ̃ me.
Be loving.
"Miganɔ dziku dom na mia viwo o, ale be dzi nagaɖe le wo ƒo o. "
"Do not be provoking your children, so that they do not become downhearted. "
Kolosetɔwo 3:21.
Colossians 3:21, footnote.
Wò nya neto mɔ ɖeka.
Be consistent.
"Mina miaƒe ‘Ɛ̃’ nanye ɛ̃, eye miaƒe ‘Ao’ nanye ao. "
"Let your word ‘Yes’ mean yes, your ‘No,’ no. "
Mateo 5:37.
Matthew 5:37.
Da sɔ.
Be reasonable.
"Mahe to na wò ale si dze. "
"I will discipline you to the proper degree. "
Yeremiya 30:11.
Jeremiah 30:11.
NYATI SI LE AKPAA DZI
COVER SUBJECT
Nu Ka Tututue Dzɔ Ðe Vihehe Dzi?
Whatever Happened to Discipline?
Le ƒe ʋɛ siwo va yi me la, ƒomegbenɔnɔ trɔ kura le yevudukɔwo me.
In recent decades, family life in Western lands has changed dramatically.
Tsã la, dzilawo ƒe gbe dzie ɖeviwo wɔna.
At one time, parents were in charge and children followed their lead.
Gake le ƒome aɖewo me egbea la, edze abe ɖeviwo boŋ ƒe gbe dzie dzilawo va le wɔwɔm ene.
Now, in some households it seems to be the other way around.
Bu kpɔɖeŋu siwo gbɔna ŋu kpɔ, wotu wo ɖe nu siwo dzɔna ŋutɔŋutɔ la dzi.
For example, consider the following scenarios, all of which are based on typical situations.
Esi ŋutsuvi ƒe-ene-vi aɖe kple dadaa yi fiase aɖe me la, ɖevia do asi ɖa be yeatsɔ fefenu aɖe.
While at the store with his mother, a four-year-old boy reaches out for a toy. His mother tries to dissuade him.
Dadaa dze agbagba be yeagbe nɛ hegblɔ be: "Fefenu gbogbo aɖewo le asiwò, alo? "
"You have enough toys already, don’t you? "
Ðe menya medoa ŋgɔ o, dadaa va kpɔe dze sii be menye nyae wòle be yeabiae hafi o.
Too late, she realizes that she should not have ended on a question.
Ðevia te gbe me tete gblɔ be: "Gake medi eya hã! "
"But I want it! " the boy whines. Fearing a tantrum his usual ploy Mom gives in.
Esi dadaa medi be wòagado ɣli ɖe ye ta abe ale si wòwɔna ɖaa ene o ta la, eƒlee nɛ kpoo.
A five-year-old girl interrupts her father as he is talking to another adult.
Nyɔnuvi ƒe-atɔ̃-vi aɖe fofo nɔ dze ɖom kple ame tsitsi aɖe eye nyɔnuvia gblɔ be: "Miaƒe dzeɖoɖoa tim, medi be mayi aƒe me! "
"I’m bored, " she announces. "I want to go home! "
Fofoa tso dzeɖoɖoa dzi hebɔbɔ gblɔ ɖe to me nɛ be: "Vinye, esusɔ vie ko míadzo, èsea? "
Her father stops mid-sentence, stoops down to his daughter, and asks in a soothing voice: "Just a few more minutes, Sweetie OK? "
Wogblɔ le James si xɔ ƒe 12 ŋu be egado ɣli ɖe eƒe nufiala ta.
Once again, 12-year-old James has been accused of shouting at his teacher.
Gake James fofo kpɔ dziku ɖe nufialaa boŋ ŋu.
James’ father is upset not at his son but at the teacher.
James fofo gblɔ nɛ be: "Ðeko wò nufiala ɖe vɔ̃e na wò.
"She’s always picking on you, " he says to James.
Meyina esama ge na sukutatɔwo. "
"I’m going to report her to the school board! "
Kpɔɖeŋu siawo menye nu siwo dzɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ o, gake woate ŋu adzɔ.
The preceding scenarios are imaginary, but they are hardly far-fetched.
Woɖe kuxi siwo ŋutɔŋutɔ dze ŋgɔ dzila siwo ɖea mɔ ɖe wo viwo ƒe amemabumabu ŋu, wɔa vi na wo viwo alo dea wo dzi ne wowɔ nu gbegblẽ la fia.
They illustrate a real problem that exists in homes where parents tolerate children’s rudeness, cave in to their demands, and "rescue " them from the consequences of their misconduct.
Agbalẽ aɖe (The Narcissism Epidemic) gblɔ be: "Eva le bɔbɔm le ŋkeke siawo me be dzila geɖewo megatea ŋu ɖea gbe na wo viwo o.
"It is increasingly common to see parents relinquishing authority to young children, " says the book The Narcissism Epidemic.
Gake ƒe ʋɛ aɖewo koe nye esi va yi la, ɖeviwo nya ame si dze aɖe gbe le aƒea me, wonyae be menye yewoe o. "
"Not that long ago, kids knew who the boss was and it wasn’t them. "
Enye nyateƒe be dzila geɖewo dzea agbagba be yewoahe yewo viwo nyuie. Woɖoa kpɔɖeŋu nyui na wo viwo eye wotɔa afɔ to heɖɔa wo ɖo le lɔlɔ̃ me ne ehiã.
Of course, many parents do strive to teach their children proper values, not only by setting a good example but also by giving firm but loving correction when needed.
Abe ale si agbalẽ si me míeyɔ nya tsoe va yi gblɔe ene la, dzila siwo nya viɖe siwo le esia wɔwɔ ŋu la "wɔa nu si to vovo na nu si ame akpa gãtɔ le wɔwɔm. "
Nevertheless, parents who recognize the value of doing so are, as the book quoted earlier puts it, "swimming against the cultural tide. "
Aleke wɔ nuwo va trɔ alea?
How did things get to this point?
Nu kae dzɔ ɖe vihehe dzi?
Whatever happened to discipline?
Dzilawo Megatea Ŋu Gbea Nya Na Wo Viwo Tututu O
Parental Authority Weakens

Ame aɖewo gblɔ be tso ƒe 1960 ƒe ƒeawo me kee dzilawo megate ŋu le nya gbem na wo viwo tututu o. Nu si gbɔ wòtsoe nye be agbalẽnyala siwo be yewonya nu tso vihehe ŋu la xlɔ̃a nu dzilawo be woƒe asi megasẽ ɖe wo viwo dzi o.
Some say that a weakening of parental authority began in the 1960’s, when so-called experts were urging parents to be more easygoing with their children.
Wogblɔna be: ‘Nye wo xɔlɔ̃, mègana woanɔ vɔ̃wòm o.’
They said: ‘Be a friend, not an authority figure.’
‘Kafukafu nyo wu tohehe.’
‘Praise is better than discipline.’
‘Mègagbe nya na viwòwo o, ke boŋ nɔ wo kafum ne wowɔ nu nyui.’
‘Rather than correct the bad, catch your children in the act of doing good.’

Ehiã be dzilawo nada asɔ le wo viwo kafukafu kple tohehe na wo me ya, gake agbalẽnyala siawo ƒe nyawo ɖee fia be tohehe na ɖeviwo ate ŋu agblẽ nu le woƒe seselelãme ŋu eye wòana woava lé fu wo dzilawo ne wotsi.

Instead of striking a balance between commendation and correction, experts seemed to imply that reprimanding children would damage their fragile emotions and cause them to resent their parents later in life.
Le ema megbe kpuie la, agbalẽnyalaawo ke gava le boblo domee be ele be woana ɖeviwo nase le wo ɖokuiwo me be ame veviwoe yewonye.
Before long, experts were also heralding the virtues of self-esteem.
Ðeko wòdze abe ɖe wova ke ɖe vihemɔnu nyuitɔ kekeake ŋu zi ɖeka ene, eyae nye be: Na viwòwo nakpɔe be ame veviwoe yewonye.
It was as if the secret to good parenting was suddenly discovered, and it was simply this: Make your children feel good about themselves.
Ele eme baa be ele be dzilawo nana wo viwo nakpɔe be asixɔxɔ le yewo ŋu ya.
Of course, it is important to instill confidence in children.
Gake ame siwo doa boblo susu si nye be ele be woana ɖeviwo nase le wo ɖokuiwo me be ame veviwoe yewonye la ya tɔ gagbɔ eme.
But the self-esteem movement took things to an extreme.
Agbalẽnyala siawo gblɔna na dzilawo be: ‘Miganɔ nya siwo ado dziku na ɖeviawo abe "Ao " alo "Mègawɔe O " ene gblɔm na wo o.
Experts told parents: ‘Avoid using negative words such as no and bad.’
Minɔ gbɔgblɔm na wo be woxɔ asi ŋutɔ eye woate ŋu awɔ nu sia nu si wodi.’
‘Keep telling your children that they are special and that they can be anything they want to be.’
Ðeko wòva le abe sese le ame ɖokui me be yenye ame vevi va le vevie na wo wu be woanye ame vevi ŋutɔŋutɔ ene.
It was as if feeling good was more important than being good.
Vifofo kple vidada le wo vi si nɔ fiazikpui dzi la kafum
Parents offer excessive praise to their son as he sits on a throne
Ame siwo doa bobloe be ele be woana ɖeviwo nase le wo ɖokuiwo me be ame veviwoe yewonye la na be ɖeviwo va bua wo ɖokuiwo amegãwoe
The self-esteem movement has done little more than make children feel entitled

Esia na be ame aɖewo va ƒo nya ta be ame siwo doa bobloe be ele be woana ɖeviwo nase le wo ɖokuiwo me be ame veviwoe yewonye la na be ɖeviwo va bua wo ɖokuiwo amegãwoe, eye wobunɛ be ele be woawɔ nu sia nu na yewo.
In the end, some say that the self-esteem movement has done little more than make children feel entitled, as if the world owes them.
Agbalẽ aɖe gblɔ be: "Esia wɔe be ŋutete si hiã be woado dzi atsɔ nyaheɖeameŋu kple dzidzedzemakpɔmakpɔ siwo doa mo ɖa godoo le agbe me la mesua wo si o. "
It has also left many young ones "ill prepared for the inevitable criticism and occasional failure that is real life, " says the book Generation Me.
(Generation Me) Vifofo aɖe ƒe nya si woyɔ le agbalẽ ma me gblɔ be: "Amebubu ame vevii ƒe nya aɖeke mele dɔwɔƒewo o. . . .
One father quoted in that book put it this way: "There is no self-esteem movement in the work world. . . .
Ne èŋlɔ nyatakaka aɖe si mede o le dɔwɔƒe la, wò dɔtɔ makafu wò be, ‘Ee, agbalẽ si dzi nèŋlɔ nua ɖo la nya kpɔ ŋutɔ’ o.
If you present a bad report at the office, your boss isn’t going to say, ‘Hey, I like the color paper you chose.’
Ðeviwo hehe alea menye nu nyui aɖeke kura wɔwɔ na wo o. "
Setting kids up like this is doing them a tremendous disservice. "
Amewo Ƒe Susu Le Tɔtrɔm
Shifting Opinions
Le ƒe geɖe siwo va yi me la, ale si amegbetɔwo ƒe susuwo trɔna nue vihehe ƒe mɔnuwo hã trɔna ɖo zi geɖe.
Over the decades, parenting practices have often reflected the ever-shifting opinions of humans.
Agbalẽnyala Ronald G. Morrish gblɔ be: "Vihehe ƒe mɔnuwo le tɔtrɔ dzi ɖaa.
"Discipline keeps changing, " writes educator Ronald G. Morrish.
Ne amewo ƒe nɔnɔme trɔ ko la, vihehe ƒe mɔnuwo hã trɔna ɖe enu. "
"It reflects changes in our society. "
Eya ta abe ale si Biblia gblɔe ene la, ele bɔbɔe be "nufiafia ƒe ya sia ya " nanɔ dzilawo ƒom anɔ yiyim anɔ gbɔgbɔm.
It is so easy for parents to be, as the Bible puts it, "tossed about as by waves and carried here and there by every wind of teaching. "
Efesotɔwo 4:14.
Ephesians 4:14.
Edze ƒãa be ale si dzilawo wɔa vi na wo viwo la le nu gblẽm.
Clearly, the current wave of relaxed discipline has had negative effects.

Esia na be dzilawo megatea ŋu zãa woƒe ŋusẽ o, eye le ɖeviawo hã gome la, mɔfiame siwo akpe ɖe wo ŋuti be woawɔ tiatia nyuiwo eye kakaɖedzi ŋutɔŋutɔ nanɔ wo si woatsɔ akpe akɔ kple agbemenyawo la mesua wo si o.
It has not only weakened parental authority but also left children without the guidance they need to make good choices and approach life with genuine confidence.
Ðe vihemɔnu aɖe li si nyo wua?
Is there a better way?
Nu Gbegblẽ Boŋ Fiam Nèlea?
Teaching the Wrong Lessons?
Tsɔe be wòe le nɔnɔme siwo gbɔna la me.
Put yourself in the following situations.
Èkplɔ viwò ŋutsuvi kple viwò nyɔnuvi tso kɔmpiutasrɔ̃ƒe yi saŋkuƒoƒosrɔ̃ƒe, eye nèkplɔ wo tso afi ma gayi bɔlƒoƒe, ale be woƒe mo nagadzaka o.
You are a ‘soccer mom.’ After school and on weekends, you ferry your son and daughter from one activity to another: skating lessons, piano lessons, soccer practice anything to keep them active.
Ègblɔ na ɖokuiwò be: ‘Ðeɖi te ŋunye, gake vinyewo nyae be yewo koe le vevie nam le agbe me, eya ta mawɔ nu sia nu si yewodi la na yewo.
‘I’m exhausted,’ you say to yourself, ‘but my kids know that they are my life and that I would do anything for them.
Ðe menye nenemae wòle be vidada nyui nawɔ na viawo oa?’
Isn’t that what it takes to be a good mom?’
Bu eŋu kpɔ: Nu ka tututu srɔ̃mee viwòawo le tso gbɔwò ne wona wò ame si dzi wo la dzea tre me dzea agba me ale be woƒe mo nagadzaka o?
Consider: What lessons are your children really learning by having a mother who will wear herself out just to keep them involved?
Ðe viwòwo mava susui be ɖeko ame tsitsiwo, vevietɔ dzilawo, li hena yewo subɔsubɔ oa?
In time, might your children come to believe that adults parents in particular are here only to serve their children’s needs?
Mɔnu nyuitɔ: Na viwòwo nakpɔe be hiahiãwo le wò hã ŋuwò.
A better approach: Let your children see that you have needs too.
Esia akpe ɖe wo ŋu woasrɔ̃ ale si woabu ame bubuwo kple wò ŋutɔ hã ŋuwò.
This will teach them to have consideration for others including you.
Fofowò sẽa ŋuta le ŋuwò eye wòhea nya ɖe ŋuwò vevie le wò ɖevime, eya ta nèɖoe be yemawɔ nenema ɖe ye viwo ŋu gbeɖe o.
You were raised by a harsh and critical father, so you have resolved to be the opposite with your children.
Esia wɔe be nèkafua viwò ŋutsu eveawo ɣesiaɣi, ne womewɔ naneke si dze kafukafu o hã.
At every opportunity you praise your two boys even when they have done nothing at all that was praiseworthy.
Ègblɔ be: ‘Ele vevie be mana woase le wo ɖokuiwo me be ame veviwoe yewonye.
‘It’s important to make them feel good about themselves,’ you tell yourself.
Ne wose le wo ɖokuiwo me nenema la, kakaɖedzi si hiã be woakpɔ dzidzedze le agbe me la asu wo si.’
‘If they feel special, they’ll have the confidence they need to succeed in life.’
Bu eŋu kpɔ: Nu ka tututu srɔ̃mee viwòawo le tso gbɔwò ne ‘èkafua wo madzemadzee’ kple susu ko be woase le wo ɖokuiwo me be ame veviwoe yewonye?
Consider: What lessons are your sons really learning by receiving ‘empty praise’ praise that is doled out just to make them feel good?
Ne èkafua viwòwo madzemadzee la, nu kae wòagblẽ le wo ŋu fifia kple etsɔme siaa? Mɔnu nyuitɔ: Da sɔ.
How might overemphasis on your boys’ self-esteem hurt them, both now and later in life?
Mèganɔ nya hem ɖe viwòwo ŋu vevie o.
A better approach: Be balanced.
Ke hã ne èbe yeakafu wo la, kafu wo ɖe nane si wowɔ nyui ta, meganye kesekukuɖɔɖɔ na wo o.
Do not be overly critical of your children; at the same time, base your praise on actual effort.
Tsɔe be nyɔnuvi eve siwo xɔ ƒe ade kple atɔ̃ le asiwò.
You are the mother of two girls, ages six and five.
Nyɔnuvi tsitsitɔ wɔa nu gbodogbodo.
The older girl tends to be hotheaded.
Etsɔ ɖeka pɛ ko wògado dziku hetu abɔ nɔvia.
Just yesterday, in a flash of anger, she punched her little sister in the arm.
Èva le ŋugble dem tso ale si nèkpɔ nyaa gbɔe ŋu.
You reflect on how you handled the situation.
Ègblɔ na ɖokuiwò be: "Nyemeka mo nɛ o, ɖeko medzro nu me kplii.
‘I chose to reason with her rather than to reprimand her,’ you recall.
Ðe mabi dzi ne megblɔ nɛ be nu si wòwɔa menyo oa? "
‘After all, won’t it damage my daughter if I tell her that she was being bad?’
Bu eŋu kpɔ: Ðe numedzodzro kple ƒe-ade-vi ɖeɖe dzaa akpɔ nyaa gbɔa?
Consider: Is reasoning alone enough for a six-year-old?
Ðe wògblẽ nyateƒe be woagblɔ na ɖevi be nu si wòwɔ la menyo oa?
Is it really harmful to use the word "bad " to describe the act of hitting a sibling?
Mɔnu nyuitɔ: Na ɖevia nakpɔ nu gbegblẽ si wòwɔ la me tsonuwo.
A better approach: Impose appropriate consequences for misbehavior.
Ne wohe to na ɖevi lɔlɔ̃tɔe la, akpe ɖe eŋu wòatrɔ eƒe agbenɔnɔ.
When administered in a loving manner, discipline will help your children learn to adjust their behavior.
ALE SI NÀWƆ AVO TSO NUTEÐEAMEDZI ME
FIND RELIEF FROM STRESS
Ðe Nu Te Ðe Dziwòa?
Are You Stressed?
"Nu tena ɖe ame sia ame dzi va ɖo afi aɖe, gake tɔnye ya wu gbɔgblɔ.
"Everyone has stress to some degree, yet I am overwhelmed with stress.
Menye nu gã ɖeka aɖe gbɔ koe wòtso o, ke boŋ etso nu vovovo siwo nye hloluitsotsowo kple ƒe gbogbo siwo metsɔ le srɔ̃nye ŋutsu si dze dɔ le ŋutilãme kple susume dzi kpɔm la gbɔ. " Jill.
It is not from just one big problem but from many situations, from struggles, and from seemingly unending years of caring for my physically and mentally ill husband. "​ Jill.
"Srɔ̃nye dzo le gbɔnye, eye eva hiã be nye ɖeka mahe mía vi eve.
"My wife left me, and I had to raise two children on my own.
Mele bɔbɔe be woanye dzilaɖekɛ o.
It was hard being a single parent.
Nu si gagblẽ nyaa ɖe edzie nye be, dɔ ge le asinye, eye ga menɔ asinye matsɔ adzra nye ʋu si gblẽ la ɖo o.
On top of that, I lost my job and I couldn’t afford to get my vehicle inspected for registration.
Nyemenya nu si tututu mawɔ o.
I had no idea how to handle things.
Nuteɖeamedzia wu tsɔtsɔ nam.
The stress was overwhelming.
Menya nyuie be mesɔ be mawu ɖokuinye o, eya ta meɖe kuku na Mawu be wòaɖe nye agbe ɖa. " Barry.
I knew deep down that it was wrong to kill myself, so I begged God to end my misery. "​ Barry.
Ðe nu tena ɖe wò hã dziwò ɣeaɖewoɣi abe Jill kple Barry enea?
Like Jill and Barry, do you sometimes feel overwhelmed with stress?
Ne nenemae la, ke nyati siwo kplɔ esia ɖo afa akɔ na wò eye woakpe ɖe ŋuwò.
If so, may the following articles comfort and help you.
Nyatiawo ƒo nu tso nu siwo gbɔ nuteɖeamedzi tsona, ale si wòate ŋu agblẽ nu le mía ŋu kple ale si míawɔ ate ŋu anɔ te ɖe enu fifia la ŋu.
They examine common causes of stress, how stress can affect us, and how we can get at least a measure of stress relief.
Nu Kawo Gbɔe Nuteɖeamedzi Tsona?
What Causes Stress?
Kɔdzi aɖe si wonya nyuie (Mayo Clinic) ka nya ta be, "Nu le tetem ɖe ame tsitsi akpa gãtɔ dzi.
"Most adults report being under increasing levels of stress, " says the well-known Mayo Clinic.
Egbea nuwo le tɔtrɔm eye nu siwo womele mɔ kpɔm na o la te ŋu dzɔna. "
"Modern life is filled with change and uncertainty. "
Bu nu siawo siwo gbɔ nuteɖeamedzi tsona dometɔ aɖewo ŋu kpɔ:
Consider just some of the changes and uncertainties that contribute to stress:
srɔ̃gbegbe
divorce
ame vevi aɖe ƒe ku
the death of a loved one
dɔléle sesẽ aɖe
severe illness
afɔku dziŋɔwo
serious accidents
nu vlo wɔwɔ
crime
hloluitsotso
a hectic pace of life
dzɔdzɔmefɔkuwo alo esiwo tso amewo gbɔ
disasters​ natural or man-made
suku alo dɔ ƒe agbanɔamedziwo
pressures at school or work
dzimaɖitsitsi ɖe dɔ kple ganyawo ƒe sesẽ ŋu
worries about employment and financial security
NE DƆ GE LE AME SI
"THE LOSS OF A JOB, "

Amerika Susuŋutinunyalawo Ƒe Habɔbɔ gblɔ be, "Ne dɔ ge le ame si la, ate ŋu ana ame natɔtɔ, ana ame si dɔ gblẽ na la nadze dɔ, ahe srɔ̃ɖeɖemekuxiwo, dzimaɖitsitsi kple blanuiléledɔ vɛ eye wòate ŋu ana ame nawu eɖokui gɔ̃ hã.
says the American Psychological Association, "can be devastating, putting unemployed workers at risk for physical illness, marital strain, anxiety, depression and even suicide.
Ne dɔ ge le ame si la, ekpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe agbea ƒe akpa sia akpa dzi. "
Loss of a job affects every part of life. "
ÐEVI SIWO DZI NU TE ÐO
STRESS IN EARLY CHILDHOOD
Nu tena ɖe ɖeviwo gɔ̃ hã dzi.
It is not uncommon for children to suffer from stress.
Wowɔa ŋlɔmi le ɖevi aɖewo ŋu le suku alo wometsɔa ɖeke le eme na wo le aƒe me o.
Some are bullied at school or neglected at home.
Wosẽa ŋuta le ɖewo ŋu, dzua wo alo dɔa wo gbɔ sesẽe.
Others are abused physically, emotionally, or sexually.
Wo dometɔ geɖe tsia dzi ɖe sukudodokpɔwo kple wo metsonuwo ŋu.
Many are anxious about exams and school grades.
Wo dometɔ aɖewo kpɔ eteƒe wo dzilawo gbe wo nɔewo, si na ƒomea gbã.
Still others see their family torn apart by divorce.
Ðevi siwo dzi nu te ɖo la, tea ŋu kua drɔ̃e baɖabaɖawo, nu menya srɔ̃na na wo o, woléa blanuiléledɔ alo womedina be yewoanɔ ame dome o.
Stressed children may have nightmares, learning difficulties, depression, or a tendency to be withdrawn.
Wo dometɔ aɖewo metea ŋu ɖua woƒe seselelãmewo dzi o.
Some seem unable to control their emotions.
Ele be woakpe ɖe ɖevi si dzi nu te ɖo la ŋu kaba.
A child suffering from stress needs urgent help.
Megbe

Nu Kae Nye Nuteɖeamedzi?
What Is Stress?
Nuteɖeamedzi nye ale si wò ametia wɔa nu le nɔnɔme sesẽwo me.
Stress is your body’s response to a demanding situation.
Wò ahɔhɔ̃ nana lãmetsi aɖewo dzina ɖe lãme na wò.
Your brain causes hormones to flood your system.
Esia wɔnɛ be wò dzi ƒona kabakaba, wò ʋu sina kabakaba, wò dzitodzito vuna alo mĩana eye wò lãmekawo liana.
These increase your heart rate, regulate your blood pressure, expand or constrict the capacity of your lungs, and tense your muscles.
Kaka nànya la, ametia le klalo anɔ te ɖe nɔnɔmea nu.
Before you are fully aware of what is happening, your body is primed for action.
Ne nu si he nuteɖeamedzia vɛ nu yi ko la, wò ametia gawɔa dɔ ale si dze.
When a stressful episode is over, your body comes off "high alert " and returns to normal.
NUTEÐEAMEDZI ATE ŊU AÐE VI ALO AGBLẼ NU
GOOD AND BAD STRESS
Nuteɖeamedzi nye mɔ aɖe si dzi ame tona nɔa te ɖe nɔnɔme sesẽwo alo afɔkuwo nu le dzɔdzɔmenu.
Stress is a natural response that enables you to deal with challenging or dangerous situations.
Tenɔnɔ ɖe nɔnɔmea nu dzea egɔme tso ahɔhɔ̃a me.
The stress response begins in your brain.
Nuteɖeamedzi si ɖea vi la ana nawɔ nu kpata.
Beneficial stress enables you to act or react quickly.
Nuteɖeamedzi si megbɔ eme o ate ŋu ana nàɖo wò taɖodzinuwo gbɔ alo ana nàwɔ dɔ nyuie, ɖewohĩ le dodokpɔ me, ne èle dɔ dim, alo le kamedefefe aɖe me.
A certain amount of stress can also help you to reach your goals or to perform better, perhaps during an exam, a job interview, or a sporting event.
Ke hã, ne nu te ɖe dziwò eteƒe didi, alo wògbɔ eme la, ate ŋu agblẽ nu le ŋuwò.
However, prolonged, extreme, or chronic stress can harm you.
Ne ètsia dzodzodzoe edziedzi la, ate ŋu agblẽ nu le wò ametia, wò seselelãme kple wò susu ŋu.
When your body is repeatedly or constantly on "high alert, " you may begin to suffer physically, emotionally, and mentally.
Wò nɔnɔme kple ale si nèwɔa nu ɖe amewo ŋu ate ŋu atrɔ.
Your behavior, including the way you treat others, may change.
Nuteɖeamedzi si nu sẽ ate ŋu ana ame natsɔ aha nono, atike vɔ̃ɖiwo zazã kple nuwɔna gbegblẽ bubuwo aɖo dɔe be yeatsɔ anɔ te ɖe enu.
Chronic stress can also lead to substance abuse and other unhealthy means of coping.
Ate ŋu ana ame nalé blanuiléledɔ, nu nati kɔ na ame, alo wòana ame nadi be yeawu ye ɖokui gɔ̃ hã.
It may even spiral into depression, burnout, or thoughts of suicide.
Togbɔ be ame sia ame kple ale si wòwɔa nui ne nu te ɖe edzi hã la, nuteɖeamedzi ate ŋu ahe dɔléle vovovowo ava ame dzi.
While stress may not affect everyone in the same way, it can contribute to a wide range of diseases.
Eye ate ŋu akpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe ametia ƒe akpa sia akpa kloe dzi.
And it can affect nearly every part of the body.
ŊUSẼ SI NUTEÐEAMEDZI ATE ŊU AKPƆ ÐE WÒ AMETIA DZI
HOW STRESS CAN AFFECT YOUR BODY
Ahɔhɔ̃mekawo ƒe dɔwɔwɔ.
Nervous system.
Ŋutsu aɖe ɖo asi ŋgonu, le nuteɖeamedzi ta.
A man, holding his hand to his forehead, feeling the effects of stress.
Wò ahɔhɔ̃mekawo nana wò ametia dzia lãmetsiwo abe adrenaline kple cortisol ene.
Your nervous system causes hormones such as adrenaline and cortisol to be released.
Esia nana wò dzi ƒona kabakaba, wò ʋu sina kabakaba, eye sukli si le wò ʋu me hã dzina ɖe edzi nu siawo katã kpena ɖe ametia ŋu wòɖea afɔ kaba ne afɔku gbɔna.
These increase your heart rate, your blood pressure, and the glucose levels in your blood​ all of which enable you to respond quickly to danger.
Gake nuteɖeamedzi si gbɔ eme ate ŋu ahe
Too much stress can lead to
dzikudodo, dzimaɖitsitsi, blanuiléledɔ, taɖuame kple alɔ̃madɔmadɔ vɛ
irritability, anxiety, depression, headaches, insomnia
Lãmekawo kple ƒuwo.
Musculoskeletal system.
Wò lãmekawo liana ale be woakpɔ tawò be nu vevi nagawɔ wò o.
Your muscles tense up to protect you from injury.
Gake nuteɖeamedzi si gbɔ eme ate ŋu ahe
Too much stress can lead to
lãmevee, taɖuame kple vevesese le lãmekawo me vɛ
body aches and pains, tension headaches, muscle spasms
Dzitodzito ƒe dɔwɔwɔ.
Respiratory system.
Dzitodzito ƒe dɔwɔwɔ kabakaba nana ame gbɔna ɔksidzin-ya nyuie wu.
You breathe faster to take in more oxygen.
Gake nuteɖeamedzi si gbɔ eme ate ŋu ana
Too much stress can lead to
gbɔgbɔtsixe natsi ame ƒo alo gbɔgbɔ masu ame o, eye le ame aɖewo gome la, enana dzidzi ƒoa wo
hyperventilation and shortness of breath, as well as panic attacks in those who are prone to them
Dzi kple ʋukawo ƒe dɔwɔwɔ.
Cardiovascular system.
Wò dzi ƒona sesĩe kabakaba ale be ʋu nate ŋu asi le lãme na wò nyuie.
Your heart beats faster and harder to distribute blood throughout your body.
Ʋukawo me vuna alo mĩana ale be ʋu nate ŋu asi ayi ametia ƒe akpa siwo hiãe wu, le kpɔɖeŋu me, ʋu sina yia lãkusiwo me ne ehiã le afi ma wu.
Blood vessels dilate or constrict to direct blood where your body needs it the most, such as in your muscles.
Gake nuteɖeamedzi si gbɔ eme ate ŋu ahe
Too much stress can lead to
ʋusɔgbɔdɔ, dzidɔ kple gbagbadɔ vɛ
high blood pressure, heart attack, stroke
Lãmenu siwo wɔa lãmetsiwo ƒe dɔwɔwɔ.
Endocrine system.
Wò lãmenu aɖewo wɔa lãmetsiwo abe adrenaline kple cortisol ene siwo kpena ɖe ametia ŋu wòtea ŋu nɔa te ɖe nuteɖeamedzi nu.
Your glands produce the hormones adrenaline and cortisol, which help the body react to stress.
Wò aklã nana sukli si le wò ʋu me la dzina ɖe edzi be wòado ŋusẽ wò.
Your liver increases your blood-sugar level to give you more energy.
Gake nuteɖeamedzi si gbɔ eme ate ŋu ana
Too much stress can lead to
ame nalé suklidɔ, ŋusẽ maganɔ ametia ŋu wòawɔ avu kple dɔlékuiwo o, si ana ame nànɔ dɔ dzem kabakaba, eƒe seselelãme nanɔ tɔtrɔm, eye wòava nɔ lolom fũu akpa
diabetes, lower immunity and increased illness, mood swings, weight gain
Dɔgbo ƒe dɔwɔwɔ.
Gastrointestinal system.
Nuteɖeamedzi ate ŋu ana wò dɔgbo ƒe dɔwɔwɔ me natɔtɔ.
The way your body processes food is disrupted.
Nuteɖeamedzi si gbɔ eme ate ŋu ana
Too much stress can lead to
dzigbɔ nanɔ ame tsɔm, ame nanɔ xe ɖem, ame nanɔ mitsi nyem alo ame mate ŋu anɔ afɔdzi dem o
nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation
Vidzidzi ŋutete.
Reproductive system.
Nuteɖeamedzi ate ŋu ana gbɔdɔdɔ ƒe dzodzro kple ŋutete nu naɖiɖi.
Stress can affect sexual desire and function.
Nuteɖeamedzi si gbɔ eme ate ŋu ana
Too much stress can lead to
ame nagbɔdzɔ le ŋutsu me, eye nyɔnu ƒe asiɖoɖoanyi me natɔtɔ
impotence, disrupted menstrual cycle
Ale Si Nàwɔ Anɔ Te Ðe Nuteɖeamedzi Nu
How to Deal With Stress

Be nàte ŋu anɔ te ɖe nuteɖeamedzi nu dzidzedzetɔe la, ele be nàbu wò lãmesẽ, ale si nèwɔa nu kple ame bubuwo, wò taɖodzinuwo kple nu siwo nètsɔ ɖoa nɔƒe gbãtɔ, siwo nye nu siwo le vevie na wò wu le agbe me la ŋu.

To deal effectively with stress, you need to think about your physical health, the way you interact with others, and your goals and priorities in life​ that is, what you consider to be truly important.
Nyati sia aƒo nu tso mɔfiame ŋutɔŋutɔ siwo ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nànɔ te ɖe nuteɖeamedzi nu nyuie wu eye be nàɖe edzi akpɔtɔ gɔ̃ hã la ŋu.
This article will review some practical principles that can help you to deal better with stress and perhaps even reduce it.
Bu Ŋkeke Ðe Sia Ðe Ko Ƒe Hiahiãwo Ŋu
Try to Live One Day at a Time
Nyɔnu aɖe le dzidzɔ kpɔm eye dzi le eƒo le dugã aɖe me
A happy and confident woman walking in a big city.
"Migatsi dzimaɖi gbeɖe le etsɔ si gbɔna ŋu o, elabena etsɔ si gbɔna la kple eya ŋutɔ ƒe dzimaɖitsitsiwoe. "​ MATEO 6:34.
"Never be anxious about the next day, for the next day will have its own anxieties. "​ MATTHEW 6:34.
Nu si wòfia: Gbe sia gbe dzimaɖitsitsi nye agbea ƒe akpa aɖe.
Meaning: Daily anxieties are a part of life.
Gake mègatsɔ etsɔ ƒe dzimaɖitsitsiwo kpe ɖe egbe tɔwo ŋu o.
But do not increase today’s anxieties by adding tomorrow’s to them.
Bu ŋkeke ɖe sia ɖe ko ƒe hiahiãwo ŋu.
Try to live one day at a time.
Nuteɖeamedzi ate ŋu ana ame natsi dzimaɖi.
Stress can cause anxiety.
Eya ta te esia kpɔ: Gbã la, se egɔme be màte ŋu aƒo asa na nuteɖeamedzi aɖewo ya o.
So try this: First, recognize that some stress is inevitable.
Ðeko dzitsitsi ɖe nu siwo ŋu màte ŋu awɔ naneke le o la, adzi wò nuteɖeamedzia ɖe edzi.
Fretting over things you cannot prevent increases your stress.
Evelia, zi geɖe la nu siwo ŋu míetsia dzi ɖo la, medzɔna ŋutɔŋutɔ o.
Second, understand that quite often things do not turn out the way we may fear they will.
Ðo Taɖodzinu Siwo Le Bɔbɔe
Set Reasonable Standards
"Nunya si tso dziƒo la, . . . esea nu gɔme. "​ YAKOBO 3:17.
"The wisdom from above is . . . reasonable. "​ JAMES 3:17.
Nu si wòfia: Mèganye ame si dia blibodede o.
Meaning: Do not be a perfectionist.
Mègaɖo taɖodzinu siwo gbɔ manya ɖo na wò ŋutɔ alo ame bubuwo o.
Avoid setting unrealistically high standards for yourself or others.
Da sɔ, ɖo taɖodzinu siwo le bɔbɔe, nya afi si wò ŋutɔ kple ame bubuwo sia ƒe ŋutetewo se ɖo.
Be modest, set reasonable standards, and know both your limitations and those of others.
Ne èwɔ esiawo la, ke àɖe nuteɖeamedzi dzi akpɔtɔ eye nu nyuiwo ado tso eme.
When you do this, you will reduce stress all around and even encourage greater success.
Azɔ hã, tsɔ nanewo wɔ nukokoe.
Also, keep a sense of humor.
Ne nanewo meyi edzi nyuie o gɔ̃ hã gake nètsɔe wɔ nukokoe la, ana nàɖe nuteɖeamedzia dzi akpɔtɔ eye wòana wò dzi nadze eme.
When you laugh​ even when something goes wrong ​you relieve tension and brighten your mood.
Nya Nu Siwo Nana Nu Tena Ðe Dziwò
Know What Stresses You
"Nugɔmesela gbɔa dzi ɖi blewu. " LODODOWO 17:27.
"A discerning man will remain calm. "​ PROVERBS 17:27.
Nu si wòfia: Seselelãme gbegblẽwo ate ŋu akpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe ale si nèbua nuwoe dzi, eya ta gbɔ dzi ɖi blewu.
Meaning: Negative emotions can cloud clear thinking, so try to stay calm.
De dzesi nu siwo nana nu tena ɖe dziwò kple ale si nèwɔa nui.
Identify what stresses you, and note your response.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne nu te ɖe dziwò la, de dzesi wò nuŋububuwo, seselelãmewo kple nuwɔnawo, eye àte ŋu aŋlɔ wo ɖi gɔ̃ hã.
For example, when you feel stressed, note your thoughts, feelings, and behavior, perhaps even making a record of them.
Ne èva nya ale si nèwɔa nui ne nu te ɖe dziwò la, ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nànɔ te ɖe nuteɖeamedzia nu nyuie wu.
By becoming more aware of your response to stress, you may be able to deal with it more effectively.
Azɔ hã, de ŋugble tso mɔ siwo dzi nàto aɖe nu siwo nana nu tena ɖe dziwò le agbe me la ɖa kura.
Also, think of ways to eliminate stressful things from your life.
Ne manyawɔ be nàɖe wo ɖa o la, di mɔ siwo dzi nàto anɔ te ɖe wo nu, ɖewohĩ anyo be nàwɔ ɖoɖo ɖe wò dɔwo alo wò ɣeyiɣi ŋu nyuie.
If that is unrealistic, look for ways to reduce their impact, perhaps by managing your tasks or time more efficiently.
Trɔ ale si nèbua nuwo ŋui.
Try to see things in a different light.
Nu siwo nana nu tena ɖe dziwò la, mana nu nate ɖe ame bubu dzi o.
What stresses you may not stress someone else.
Esia ate ŋu atso ale si nèbua nuwoe gbɔ.
The difference may be in viewpoint.
Bu aɖaŋuɖoɖo etɔ̃ siawo ŋu kpɔ:
Consider these three suggestions:
Mèganɔ susu vɔ̃wo bum ɖe amewo ŋu kabakaba o.
Do not be quick to assume bad motives.
Ame aɖe ate ŋu ava tso ŋgɔ na wò le fli me.
A person may cut ahead of you in a line.
Ne èbu eƒe nuwɔnaa be enye ameŋumabumabu la, ana wò dzi naho.
If you attribute his act to rudeness, you may become upset.
Ðe ema teƒe la, nu ka tae màbui be susu nyui aɖe tae wòwɔe ɖo o?
Instead, why not assume that his motive was good?
Anɔ eme hã be susu nyui aɖe tae!
You may be right!
Susu nyui nenɔ asiwò ɖe nɔnɔmea ŋu.
See the positive side of a situation.
Ne èle lalam be yeakpɔ ɖɔkta alo le yameʋudzeƒe ɣeyiɣi didi aɖe la, anɔ bɔbɔe be nàdo dzi alala ne èzã ɣeyiɣi ma tsɔ xlẽ nane, awɔ ɖoɖo ɖe dɔ ŋu alo atsɔ axlẽ wò e-mailwo.
A long wait at a doctor’s office or an airport is easier to bear if you use the time to do some reading or to catch up on work or e-mail.
Kpɔ nu yi ŋgɔe.
Keep the big picture in mind.
Bia ɖokuiwò be, ‘Ðe kuxi sia ava do ga ɖe edzi le ŋkeke aɖewo megbea?’
Ask yourself, ‘Will this problem be a big issue tomorrow or next week?’
De dzesi kuxi siwo nye sueawo alo esiwo anɔ anyi ɣeyiɣi kpuie aɖe kple esiwo nye ŋkubiãnyawo.
Distinguish between minor or short-term issues and more serious ones.
Na Wò Nuwo Nanɔ Ðoɖo Nu
Try to Be Orderly
Nyɔnu aɖe lé fon ɖe asi, eye wòle ɖoɖo wɔm ɖe ŋkekea ŋu.
A woman holding her smartphone, using a daily planning application.
"Mina nuwo katã nayi edzi nyuie ɖe ɖoɖo nu. " 1 KORINTOTƆWO 14:40.
"Let all things take place decently and by arrangement. "​ 1 CORINTHIANS 14:40.
Nu si wòfia: Dze agbagba nàna wò nuwo nanɔ ɖoɖo nu.
Meaning: Try to maintain order in your life.
Edzɔa dzi na mí ne nuwo le ɖoɖo nu.
We like a reasonable amount of order in life.
Nu ɖeka aɖe si ate ŋu ana nuwo manɔ ɖoɖo nu o, eye wòana nu nate ɖe mía dzi ye nye ne míehea megbelele, esia awɔe be dɔ nali kɔ ɖe mía dzi.
One thing that can contribute to disorder​ and stress ​is procrastination, and this may lead to a growing list of unfinished tasks.
Ðe manyo be nàte aɖaŋuɖoɖo eve siawo kpɔ oa?
Why not try these two suggestions?
Wɔ ɖoɖo aɖe koŋ eye nàzɔ ɖe edzi.
Make a practical schedule, and stick to it.
De dzesi nu siwo nana nèhea megbelele eye nàwɔ nane tso wo ŋu.
Identify and correct any attitudes that cause you to procrastinate.
Da Sɔ Le Agbe Me
Pursue a Balanced Lifestyle
"Gbɔɖeme asiʋlo ɖeka nyo wu dɔ sesẽ wɔwɔ kple dagbadagba ɖe yame asiʋlo eve. " NYAGBLƆLA 4:6.
"Better is a handful of rest than two handfuls of hard work and chasing after the wind. "​ ECCLESIASTES 4:6.
Nu si wòfia: Ame siwo vuna ɖe dɔ ŋu fũu la, mekpɔa viɖe aɖeke tsoa woƒe "dɔ sesẽ wɔwɔ . . . asiʋlo eve " la me o.
Meaning: Workaholics can deprive themselves of the benefits of their "two handfuls of hard work. "
Edzɔna be ɣeyiɣi alo lãmesẽ gɔ̃ hã meva nɔa wo si be woase vivi na nu si ŋu wokpe fu ɖo o.
They may have no time or energy left to enjoy what they worked for.
Susu nyui nenɔ asiwò ɖe dɔ kple ga ŋu.
Have a realistic view of work and money.
Ne ga geɖe le ame si la, mefia be akpɔ dzidzɔ geɖe alo nu mate ɖe edzi o.
More money does not mean more happiness or less stress.
Le nyateƒe me la, ate ŋu ana ame makpɔ dzidzɔ o eye nu nate ɖe edzi boŋ.
In fact, the opposite can be true.
Nyagblɔla 5:12 gblɔ be: "Nu gbogbo siwo le kesinɔtɔ si la menana wòdɔa alɔ̃ o. "
"The plenty belonging to the rich one does not permit him to sleep, " says Ecclesiastes 5:12.
Eya ta nɔ agbe ɖe nu si le asiwò la nu.
So try to live within your means.
Di ɣeyiɣi nàɖi ɖe eme.
Make time to relax.
Ne èwɔa nu siwo doa dzidzɔ na wò la, àɖe nuteɖeamedzi dzi akpɔtɔ.
You relieve stress when you do things you enjoy.
Ke hã, modzaka siwo nànɔ anyi ko aɖe, abe Television kpɔkpɔ ene made dziwò o.
However, passive recreation, such as watching TV, may not help.
Zã mɔɖaŋunuwo nyuie.
Keep technology in its place.
Ƒo asa na e-mail, text message kple internet dzi hahoo kadodowo zazã edziedzi.
Avoid constantly checking e-mail, texts, or social media sites.
Mèganɔ e-mail siwo ku ɖe dɔ ŋu xlẽm ne mèle dɔ me o, negbe ɖe wòhiã vevie ko hafi.
Unless circumstances require it, do not check work-related e-mail outside of working hours.
Kpɔ Wò Lãmesẽ Ta
Take Care of Your Health
Ðekakpui aɖe le du ƒum eye wòle nu kom.
A young man smiling as he is running outdoors.
"Ŋutilãmamla nyo. " 1 TIMOTEO 4:8.
"Physical training is beneficial. "​ 1 TIMOTHY 4:8.
Nu si wòfia: Kamedede edziedzi nana míenɔa lãmesẽ me.
Meaning: Regular exercise promotes better health.
Wɔ nu siwo ade wò lãmesẽ dzi.
Develop healthful habits.
Kamedede ate ŋu ade wo lãmesẽ dzi eye wòana wò ametia nanɔ te ɖe nuteɖeamedzi nu.
Physical activity can lift your mood and improve your body’s response to stress.
Ðu nu siwo me nunyiame le, eye nànɔ nu ɖum ɖe ɖoɖo nu.
Eat nutritious food, and try to avoid skipping meals.
Dze agbagba nàɖi ɖe eme wòasu wò.
Be sure to get enough rest.
Ƒo asa na nuteɖeamedzi "gbɔkpɔnu " siwo gblẽa nu le ame ŋu abe atamanono, atike vɔ̃ɖi zazã kple aha tsu nono ene.
Avoid harmful "solutions " to stress, such as smoking or drug and alcohol abuse.
Mlɔeba la, ɖeko nu siawo agblẽ nu le wò lãmesẽ ŋu eye woana naɖo ko.
In the long run, these heighten stress, perhaps by robbing you of your health and hard-earned money.
Ne wò nuteɖeamedzia wu tsɔtsɔ na wò la, ekema yi kɔdzi.
See your doctor if your stress becomes overwhelming.
Megakpe ŋu na wò be nàbia kpekpeɖeŋu tso ɖɔkta gbɔ o.
Getting professional help is not an admission of failure.
"DƆMENYONYO ATE ŊU ANA NÀÐE NUTEÐEAMEDZI DZI AKPƆTƆ "
"KILL YOUR STRESS WITH KINDNESS "
"Ame si nyoa dɔme la le nyui wɔm na eya ŋutɔ ɖokui, ke ŋutasẽla hea xaxa vaa eya ŋutɔ ɖokui dzi. "
"A kind man benefits himself, but the cruel person brings trouble on himself. "​ PROVERBS 11:17.
LODODOWO 11:17. Agbalẽ si nye Overcoming Stress ƒe tanya aɖee nye "Dɔmenyonyo Ate Ŋu Ana Nàɖe Nuteɖeamedzi Dzi Akpɔtɔ. "
The book Overcoming Stress has a chapter entitled "Kill Your Stress with Kindness. "
Agbalẽa ŋlɔla, si nye Agbalẽnyalagã Tim Cantopher gblɔ be ne èwɔa nu ɖe amewo ŋu dɔmenyotɔe la, ate ŋu ade wò lãmesẽ dzi eye wòana nàkpɔ dzidzɔ.
Treating others kindly, according to the author, Dr. Tim Cantopher, can promote health and happiness.
To vovo na ema la, ame si mewɔa nu ɖe amewo ŋu nyuie o alo sẽa ŋuta la, mekpɔa dzidzɔ o elabena eɖea eɖokui ɖe aga.
On the other hand, an unkind or cruel person makes himself unhappy because he alienates himself from others.
Míate ŋu aɖe nuteɖeamedzi hã dzi akpɔtɔ ne míewɔa nu ɖe mía ɖokuiwo ŋu nyuie.
We may also get stress relief by treating ourselves kindly.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, mele be míadi nu siwo gbɔ manya ɖo o alo sesẽ la tso mía ɖokui si o.
For example, we should not make harsh or unrealistic demands on ourselves.
Alo be míabu mía ɖokuiwo be míele ɖeke me o.
Nor should we belittle or malign ourselves.
Yesu Kristo gblɔ be: "Lɔ̃ hawòvi abe wò ŋutɔ ɖokuiwò ene. "
"You must love your neighbor as yourself, " Jesus Christ said.​ Mark 12:31.
Marko 12:31.
Set Priorities
‘Mikpɔ nu siwo le vevie wu la dze sii.’​ FILIPITƆWO 1:10.
"Make sure of the more important things. "​ PHILIPPIANS 1:10.
Nu si wòfia: Bu nu siwo le vevie na wò wu la ŋu.
Meaning: Carefully consider your priorities.
Ŋlɔ wò dɔwo ɖi eye esiwo le vevie wu la nava gbã.
List your tasks in order of importance.
Esia akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàlé fɔ ɖe dɔ siwo le vevie wu la ŋu, eye ana nàkpɔ esiwo ŋu nàɖe asi le alo ade asi na ame bubu kple esiwo me nàte fli ɖo.
This will help you focus on the more important jobs, and it will reveal which ones you can put off, delegate, or even eliminate.
Ŋlɔ ale si nèzã wò ɣeyiɣiwo le kwasiɖa ɖeka me la ɖi.
For a week, keep track of how you use your time.
Eye nàdi mɔ siwo dzi nàgazã wò ɣeyiɣiwo le nyuie wu.
Then look for ways to make better use of it.
Ne èzãa wò ɣeyiɣiwo nyuie la, mana nu nate ɖe dziwò o.
The more you are in control, the less pressured you will feel.
Wɔ ɖoɖo ɖe ɖiɖiɖeme ŋu.
Schedule some downtime.
Miniti ʋɛ aɖewo ƒe ɖiɖiɖeme ate ŋu ade agbe yeye mewò eye wòaɖe wò nuteɖeamedzi dzi akpɔtɔ.
Even short breaks can reinvigorate you and reduce your stress.
Vifofo kple vidada aɖe kpɔ vovo ɖe wo viŋutsuvi kple wo vinyɔnuvi ŋu.
A father and mother spending time together with their young son and daughter.
Di Kpekpeɖeŋu
Get Support
"Nuxaxa le dzi me ɖe wòtea ame ƒe dzi ɖe anyi, ke nya nyui nana dzi kpɔa dzidzɔ. " LODODOWO 12:25.
"Anxiety in a man’s heart weighs it down, but a good word cheers it up. "​ PROVERBS 12:25.
Nu si wòfia: Nya siwo amewo agblɔ veveseɖeamenutɔe alo dɔmenyotɔe la, ate ŋu ana agbe naɖo mewò.
Meaning: Kind, compassionate words from others can lift your spirits.
Ðo dze tso eŋu na ame aɖe si sea nu gɔme.
Talk things over with an understanding person.
Xɔ̃ si dzi nèka ɖo ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàkpɔ nuwo bubui alo nàkpɔ egbɔkpɔnu aɖe si dzi nèŋe aɖaba ƒu.
A confidant may help you to see things differently or even to see a solution you overlooked.
Eye ne èƒo nu tso eŋu ko la, ana nàvo le ɖokuiwò me.
And just unburdening yourself can make you feel better.
Bia kpekpeɖeŋu.
Ask for help.
Ðe nàte ŋu ade dɔ asi na ame bubuwo alo ana woakpe ɖe ŋuwòa?
Can you delegate a task or share the workload?
Ne wò dɔwɔhati aɖee nana nu tena ɖe dziwò la, di mɔ siwo dzi nàto aɖɔ nuwo ɖo.
If a work associate stresses you, look for ways to improve the situation.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ɖe nàte ŋu atsɔ aɖaŋudzedze ana amea nanya ale si eƒe nuwɔna nana nèsena le ɖokuiwò mea?
For example, could you kindly and tactfully tell the person how he or she makes you feel?
(Lododowo 17:27) Ne wò agbagbadzedzea medze edzi o la, ɖe nàte ŋu aɖe ɣeyiɣi si nèzãna le amea gbɔ dzi akpɔtɔa?
(Proverbs 17:27) If such measures fail, can you reduce the time you spend with the person?
Kpɔ Wò Gbɔgbɔmenuhiahiãwo Gbɔ
Care for Your Spiritual Need
Dɔwɔla aɖe le gbe dom ɖa le dɔme.
A businessman at his workplace praying.
"Dzidzɔtɔwoe nye ame siwo nyae be gbɔgbɔmenuwo hiã yewo. " MATEO 5:3.
"Happy are those conscious of their spiritual need. "​ MATTHEW 5:3.
Nu si wòfia: Menye nuɖuɖu, nudodo kple mlɔƒe koe amegbetɔwo hiã na o.
Meaning: As humans, we need more than food, clothing, and shelter.
Ehiã be míakpɔ míaƒe gbɔgbɔmenuhiahiãwo hã gbɔ.
We have a spiritual need.
Be míakpɔ dzidzɔ la, ele be míatsi dzi ɖe hiahiã ma gbɔ kpɔkpɔ ŋu.
To be happy, we must be conscious of that need and attend to it.
Gbedodoɖa ate ŋu akpe ɖe ame ŋu ŋutɔ.
Prayer can be a big help.

Mawu le kpewòm be ‘nàdro wò dzimaɖitsitsiwo katã ɖe ye dzi, elabena eléa be na wò.’ (1 Petro 5:7) Gbedodoɖa kple ŋugbledede le nu siwo tua ame ɖo ŋu la, ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nàkpɔ ŋutifafa si ana wò dzi nadze eme. Filipitɔwo 4:6, 7.
God invites you to "throw all your anxiety on him, because he cares for you. " (1 Peter 5:7) Prayer and wholesome meditation can result in deep inner peace.​ Philippians 4:6, 7.
Nɔ nu siwo ana nàte ɖe Mawu ŋu geɖe wu la xlẽm.
Read spiritually uplifting things.
Mɔfiame siwo ŋu míeƒo nu tsoe le magazine sia me la tso Biblia, si woŋlɔ be wòakpe ɖe mía ŋu míate ɖe Mawu ŋu la me.
The principles discussed in this magazine come from the Bible, which was written to satisfy our spiritual need.
Mɔfiame mawo nana ‘nunya vavãtɔ kple tamebubuŋutete’ sua ame si.
These also foster "practical wisdom and thinking ability. "

(Proverbs 3:21) Why not set a goal to read the Bible?

The book of Proverbs might be a good place to start.
TSƆTSƆKE ƑE VIÐEWO
THE POWER OF FORGIVENESS
"Ame si sea nu gɔme nyuie la, medoa dziku kabakaba o, eye atsyɔ̃ wònye nɛ be wòaŋe aɖaba aƒu agɔdzedze dzi. " LODODOWO 19:11.
"The insight of a man certainly slows down his anger, and it is beauty on his part to overlook an offense. "​ PROVERBS 19:11.
Le agbalẽ si nye Journal of Health Psychology me la, Aƒetɔ Loren Toussaint gblɔ be, "nuteɖeamedzi gblẽa nu le míaƒe lãmesẽ ŋu, eye tsɔtsɔke kpɔa míaƒe lãmesẽ ta. "
In the Journal of Health Psychology, Loren Toussaint states that "stress degrades [health] and forgiveness protects health. "
Egblɔ kpee be: "Tsɔtsɔke nye asiɖeɖe le seselelãme gbegblẽwo kple ale si míewɔa nu ɖe agɔdzelaa ŋu la ŋu eye esia wɔnɛ be susu nyuiwo va sua mía si ɖe agɔdzelaa ŋu. "
He adds: "Forgiveness is the release of negative​ and the potential enhancement of positive ​feelings, emotions, and behaviors toward an offender. "
Eƒo eta be ne míetsɔna kena faa la, "ana míaɖe nuteɖeamedzi kple emetsonu bubuawo dzi akpɔtɔ.
He thus concludes that a forgiving spirit "may help minimize stress-related disorders. "
Anya Wɔ Be Míavo Tso Nuteɖeamedzi Me
A Stress-Free Life Is Possible
Biblia ƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖo siwo me nunya le la ate ŋu akpe ɖe mía ŋu míavo tso nuteɖeamedzi me.
The wisdom in the Bible can help us to avoid much needless stress.
Manya wɔ be míaɖe nu siwo katã nana nu tena ɖe mía dzi la ɖa le mía ɖokui si o.
We ourselves cannot eliminate all that stresses us.
Gake mía Wɔla ya ate ŋui.
But our Creator can.
Etia ame aɖe gɔ̃ hã be wòava na gbɔdzɔe mí.
He has even appointed someone to come to our aid.
Ame mae nye Yesu Kristo.
That one is Jesus Christ.
Eteƒe madidi o ava wɔ nu wɔnuku siwo lolo wu esiwo wòwɔ esime wònɔ anyigba dzi la le xexea me godoo.
On a global scale, he will soon do even more wonderful things than he did when he was a man on earth.

"NUTEÐEAMEDZI ƑE ƔEYIƔI SESẼWO "
"PERILOUS TIMES OF GREAT STRESS "
"Nu te ɖe amewo dzi, wotsi dzimaɖi, lé blanui eye wole veve sem egbea wu ɣeyiɣi ɖe sia ɖe. " Mohamed S. Younis, Gallup ƒe nuŋɔŋlɔmetola.
"The world is more stressed, worried, sad and in pain today than we’ve ever seen it. "​ Mohamed S. Younis, Gallup managing editor.
Nu ka tae nuteɖeamedzi bɔ alea?
Why is stress so common?
Biblia ɖo nya sia ŋu eme kɔ nyuie.
The Bible gives a most reasonable answer.
Egblɔ le 2 Timoteo 3:1 be: "Le ŋkeke mamlɛawo me la, nuteɖeamedzi ƒe ɣeyiɣi sesẽwo kple kuxi sesẽwo ava. "
At 2 Timothy 3:1, it states: "In the last days will come . . . perilous times of great stress and trouble. "
(The Amplified Bible) Biblia yi edzi ɖe susu si tae la me be, nɔnɔme gbegblẽ si anɔ amewo si la gbɔe wòatso.

Nɔnɔme mawo ƒe ɖewoe nye ŋukeklẽ, ɖokuidodoɖedzi, alakpanuwɔwɔ le subɔsubɔnyawo me, adãwɔwɔ, ame ƒe ƒometɔwo malɔmalɔ̃ kple ɖokuidzimaɖumaɖu.
These traits include greed, arrogance, religious hypocrisy, a violent disposition, a lack of family affection, and a lack of self-control.
