Blemagbalẽ Aɖe Si Gaɖea Vi Na Mí Egbea
An Ancient Book for Modern Life
Ame geɖe dea bubu Biblia ŋu be enye subɔsubɔgbalẽ.
Many people respect the Bible for its religious significance.
Ke hã, menye subɔsubɔnyawo ŋu koe Biblia ƒo nu tsoe o.
However, the Bible offers more than religious guidance.
Eƒo nu tso nu ŋutɔŋutɔ siwo aɖe vi na mí le agbe me hã ŋu.
It has practical advice for everyday living.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, se nya si ame aɖewo gblɔ tso ale si Biblia xexlẽ kple eƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖowo dzi wɔwɔ ɖe vi na woe ɖa.
Consider, for example, what some people say about how they have personally benefited from reading the Bible and applying its advice in their life.
"Nye agbe va nyo wu.
"My life is more balanced.
Eye ale si mebua nuwo ŋui hesea wo gɔme la va nyo ɖe edzi.
My mental and emotional health has improved.
Meva le dzidzɔ kpɔm fifia wu. " Fiona.
I have gained a more positive outlook. "​ Fiona.
"Biblia sɔsrɔ̃ na taɖodzinu ŋutɔŋutɔ kple gɔmesese va le nye agbe ŋu. "
"From studying the Bible, I have found real purpose and meaning in life. "​ Gnitko.
Gnitko. "Nye agbe va nyo ɖe edzi fifia wu.
"My life has changed immeasurably for the better.
Meva nɔa agbe tsɛ eye mekpɔa vovo ɖe nye ƒomea ŋu. " Andrew.
I now have a simple, family-oriented lifestyle. "​ Andrew.
Kpɔɖeŋu ʋɛ aɖewo koe nye esiawo.
These are not isolated experiences.
Le xexea me godoo egbea, ame geɖe va kpɔe be aɖaŋuɖoɖo geɖe le Biblia me siwo ate ŋu aɖe vi na yewo le mɔ ŋutɔŋutɔwo nu.
Many people around the world have found that the Bible has much practical guidance for everyday life.
Na míakpɔ ale si Biblia ate ŋu akpe ɖe amewo ŋu le mɔ siwo gbɔna nu ɖa . . .
Let us consider how the Bible can help people enhance their . . .

Physical health
Míaƒe seselelãmewo
Emotional health
Ƒomegbenɔnɔ kple xɔlɔ̃wo

Gazazã

Mawusubɔsubɔ
Spirituality
Nyati siwo akplɔe ɖo la akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàkpɔe be menye subɔsubɔgbalẽ koe Biblia nye o ke boŋ aɖaŋuɖoɖo siwo ate ŋu aɖe vi na wò hã le eme.
The following material will show how the Bible truly is not only a sacred book but also one that can benefit you in tangible ways.
Lãmesẽmenɔnɔ
Physical Health
Menye atikeŋutinunyagbalẽe Biblia nye o.
The Bible is not a medical textbook.
Ke hã aɖaŋu siwo wòɖo la akpe ɖe mía ŋu míanɔ lãmesẽ me.
Yet, it promotes a healthful course of life.
Bu Biblia ƒe mɔfiame aɖewo siwo akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nànɔ lãmesẽ me la ŋu kpɔ.
Consider some Bible principles that can improve your life physically.
LÉ BE NA WÒ AMETIA
TAKE CARE OF YOUR BODY
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Ame aɖeke melé fu eya ŋutɔ ƒe ŋutilã kpɔ o, ke boŋ enyinɛ, eye wòléa be nɛ nyuie. " Efesotɔwo 5:29.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "No man ever hated his own body, but he feeds and cherishes it. "​ Ephesians 5:29.
NU SI WÒFIA: Biblia ƒe mɔfiame sia de dzi ƒo na mí be míawɔ mía tɔ sinua alé be na mía ɖokui.
WHAT IT MEANS: This Bible principle encourages us to do what we can to care for our physical health.
Numekuku aɖe ɖee fia be ale si ame akpa gãtɔ nɔa gbee gbɔe lãmesẽkuxi geɖewo tsona.
One study shows that many health problems are related to personal lifestyle choices.
Eya ta ale si nènɔa agbee la ate ŋu ana nànɔ lãmesẽ nyuie me.
Hence, making the right personal choices can lead to better health.
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ:
WHAT YOU CAN DO:
Ðu Nu Si Me Nunyiame Le.
Nutrition.
Ðu nu siwo me nunyiame le eye nànɔ tsi nom sɔ gbɔ.
Take charge of your nutrition by eating healthful foods and drinking enough water.
Nɔ Kame Dem.
Stay Active.
Ƒe ka kee nèɖaxɔ o, èɖanye nuwɔametɔ alo dɔléle sesẽ aɖe le ŋuwò o, kamedede ana nànɔ lãmesẽ me.
Physical activity can improve your health regardless of your age, even if you are disabled or limited by chronic illness.
Togbɔ be ame siwo lɔ̃ wò kple ɖɔktawo aɖo aɖaŋu nyuiwo na wò hã la, wò ŋutɔe awɔ edzi be wòaɖe vi na wò!
While loved ones and health practitioners can assist you with your exercise program, only you can make it work!
Dɔ Alɔ̃ Wòasu Wò.
Get Enough Sleep.
Ne mèdɔa alɔ̃ wòsua wò o la, ate ŋu ana nàva dze dɔ vevie emegbe.
Prolonged sleep deprivation is associated with risks for serious illnesses.
Ame aɖewo tsɔa nu geɖe doa agba na wo ɖokuiwo le alɔ̃dɔɣiwo.
As a result of the choices they make, many people do not get enough sleep.
Ke hã ne ètiae be yeadɔ alɔ̃ wòasu ye nyuie la, ànɔ lãmesẽ me.
Yet, by choosing to sleep enough, you choose to live better.
TSRI NUMAME GBEGBLẼWO
AVOID HARMFUL HABITS
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Mina míakɔ mía ɖokui ŋu tso ŋutilã kple gbɔgbɔ ƒe ɖiƒoƒo sia ɖiƒoƒo me. " 2 Korintotɔwo 7:1.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Let us cleanse ourselves of every defilement of flesh and spirit. "​ 2 Corinthians 7:1.
NU SI WÒFIA: Eɖea vi na mí ŋutɔ ne míetsri nu siwo gblẽa nu le mía ŋu abe atama kple nu bubu siwo nye nu siwo koŋ gblẽa nu le míaƒe lãmesẽ ŋu eye wohea ku vɛ.
WHAT IT MEANS: We benefit from not polluting our bodies with harmful substances such as tobacco products, which are known to be a major cause of disease and death.
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ: Ðo ɣeyiɣi si nàdzudzɔ keŋkeŋ eye nàde dzesii ɖi.
WHAT YOU CAN DO: Set a date to quit, and mark it on your calendar.
Hafi ŋkeke ma naɖo la, tsɔ sigaretwo, dzowɔgbawo, dzosinuwo kple nu bubu siwo do ƒome kplii la ƒu gbe.
Just before that day, dispose of cigarettes, ashtrays, lighters, and other paraphernalia associated with this harmful habit.
Mèganɔ teƒe siwo amewo aƒoe ɖe nuwò be nàƒo ɖokuiwò ɖe nuwɔna siawo me yim o.
Avoid places where others engage in habits like this.
Gblɔ ale si nètso nya mee na xɔlɔ̃ siwo di be nàtrɔ ne woakpe ɖe ŋuwò.
Tell supporting friends about your decision.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME BUBUWO
OTHER BIBLE PRINCIPLES
Ŋutsu aɖe le Biblia xlẽm
A man reads the Bible
Bia Yehowa Ðasefo siwo le miaƒe nutoa me dometɔ aɖe ne wòana Biblia ɖeka wò
You may obtain a printed copy of the Bible by contacting one of Jehovah’s Witnesses in your community
WƆ NU SIWO ANA NÀNƆ DEDIE.
BE SAFETY CONSCIOUS.
"Ne ètso aƒe yeye la, tɔ kpɔ ɖe xɔa tame, bena ame aɖeke magage le edzi, eye nàna wò aƒe naɖi ʋufɔ o. " 5 MOSE 22:8.
"If you build a new house, you must also make a parapet for your roof, so that you may not bring bloodguilt on your house because of someone falling from it. "​ DEUTERONOMY 22:8.
ÐU WÒ DZIKU DZI.
CONTROL YOUR ANGER.
"Ame si medoa dziku kabakaba o la, nugɔmesese bɔ ɖe esi, ke ame si megbɔa dzi ɖi o la ɖea eƒe bometsitsi fiana. " LODODOWO 14:29.
"The one who is slow to anger has great discernment, but the impatient one displays his foolishness. "​ PROVERBS 14:29.
TSRI NU TSU ÐUÐU.
AVOID OVEREATING.
‘Mèganɔ nu tsu ɖulawo dome o.’ LODODOWO 23:20.
"Do not be . . . among those who gorge themselves. "​ PROVERBS 23:20.
Ƒomegbenɔnɔ Kple Xɔlɔ̃wo
Family Life and Friendships
Esesẽna na ame geɖe be woadze xɔlɔ̃wo eye woana wo kpli wo dome navivi.
Many find it daunting to maintain strong personal relationships.
Bu Biblia ƒe mɔfiame siwo ate ŋu akpe ɖe ŋuwò be nàna wò kple amewo dome navivi ŋu kpɔ.
Consider some Bible principles that can help you improve your life socially.
MÈGADI ÐOKUIWÒ TƆ O
BE UNSELFISH
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: ‘Miganɔ miawo ŋutɔ miaƒe nyonyo ko dim o, ke midi ame bubuwo hã ƒe nyonyo.’ Filipitɔwo 2:4.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Look out not only for your own interests, but also for the interests of others. "​ Philippians 2:4.
NU SI WÒFIA: Mía kple amewo dome anyo ɖe edzi wu ne míenana míaƒe susu nɔa nu si míate ŋu awɔ na wo, tsɔ wu nu si woawɔ na mí ŋu.
WHAT IT MEANS: Successful relationships are more about giving than about receiving.
Ne ɖokuiwò tɔ ko nèdina la, wò kple amewo dome agblẽ.
If you follow a selfish course of life, you can damage your relationships with others.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ate ŋu adzɔ be srɔ̃tɔ si dia eɖokuitɔ la, mawɔ nuteƒe na srɔ̃a o.
For example, a selfish marriage mate may be disloyal to his or her partner.
Azɔ hã, ame aɖeke medina be yeadze xɔ̃ ame si dana le nu siwo le esi ta alo le nu si wònya ta o.
Additionally, nobody wants to make friends with a person who always boasts about what he owns or knows.
Agbalẽ aɖe (The Road to Character) gblɔ be, "ame siwo dia wo ɖokui ɖeɖe ko tɔ la va toa kuxi vovovowo me. "
Thus, as the book The Road to Character says, "self-centeredness leads in several unfortunate directions. "
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ:
WHAT YOU CAN DO:
Kpe ɖe amewo ŋu.
Help others.
Kakaɖedzi kple ɖokuitsɔtsɔna ye nana xɔlɔ̃wo dome sẽna ɖe edzi.
Strong friendships stem from a sense of commitment and trust.
Numekuku aɖe ɖee fia be ame siwo kpena ɖe amewo ŋu la meléa blanuiléledɔ kaba o, eye enana amewo dea bubu wo ŋu.
Some studies indicate that people who help others suffer less from depression and boost their own self-esteem.
Se veve ɖe amewo nu.
Show empathy.
Woɖe veveseɖeamenu gɔme be enye vevesese si sem ame bubu le la sese le wò dzi me.
Empathy has been described as feeling another person’s pain in your heart.
Ne èsea veve ɖe ame nu la, awɔe be mànɔ hatsekanya siwo tɔa ame gblɔm ɖe amewo ŋu be wòave wo o.
If you show empathy, you will be less likely to use biting sarcasm, that is, sharp and often ironic expressions intended to hurt the feelings of another person.
Ne èsea veve ɖe amewo nu la, màna woƒe nuwɔnawo nanɔ fu ɖem na wò o.
When you show empathy, you also become tolerant of others.
Veveseseɖeamenu akpe ɖe ŋuwò be màbu nazã ɖe amewo ŋu o, azɔ hã, àdze xɔlɔ̃ ame siwo tso dukɔ kple teƒe vovovowo faa.
Thus, empathy can help you to avoid being prejudiced and also to make friends from different cultures or backgrounds.
Kpɔ vovo ɖe amewo ŋu.
Give of your time.
Ne èkpɔa vovo ɖe amewo ŋu la, awɔe be nànya wo nyuie wu.
The more time you spend with others, the better you will get to know them.
Ahiã be nàɖo dze tuameɖowo kple amewo, esia awɔe be nàte ŋu adze xɔ̃ wo.
You need to have meaningful conversations with others to make real friends.
Eya ta nye toɖola nyui.
So be a good listener.
Ðee fia xɔ̃wòa be yetsɔ ɖe le eme nɛ.
Show interest in your friends’ concerns.
Numekuku aɖe si wowɔ nyitsɔ laa gblɔ be "dze tuameɖowo ɖoɖo kple amewo nana wokpɔa dzidzɔ. "
A recent study states that "deep conversations may actually make people happier. "
TIA WÒ ZƆHƐWO LE NUNYA ME
CHOOSE FRIENDSHIPS WISELY
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Hadede vɔ̃wo gblẽa nɔnɔme nyuiwo. " 1 Korintotɔwo 15:33.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Bad associations corrupt good morals. "​ 1 Corinthians 15:33, footnote.
NU SI WÒFIA: Ame siwo nèdea ha kplii la ate ŋu akpɔ ŋusẽ nyui alo ŋusẽ gbegblẽ ɖe dziwò.
WHAT IT MEANS: The people you spend time with have a great influence on you​ for good or for bad.
Ame siwo srɔ̃a nu tso amegbetɔwo ƒe nɔnɔmewo ŋu lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be ame siwo míedea ha kplii la kpɔa ŋusẽ gã ɖe mía dzi.
Sociologists agree that such influence can affect your life.
Akpatɔgbɔnɔla mesea akpa dzena o, le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne èdea ha kple ame siwo noa sigaret alo ame siwo gbea wo srɔ̃wo la, wò hã adze sigaret yɔyɔ alo àdi be yeagbe ye srɔ̃.
For example, they say that if you surround yourself with people who smoke or who are getting divorced, you may be more likely to start smoking or to want a divorce.
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ: Dze xɔ̃ ame siwo dea asixɔxɔ nu siwo ŋu nèdea asixɔxɔe siwo ɖea nɔnɔme siwo dzea ŋuwò fiana alo nàdi be yeasrɔ̃ la.
WHAT YOU CAN DO: Make friends with people who display qualities and have values you admire or want to imitate.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, dze xɔ̃ ame siwo ɖɔa ŋu ɖo, dea bubu ame ŋu, nye dɔmenyolawo kple amedzrowɔlawo.
For instance, seek association with people who are tactful, respectful, generous, and hospitable.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME BUBUWO

Watch Bible-based videos designed to help married couples, teenagers, and young children improve their family life
TSRI NYA TƆAMEWO GBƆGBLƆ.
AVOID HURTFUL SPEECH.
"Nuƒoƒo eŋumabumabui le abe yitɔame ene. " LODODOWO 12:18.
"Thoughtless speech is like the stabs of a sword. "​ PROVERBS 12:18.
NYO DƆME.
BE GENEROUS.
"Eme anyo na dɔmenyotɔ. " LODODOWO 11:25.
"The generous person will prosper. "​ PROVERBS 11:25.
WƆ NU ÐE AMEWO ŊU ABE ALE SI NÀDI BE WOAWƆ NA YE ENE.
TREAT OTHERS AS YOU WANT TO BE TREATED.
"Nu sia nu si miedina be amewo nawɔ na mi la, miawo hã miwɔ nenema ke na wo. "
"All things . . . that you want men to do to you, you also must do to them. "​ MATTHEW 7:12.
MATEO 7:12. Gazazã
Financial Stability
Biblia ƒe mɔfiamewo le kpekpem ɖe ame geɖewo ŋu wole ga zãm nyuie wu.
Many people have minimized their money problems by applying Bible principles.
WƆ ÐOÐO NYUI
HAVE A GOOD PLAN
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Veviedola ƒe ɖoɖowo hea dzidzedzekpɔkpɔ vanɛ, ke ame sia ame si tsia klokloklo la, hiã atui. " Lododowo 21:5.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "The plans of the diligent surely lead to success, but all who are hasty surely head for poverty. "​ Proverbs 21:5.
NU SI WÒFIA: Nu vevi si akpe ɖe ŋuwò nàkpɔ dzidzedzee nye be nàzɔ ɖe ɖoɖo siwo nèwɔ dzi.
WHAT IT MEANS: Diligently sticking to your plans is an important key to success.
Eya ta wɔ ɖoɖo ɖe gazazã ŋu.
Therefore, plan before spending.
Ðo ŋku edzi be menye nu sia nu si ŋu nèke ɖo koe nàƒle o.
Remember, you likely cannot buy everything you want.
Eya ta zã ga le nunya me.
Thus, spend your money wisely.
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ:
WHAT YOU CAN DO:
Wɔ ɖoɖo eye nàzɔ ɖe edzi.
Stick to a budget.
Ŋlɔ wò gazazãwo katã ɖi, eye nàma wo ɖe nu vovovoawo nu.
Write down all your expenses, and put them in categories.
Eyome ma ga ɖe nuawo nu.
Then allocate funds for each expense.
Ne èzã ga ɖe nanewo ŋu wu la, ɖee le ɖewo ŋu nàtsɔ aɖo ema teƒe.
If you overspend in one category, take money from another to cover the difference.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne èzã ga fũu ɖe mɔ̃memi ŋu la, ɖe gaa tso nu bubu siwo mele vevie tututu o abe awuƒlega ene ŋu nàtsɔ aɖo eteƒe.
For example, if you spent more than you planned on automobile fuel, take money set aside for a less important purpose​ for example, dining out.
Ƒo asa na fenyinyi.
Avoid unnecessary debt.
Dze agbagba ɖe sia ɖe nàtsri fenyinyi.
To the extent possible, avoid going into debt.
Ðe ema teƒe la, dzra ga ɖo nàtsɔ aƒle nu siwo hiã wò la.
Instead, save up to buy the items you need.
Ne èzãa agbananuƒlegbalẽvi la, dze agbagba nàxe ga siwo katã susɔ ɣleti sia ɣleti be màganɔ deme xem na wo o.
If you use a credit card, try to pay off your balance in full each month to avoid paying interest.
Ne fe le ŋuwò la, wɔ ɖoɖo ɖe exexe ŋu eye nàzɔ ɖe edzi.
If you are in debt, set up a repayment plan, and then stick to it.
Numekuku aɖe ɖee fia be ne amewo tsɔ agbananuƒlegbalẽvi le nu ƒlem la, woƒlea nu wògbɔa eme.
One study suggests that when paying with a credit card, people are prone to spend more.
Eya ta ne agbananuƒlegbalẽvi le asiwò la, nya ale si nàzãe.
So if you have a credit card, use it with restraint.
KPƆ NYUIE LE NUMAME GBEGBLẼWO ŊU
BEWARE OF HARMFUL ATTITUDES
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Kuviatɔ medea agble le vuvɔŋɔli o, eya ta abia nu le nuŋeɣi, esi naneke mele esi o ta. " Lododowo 20:4.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "The lazy one does not plow in winter, so he will be begging during the harvest when he has nothing. "​ Proverbs 20:4.
NU SI WÒFIA: Kuviawɔwɔ ate ŋu ana ame naɖi hiã.
WHAT IT MEANS: Laziness can contribute to poverty.
Eya ta do vevie dɔ, eye ne anya wɔ la, nàwɔ ɖoɖo ɖe ale si nàzã ga fifia kple etsɔme ŋu.
Therefore, be a diligent worker, and to the extent possible, plan your financial future.
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ:
WHAT YOU CAN DO:
Wɔ dɔ sesĩe.
Work hard.
Lé fɔ ɖe dɔ si nèwɔna ŋu eye nànye ame si dzi woate ŋu aka ɖo.
Protect your source of income by being industrious and dependable at your job.
Dɔtɔwo lɔ̃a ame siwo doa vevie dɔ.
Employers appreciate diligence.
Ði anukware.
Be honest.
Mèganɔ ame si nèle dɔ wɔm na fim o.
Do not steal from your employer.
Anukwaremaɖimaɖi agblẽ wò ŋkɔ eye asesẽ hafi nàgakpɔ dɔ.
Dishonesty could mar your reputation and make it difficult for you to find employment later on.
Mègaklẽ ŋu o.
Avoid greed.
Ne èklẽa ŋu ɖe ga ŋu la, ava gblẽ nu le wò lãmesẽ ŋu eye wòana wò kple ame bubuwo dome nagblẽ.
An unbalanced approach to money can eventually damage your health and your relationships with others.
Ðo ŋku edzi be agbe xɔ asi wu ga.
Remember, there is more to life than money.

DO NOT WASTE TIME AND RESOURCES ON BAD HABITS.
"Ahamula kple nu tsu ɖula la, ada ahe, eye akɔlɔ̃edɔdɔ ɖe wònana wotsia ɖovu me. "
"A drunkard and a glutton will come to poverty, and drowsiness will clothe one with rags. "​ PROVERBS 23:21.
LODODOWO 23:21.
AVOID UNDUE STRESS.
MÈGATSI DZI FŨU AKPA ÐE GA ŊU O. "Midzudzɔ dzimaɖitsitsi ɖe miaƒe agbewo ŋu le nu si miaɖu alo nu si miano ŋuti, alo le miaƒe ŋutilãwo ŋu le nu si miado ŋuti. "
"Stop being anxious about your lives as to what you will eat or what you will drink, or about your bodies as to what you will wear. "​ MATTHEW 6:25.
MATEO 6:25.
AVOID ENVY.
MÈGABIÃ ŊU O. "Ŋubiãla le yɔyɔm ɖe kesinɔnuwo ŋu, ke menya be hiã ava tu ye o. " LODODOWO 28:22.
"An envious man is eager for wealth, not knowing that poverty will overtake him. "​ PROVERBS 28:22.
Mawusubɔsubɔ
Spirituality
Abe ale si míekpɔe le nyati gbãtɔ me ene la, ame geɖe bua Biblia be enye agbalẽ kɔkɔe.
As noted at the outset, many people consider the Bible to be a sacred book.
Wova kpɔe be ne yewoxlẽe, wɔ ɖe eƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖowo dzi la, enana yewotena ɖe Mawu ŋu eye wova sea nu si tae míele agbe ɖo la gɔme.
They find that when they read it and apply its guidance, they feel uplifted spiritually and come to understand their purpose in life.
Biblia zã nya "gbɔgbɔmenuwo " tsɔ fia nɔnɔme si le ame si alo ale si wòbua agbee.
The Bible uses the word "spirituality " to refer to an attitude or an approach to life.
(Yuda 18, 19) To vovo na ame si ƒe susu katã nɔa ŋutilãmenu siwo ade eya ɖeɖe ko dzi ŋu la, ame si tsia dzi ɖe gbɔgbɔmenuwo ŋu ya dea asixɔxɔ Mawu ƒe nudidiwo ŋu. Efesotɔwo 5:1.
(Jude 18, 19) Unlike a fleshly-minded person, who focuses more on self, those with a spiritual outlook value God’s standards.​ Ephesians 5:1.
MƆKPƆKPƆ
HOPE
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Ne dzi ɖe le ƒowò le xaxaɣi la, ekema wò ŋusẽ dzi aɖe kpɔtɔ. " Lododowo 24:10, etenuŋɔŋlɔ.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "If you become discouraged in times of trouble, your strength will be meager. "​ Proverbs 24:10, footnote.
NU SI WÒFIA: Dziɖeleameƒo ate ŋu ana ŋusẽ si míatsɔ anɔ te ɖe kuxiwo nu la dzi naɖe kpɔtɔ.
WHAT IT MEANS: Discouragement can sap us of the strength we need in order to deal with life’s problems.
Gake mɔkpɔkpɔ ate ŋu ana dzi naɖo mía ƒo míayi edzi anɔ dzi dom.
On the other hand, hope can give us the courage to keep going.
Efaa akɔ na mí ŋutɔ ne míenyae be kuxi siwo me tom míele la manɔ anyi ɖaa o; le nyateƒe me la, nu nyui aɖe ate ŋu ado go tso míaƒe dzidodoa me.
It can be comforting to acknowledge that the problems we face may well be temporary; in fact, something good may come from them.
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ: Na wò susu nanɔ nu nyui siwo ava le etsɔme la ŋu.
WHAT YOU CAN DO: Try to have an optimistic view of the future.
Le esi nàtsi dzi ɖe nu siwo ate ŋu ava dzɔ alo anɔ anyi ɖi anɔ mɔ kpɔm na nɔnɔme siwo ade dziwò teƒe la, ɖe afɔ siwo ana nàɖo wò taɖodzinuwo gbɔ.
Instead of worrying about what might happen or waiting for the perfect set of circumstances, take action in harmony with your goals.
"Nuɖiɖeame " ate ŋu adzɔ ɣeaɖewoɣi ya.
Granted, "unexpected events " can occur.
(Nyagblɔla 9:11) Gake zi geɖe la, nuwo va nyona wu ale si míesusui gɔ̃ hã.
(Ecclesiastes 9:11) Realistically, though, things often turn out better than we may expect.

Eya ta Biblia zã agbledede tsɔ wɔ kpɔɖeŋu esi wògblɔ be: "Ƒã wò nukuwo le ŋdi, eye wò alɔ megadzudzɔ o va se ɖe fiẽ; elabena mènya kae awɔ nyuie o, eɖanye esi alo ekemɛ o, alo ne wo kple eve lae le nyonyo ge o. " Nyagblɔla 11:6.

Thus, using an agricultural metaphor, the Bible says: "Sow your seed in the morning and do not let your hand rest until the evening; for you do not know which will have success, whether this one or that one, or whether they will both do well. "​ Ecclesiastes 11:6.
EÐO BIABIA VEVI SIWO KU ÐE AGBE ŊU
ANSWERS TO LIFE’S BIG QUESTIONS
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Na gɔmesesem . . .
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Give me understanding . . .
Wò nyawo . . . nye nyateƒe. " Psalmo 119:144, 160.
Your word is truth. "​ Psalm 119:144, 160.
NU SI WÒFIA: Biblia ɖo biabia vevi siwo ku ɖe agbe ŋu siwo ame geɖe biana la ŋu.
WHAT IT MEANS: The Bible provides answers to the questions that virtually everyone asks.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, eɖo biabia siwo gbɔna ŋu
For example, it answers such questions as
Afi kae míedzɔ tso?
Where did we come from?
Nu ka tae míele gbe ɖo?
Why are we here?
Nu kae dzɔna ɖe ame dzi ne eku?
What happens when a person dies?
Agbea katã koe nye esia?
Is this life all there is?
Ame miliɔn geɖe siwo le xexea me la va le dzidzɔ kpɔm le esi wokpɔ biabia siawo kple bubu geɖewo ƒe ŋuɖoɖowo le Biblia me ta.
Millions of people around the world have improved their lives by examining the Bible’s answers to those questions and more.
NU SI NÀTE ŊU AWƆ: Wò ŋutɔ dzro Biblia me be nàkpɔ nu si wòfia.
WHAT YOU CAN DO: Examine for yourself what the Bible teaches.
Bia Yehowa Ðasefo aɖe wòakpe ɖe ŋuwò nàse Biblia gɔme.
Ask any one of Jehovah’s Witnesses for help to understand the Bible.

So its wisdom has reached and helped more people than any other publication.

JEHOVAH’S WITNESSES AND THE BIBLE

These are some of the Bible translations that we have distributed over the years:

Viɖe Siwo Le Ðokuidziɖuɖu Me
The Benefits of Self-Control
NU KAE NYE ÐOKUIDZIÐUÐU?
WHAT IS SELF-CONTROL?
Ðokuidziɖuɖu fia be
Self-control includes the ability to
ame nalala
delay gratification
ame nazi eɖokui dzi
restrain impulses
ame nawɔ nane awu enu ne medzɔa dzi nɛ o gɔ̃ hã
complete unpleasant tasks
ame natsɔ ame bubuwo ƒe nyonyo aɖo ŋgɔ na eya ŋutɔ tɔ
put others before self
NU KA TAE ÐOKUIDZIÐUÐU LE VEVIE?
WHY IS SELF-CONTROL IMPORTANT?
Ðevi siwo tea ŋu ɖua wo ɖokui dzi la tea ŋu nɔa te ɖe tetekpɔwo nu, ne edze abe tetekpɔa aɖe vi na wo ɣeyiɣi kpuie aɖe hã.
Children who have greater self-control can resist temptation, even if the temptation promises short-term rewards.
Gake ɖevi siwo meɖua wo ɖokuiwo dzi o la
In contrast, children with less self-control may be more likely to
va nɔa dziku dom kabakaba
be aggressive
va léa blanuiléledɔ
suffer depression
va noa atama alo mua aha alo nɔa atike vɔ̃ɖiwo zãm
smoke or abuse alcohol or drugs
meva léa fɔ ɖe nu ŋu ɖuna nyuie o
make poor choices in what they eat
Numekuku aɖe ɖee fia be ɖevi siwo ɖua wo ɖokui dzi la, nɔa lãmesẽ me, wometsia dzi ɖe ga ŋu o, eye wowɔna ɖe se dzi wu le woƒe tsitsi me.
One study found that children with greater self-control were less likely, as adults, to have health issues, financial stress, and problems with the law.
Numekuku ma na Angela Duckworth si nye Nufialagã le Yunivɛsiti aɖe (University of Pennsylvania) la ƒo nya ta be: "Ðokuidziɖuɖu aɖeke meli si woagblɔ be ‘egbɔ eme’ o. "
That study led Professor Angela Duckworth of the University of Pennsylvania to conclude: "There may be no such thing as ‘too much’ self-control. "
ALE SI NÀFIA ÐOKUIDZIÐUÐU VIWÒ
HOW TO TEACH SELF-CONTROL
Mègaɖe mɔ ɖe nu sia nu ko ŋu o.
Learn to say no and mean it.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "[Na wò] ‘Ɛ̃’ nanye ɛ̃, eye [wò] ‘Ao’ nanye ao. " Mateo 5:37.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Let your word ‘Yes’ mean yes, your ‘No,’ no. "​ Matthew 5:37.
Ðevi suewo ate ŋu ado nu si wo dzilawo ɖo be yewomawɔ o la kpɔ to avinugbee wɔwɔ me le dutoƒo gɔ̃ hã.
Young children might test a parent’s resolve by throwing a tantrum​ perhaps even in public.
Ne dzilaa na ta la, ɖevia akpɔe be ne yenya fa avi ko la, ana ye dzila natrɔ susu awɔ nu si yedi.
If the parent gives in, the child learns that tantrums are an effective way to get a no changed to a yes.
Gake ne dzilaa gbe eye wòɖoe kplikpaa la, ana ɖevia nasrɔ̃ nu vevi aɖe le agbe me be, menye nu sia nu si dzro mí le agbe mee asu mía si o.
On the other hand, if the parent says no and means it, the child learns a basic fact of life​ that we cannot always get what we want.
Agbalẽnyalagã David Walsh gblɔ be: "Togbɔ be adze abe ame siwo ƒe asi sua nu sia nu si dim wole dzi akpɔ dzidzɔ ene hã, menyea nyateƒe o.
"Ironically, people who learn that lesson seem to be the most fulfilled, " writes Dr. David Walsh.
Ke boŋ ame siwo ɖua wo ɖokuiwo dzie kpɔa dzidzɔ wu. Ne míetsɔ nu sia nu si mía viwo biana naa wo la, ke míele nu gblẽm le wo ŋu boŋ. "
"We’re not doing our kids any favors when we teach them that the world will always serve up whatever they want on a silver platter. "

Ne ègbena nanewo na viwò fifia la, akpe ɖe eŋu emegbe le agbe me be wòagbe nanewo, le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne wole nya ƒom ɖe enu be wòazã atike vɔ̃ɖi, wòadɔ kple ame aɖe evɔ meɖe srɔ̃ o, alo awɔ nu gbegblẽ bubu aɖewo la, agbe.
Saying no to your child now will help him to say no to himself later in life​ for example, if he is tempted to take drugs, have premarital sex, or engage in other harmful practices.
Kpe ɖe viwòa ŋu wòase egɔme be emetsonuawo ate ŋu anye nyui alo vɔ̃.
Help your children to understand consequences, both good and bad.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Nu si ame ƒãna la, esia kee wòaŋe. " Galatiatɔwo 6:7.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Whatever a person is sowing, this he will also reap. "​ Galatians 6:7.
Ehiã be viwòa nase egɔme be afɔɖeɖe ɖe sia ɖe kple emetsonue zɔna, eya ta ne míeɖu mía ɖokui dzi o la, emetsonuwo medea ame dzi o.
Your child needs to understand that actions have consequences and that a lack of self-control will therefore have undesirable results.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne nu vi aɖe dzɔ ko wòado dziku vɔɖivɔ̃ɖi la, amewo aƒo asa nɛ keŋkeŋ.
For example, if your son typically loses his temper when he gets upset, others may tend to avoid him.
Ke hã, ne esrɔ̃ ale si wòaɖu eɖokui dzi ne wodo dziku nɛ, alo srɔ̃ ale si wòagbɔ dzi ɖi ke menye be wòado adã o la, amewo alɔ̃ be yewoate ɖe eŋu.
On the other hand, if he develops the ability to restrain himself when provoked​ or to wait patiently rather than interrupt ​people will be drawn to him.
Kpe ɖe viwòa ŋu wòase egɔme be nu nyui geɖe ado tso eme ne eléa eɖokui.
Help your child understand that he is more likely to have good outcomes when he practices self-restraint.
Fia viwò be wòatsɔ nu vevitɔwo aɖo nɔƒe gbãtɔ.
Teach your child to prioritize.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: ‘Mikpɔ nu siwo le vevie wu la dze sii.’ Filipitɔwo 1:10.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Make sure of the more important things. "​ Philippians 1:10.
Ðokuidziɖuɖu mefia be ame nagbe be yemawɔ nu gbegblẽ ko evɔ o; ebia be ame nawɔ nu si hiã, ne nua wɔwɔ medoa dzidzɔ na ame o gɔ̃ hã.
Self-control is not just a matter of holding back from doing wrong; it includes doing what is necessary, even when this is not particularly exciting or fun.
Ele vevie be viwòa nasrɔ̃ ale si wòatsɔ nu vevitɔwo aɖo nɔƒe gbãtɔ eye wòalé wo me ɖe asi.
It is important for your child to learn how to establish priorities and stick to them.
Na viwòa nawɔ nu vevitɔwo gbã.
Have your child do the important things first.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ele be wòawɔ sukudɔdeasiwo gbã hafi afe fefe.
For example, he should put homework before recreation.
Ðo kpɔɖeŋu nyui si wòasrɔ̃.
Be a good role model.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Meɖo kpɔɖeŋu ɖi na mi be, ale si tututu mewɔ na mi la, miawo hã miawɔ nenema ke. "
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "I set the pattern for you, that just as I did to you, you should also do. "​ John 13:15.
Yohanes 13:15. Viwòa léa ŋku ɖe ale si nèwɔa nui ne nane dzɔ si do dziku na wò la ŋu.
Your child will see how you respond to unpleasant or frustrating situations.
Ðee fia to kpɔɖeŋu si nèɖona me be nu nyuiwo dona tsoa eme ne míeɖu mía ɖokui dzi.
Demonstrate by your example that self-control leads to better outcomes.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne viwò wɔ nane si ho dzi na wò la, ɖe nèwɔa nu le dziku me loo alo ɖe nèléa ɖokuiwò?
For example, when your child tests your patience, do you react with anger or do you remain calm?
Vidada aɖe gbe na viaŋutsuvi be wòagafɔ kpetikewo le fiase me o
A mother says no as her little boy tries to pick out candy in a store

Ne ègbena nanewo na viwò fifia la, akpe ɖe eŋu emegbe le agbe me be wòagbe nanewo, le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne wole nya ƒom ɖe enu be wòazã atike vɔ̃ɖi, alo awɔ nu gbegblẽ bubu aɖewo la, agbe
Saying no to your child now will help him to say no to himself later in life​ for example, if he is tempted to take drugs or to engage in other harmful practices
Ðo Kpɔɖeŋu Nyui
Teach by Example
Ðe vinyea kpɔnɛ be meléa ɖokuinye ne nɔnɔme sesẽ siwo ate ŋu ana mado dziku do mo ɖa?
Does my child see me work through frustrating situations without losing my temper?
Ðe meɖea nu si tae medzea agbagba be makpɔ kuxiwo gbɔ le dzigbɔɖi me la me na vinyea?
Have I explained to my child the reasons why I try to handle problems calmly?
Nya kae vinye agblɔ tso ŋunye ɖe wòakpɔ be mewɔa nu dzitsitsitɔe hedoa dziku kabakaba loo alo meléa ɖokuinye eye meɖua ɖokuinye dzia?
How would my child describe me​ as impulsive and quick-tempered or as self-disciplined and controlled?
Nu Si Míewɔna . . .
What We Did . . .
"Togbɔ be míeɖea mɔ na mía vinyɔnua be wòado dziku hã la, míeɖea mɔ gbeɖe be eƒe dzikua nagblẽ nu le ame bubuwo ŋu o.
"Even though our daughter was allowed to become frustrated or angry, she wasn’t allowed to let those feelings exasperate those around her.
Ne mete ŋu ɖu eɖokui dzi o la, míeɖea mɔ nɛ be wòade ha kple ame bubuwo o va se ɖe esime eƒe dzikua nu fa. " Theresa.
If she couldn’t control herself, then she would be removed from others’ company until she could calm down. "​ Theresa.
"Nye kple srɔ̃nye míeɖoe be ne mía viwo wɔ nane wòdzɔ dzi na mí la, míana woanya.
"My wife and I made it our aim to let our children know when they made us proud.
Ne wote ŋu ɖu wo ɖokuiwo dzi le nɔnɔme sesẽ aɖe me la, míekafua wo. " Wayne.
We praised them when they didn’t allow difficulty to get them out of sorts or when they kept their cool and showed self-control. "​ Wayne.
Ale Si Wòabɔbɔ Eɖokui
How to Be Humble
NU KAE NYE ÐOKUIBƆBƆ?
WHAT IS HUMILITY?
Ðokuibɔbɔlawo dea bubu ame ŋu.
Humble people are respectful.
Womedana loo alo kpɔa mɔ be amewo nawɔ nu ɖe yewo ŋu etɔxɛ o.
They do not behave arrogantly, nor do they expect others to treat them as special.
Ke boŋ ɖokuibɔbɔla tsɔa ɖe le eme na ame bubuwo vevie, eye wòdina be yeasrɔ̃ nu tso wo gbɔ.
Rather, a person with humility takes genuine interest in others and is willing to learn from them.
Ame aɖewo bua ɖokuibɔbɔ vodadatɔe ɣeaɖewoɣi be enye gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔ.
Sometimes humility is misjudged as a weakness.
Gake menye gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔe o, ke boŋ ekpena ɖe ame ŋu be wòade dzesi eƒe vodadawo eye wòanya afi si eƒe ŋutetewo se ɖo.
In reality, it is a strength that helps people recognize their faults and acknowledge their limitations.
NU KA TAE ÐOKUIBƆBƆ LE VEVIE?
WHY IS HUMILITY IMPORTANT?
Ðokuibɔbɔ nana kadodowo me nyona.
Humility benefits relationships.
Agbalẽ aɖe (The Narcissism Epidemic) gblɔ be, "Zi geɖe la, ɖokuibɔbɔla tea ŋu dzea xɔ̃wo bɔbɔe. "
"Overall, humble people are more connected to others, " says the book The Narcissism Epidemic.
Eyi edzi gblɔ be: "Enɔa bɔbɔe be wòade ha kple amewo le afi sia afi. "
It adds that such people find it "easier to relate to other people and the wider world. "
Ðokuibɔbɔ ate ŋu aɖe vi na viwòa le etsɔme.
Humility benefits your child’s future.
Ne viwò srɔ̃ ɖokuibɔbɔ la, akpe ɖe eŋu fifia kple etsɔme le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne eyi dɔ diƒe.
Learning to be humble will help your child both now and later in life​ for example, when seeking employment.
Agbalẽnyalagã Leonard Sax gblɔ be: "Sɔhɛ si doa eɖokui ɖe dzi, evɔ medea dzesi eƒe gbɔdzɔgbɔdzɔwo o la, metea ŋu ɖoa nyawo ŋu wòdea dzi gbɔ na dɔtɔ ne ele dɔ dim eye wole gbe biamee o.
"The young person with bloated self-esteem, unaware of her own deficiencies, is unlikely to do well in the job interview, " writes Dr. Leonard Sax.
Gake sɔhɛ si di tso dzi me be yeanya nu si le vevie na dɔtɔa la, ƒe asi tea ŋu sua dɔa dzi bɔbɔe wu. "
"But the young person who is genuinely interested in what the recruiter has to say is more likely to get the job. "
ALE SI NÀFIA ÐOKUIBƆBƆ VIWÒ
HOW TO TEACH HUMILITY
Kpe ɖe viwòa ŋu be wòagabu eɖokui ŋu fũu o.
Encourage a balanced view of self.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Ne ame aɖe susuna be yenye nane, evɔ menye naneke o la, eɖokui ko blem wòle. " Galatiatɔwo 6:3.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "If anyone thinks he is something when he is nothing, he is deceiving himself. "​ Galatians 6:3.
Mègaɖɔ kesekuku nɛ o.
Avoid misleading maxims.
Nyawo abe "Wò asi ate ŋu asu nu sia nu dzi " kple "Àte ŋu ava nye nu sia nu si nèdi be yeava nye " ene gbɔgblɔ, adze dzideƒonyawo, gake zi geɖe la, eto vovo na ale si agbea ŋutɔ nɔna.
Sayings like "All your dreams can come true " and "You can be anything that you want to be " might sound inspiring, but they often do not prove true in real life.
Ke hã, ne eɖoa taɖodzinu nyui siwo gbɔ wòate ŋu aɖo eye wòdzea agbagba be yeaɖo wo gbɔ la, ate ŋu ava kpɔ dzidzedze.
Your children will likely be more successful if they have reasonable goals and work hard to achieve them.
Kafui ɖe nane koŋ ta.
Praise specific actions.
Ne ègblɔ na viwò be "ède ŋgɔ ŋutɔ " la, makpe ɖe eŋu wòabɔbɔ eɖokui o.
Simply telling a child that he or she is "awesome " does not encourage humility.
Kafukafua neku ɖe nane koŋ ŋu.
Be specific.
Mègana wòazã Internet dzi hahoo kadodowo fũu akpa o.
Limit your child’s use of social media.
Zi geɖe la, Internet dzi hahoo kadodowo nana ame hea susu va eɖokui dzi enana ame doa boblo eƒe ŋutetewo kple nu siwo wòte ŋu wɔna, eye esia fia be ame mebɔbɔ eɖokui o.
Often, social media is linked with self-promotion​ broadcasting a person’s talents and accomplishments ​the very opposite of humility.
Fia viwòa be wòanye ame si ɖea kuku kaba.
Encourage your child to apologize quickly.
Kpe ɖe viwòa ŋu wòakpɔ afi siwo wòdze agɔ le, eye wòalɔ̃ ɖe edzi.
Help your child to see where he is wrong and to acknowledge it.
Fiae be wòakpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe nu ŋu.
Promote gratitude.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Minye akpedalawo. " Kolosetɔwo 3:15.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Show yourselves thankful. "​ Colossians 3:15.
Fiae be wòakpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe Mawu ƒe nuwɔwɔwo ŋu.
Gratitude for creation.
Ele be ɖevi nasrɔ̃ ale si wòakpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe nuwɔwɔwo ŋu kple ale si gbegbe woɖea vi na míi.
Children should appreciate nature and how much we depend on it for survival.
Míehiã ya agbɔ, tsi ano kple nuɖuɖu be míaɖu.
We need air to breathe, water to drink, and food to eat.
Zã kpɔɖeŋu siawo nàtsɔ aƒã ale si viwòa nakpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe Mawu ƒe nuwɔwɔ wɔnuku siwo le xexea me ŋu la ɖe eme, eye wòada akpe ɖe wo ta.
Use these examples to instill appreciation, awe, and gratitude for the wonders of the natural world.
Fiae be wòakpɔ ŋudzedze ɖe amewo ŋu.
Gratitude for people.
Ðo ŋku edzi na viwòa be ame bubuwo nyo wui le mɔ aɖe nu eye le esi wòaʋã ŋu wo le woƒe ŋutetewo kple nu siwo wote ŋu wɔna ŋu teƒe la, ate ŋu asrɔ̃ nu tso wo gbɔ boŋ.
Remind your child that everyone is superior to him in one way or another and that instead of being jealous of others’ skills and abilities, he can learn from them.
Fiae be wòanye akpedala.
Expressing gratitude.
Fia viwòa wòasrɔ̃ ale si wòagblɔ be "akpe, " gake menye be wòagblɔe kple nu ko o, ke boŋ wòatso dzi me nɛ.
Teach your children to say "thank you, " not just with words but with genuine appreciation.
Ne míekpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe nu ŋu la, enana míebɔbɔa mía ɖokui.
A grateful spirit has been called a building block of humility.
Kpe ɖe viwòa ŋu be wòawɔ nu si aɖe vi na ame bubuwo.
Teach your children that there is value in serving others.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Mitsɔ ɖokuibɔbɔ bu ame bubuwo be wonye gã wu mi, ale be miaganɔ miawo ŋutɔ miaƒe nyonyo ko dim o, ke miadi ame bubuwo hã ƒe nyonyo. " Filipitɔwo 2:3, 4.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "With humility consider others superior to you, as you look out not only for your own interests, but also for the interests of others. "​ Philippians 2:3, 4.
De aƒemedɔwo asi na viwòa.
Expect your child to do chores.
Ne mèdea aƒemedɔwo asi na viwòa le ƒomea me o la, ke èle gbɔgblɔm nɛ be, ‘Èle vevie wu dɔ mawo!’
Exempting your child from family chores might give him the message, ‘You are too important to do this!’
Kpe ɖe eŋu wòawɔ aƒemedɔwo vɔ hafi afe fefe.
Family duties should come first, and playing second.
Ƒo nu tso ale si aƒemedɔwo ɖea vi na ame bubuwoe kple ale si wokpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe dɔa kpakple ewɔla siaa ŋu la ŋu nɛ.
Point out how chores benefit others and how others will appreciate and respect him for doing them.
Te gbe ɖe ale si wònyo be woakpe ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu la dzi nɛ.
Emphasize that serving others is a privilege.
Kpekpe ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu ana wòatsi le susu me.
Doing so is a primary way to develop maturity.
Eya ta kpe ɖe viwòa ŋu be eƒe susu nanɔ ame siwo hiã na kpekpeɖeŋu la ŋu.
Therefore, encourage your child to identify those in need.
Gblɔ nu siwo wòate ŋu awɔ atsɔ akpe ɖe wo ŋu la nɛ.
Discuss with him what he can do to help them.
Ne ekpe ɖe ame aɖe ŋu la, kafui eye nàde dzi ƒo nɛ.
Commend and support your child as he serves others.
Ŋutsuvi aɖe tsɔ gbeɖuɖɔ le gbeɖuɖɔgo me dem
A boy puts trash in a bin

Ðevi si srɔ̃ ale si wòawɔ aƒemedɔ tsɛwo la va zua ame tsitsi si tea ŋu wɔa dɔ kple ame bubuwo faa
A child who learns to perform humble tasks at home is more likely to work well with others as an adult
Ðo Kpɔɖeŋu Nyui
Teach by Example
Ðe menana vinyewo nyana be ɣeaɖewoɣi la, nye ŋutɔ hã mehiãna na ame bubuwo ƒe kpekpeɖeŋua?
Do I let my children know that at times I also need help from others?
Ðe meƒoa nu nyui tso amewo ŋu eye mekpɔa ŋudzedze ɖe wo ŋu loo alo ɖe medaa wo ɖe anyia?
Do I speak positively and appreciatively about others, or do I belittle them?
Ðe vinyewo kpɔnɛ be edzɔa dzi nam be makpe ɖe amewo ŋua?
Do my children see that I value serving others?
Nu Si Míewɔna . . .
What We Did . . .
"Mía vinyɔnua gblɔ na mí be yeƒe sukuxɔmehati aɖe mewɔa nu ɖe amewo ŋu nyuie o, eya ta amewo melɔ̃a eƒe nya o.
"Our daughter told us about a classmate who, she said, is mean to others and is not liked.
Megblɔ na mía via be wòabu nu siwo me wòanya nɔ totom le aƒe me ŋu kpɔ.
I told her to think of what that girl might be going through at home.
Le nyateƒe me la, menye ame sia ame ŋue wowɔa nu ɖo nyuie le aƒe me o.
After all, not everybody has a good family life.
Esia kpe ɖe mía via ŋu wòkpɔe be yemenyo wu ame bubuwo o.
That helped our daughter to see that she is not better than others.
Ðeko nuwo de ye dzi wu. " Karen.
She may just have better circumstances. "​ Karen.
"Míedea dzi ƒo na mía vinyɔnuawo be woalé fɔ ɖe woƒe sukunusɔsrɔ̃wo ŋu eye woawɔ wo tɔ sinua eye woagatsɔ wo ɖokuiwo anɔ sɔsɔm kple wo tɔ bubuwo o.
"We encourage our daughters to enjoy what they learn in school and simply to do their best without comparing themselves to others.
Míenana wonyana be míawo hã míatsɔ wo asɔ kple ame bubuwo o. " Marianna.
We want them to know that we will not compare them to others either. "​ Marianna.
Ale Si Wòanɔ Te Ðe Nu Nu
How to Be Resilient
NU KAE WÒFIA BE WOANƆ TE ÐE NU NU?
WHAT IS RESILIENCE?
Ame si nɔa te ɖe nu nu nye ame si tea ŋu trɔna ɖe nɔnɔmeawo ŋu bɔbɔe eye wògakpɔa dzidzɔ.
A resilient person bounces back from obstacles and disappointments.
Nanewo me toto ye nana nɔnɔme sia va sua ame si.
This skill is acquired through experience.
Ale si ko ɖevi si le azɔlizɔzɔ srɔ̃m megbea anyidzedze o la, nenemae agbe madze edzi na ɖevi ne mesrɔ̃ ale si wòanɔ te ɖe kuxiwo nu o.
Just as a child cannot learn how to walk without an occasional fall, he cannot learn how to succeed in life without experiencing occasional setbacks.
NU KA TAE TENƆNƆ ÐE NU NU LE VEVIE?
WHY IS RESILIENCE IMPORTANT?
Dzi ɖena le ɖevi aɖewo ƒo ne wodo kpo nu, wole nɔnɔme sesẽ aɖe me tom, alo wohe nya ɖe wo ŋu.
Some children get discouraged when they meet with failure, adversity, or criticism.
Ðewo ya naa ta kura.
Others give up entirely.
Ke hã, ele be wòase nyateƒenya vevi siawo gɔme:
However, they need to understand the following facts:
Míado kpo nu le nanewo me godoo. Yakobo 3:2.
Failure is inevitable in some endeavors.​ James 3:2.
Ame sia ame toa nɔnɔme sesẽ aɖe me ɣeaɖewoɣi. Nyagblɔla 9:11.
Adversity affects everyone at some point.​ Ecclesiastes 9:11.
Ðɔɖɔɖo hiã be míate ŋu asrɔ̃ nu geɖe. Lododowo 9:9.
Correction is vital for learning.​ Proverbs 9:9.
Tenɔnɔ ɖe nu nu akpe ɖe viwòa ŋu be dzi nanɔ eƒo wòakpe akɔ kple agbemekuxiwo.
Resilience will help your child face life’s challenges with confidence.
ALE SI NÀFIA VIWÒA BE WÒANƆ TE ÐE NU NU
HOW TO TEACH RESILIENCE
Ne viwòa do kpo nu le nane me.
When your child fails.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Ne ame dzɔdzɔe dze anyi zi adre hã la, agafɔ. " Lododowo 24:16.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "The righteous one may fall seven times, and he will get up again. "​ Proverbs 24:16.
Kpe ɖe viwòa ŋu be wòada nuwo akpɔ nyuie.
Help your child put things in perspective.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, nu kae wòawɔ ne ege le sukudodokpɔ aɖe me?
For example, what would he do if he failed a test at school?
Ðewohĩ ana ta agblɔ be, "Nye ya nyemate ŋu awɔ naneke wòanyo o! "
He might give up, saying, "I can’t do anything right! "
Be nàfia ale si wòanɔ te ɖe nu nui la, kpe ɖe eŋu wòakpɔe ɖa be nu kae yeawɔ be dodokpɔa nanyo ɣebubuɣi hã.
To teach resilience, help your child work out a strategy that will help him to improve.
Ne èwɔe elea la, viwòa ŋutɔ ate ŋu akpɔ kuxia gbɔ, wu be kuxia naɖu edzi.
In this way, he will take charge of the problem rather than become a victim of it.
Gake wò ŋutɔ mègakpɔ kuxia gbɔ nɛ o.
At the same time, avoid fixing the problem for your child.
Kpe ɖe eŋu be eya ŋutɔ boŋ nadi mɔ si dzi wòato akpɔ egbɔ.
Instead, help him create his own plan.
Àte ŋu abiae be: "Nu kae nèsusu be yeate ŋu awɔ be yeagase nyati ma gɔme nyuie wu ne wole efiam? "
You might ask him, "What can you do to improve your understanding of the subject that is being taught? "
Ne nya vɔ̃ aɖe dzɔ.
When adversity strikes.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Mienya ale si miaƒe agbe anɔ etsɔ o. " Yakobo 4:14.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "You do not know what your life will be like tomorrow. "​ James 4:14.
Ame aɖeke menya nu si adzɔ etsɔ o.
Life is unpredictable.
Ame si nye gatɔ egbea ate ŋu ava zu hiãtɔ etsɔ; ame si le lãmesẽ me egbea ate ŋu ava zu dɔnɔ etsɔ.
A person who is rich today might be poor tomorrow; a person who is healthy today might be sick tomorrow.
Biblia gblɔ be: "Dziɖuɖu le duɖimekeke me mele afɔ ɖeablɛ me ɣesiaɣi o, dziɖuɖu le aʋa me mele kalẽwɔwɔ me ɣesiaɣi o . . . elabena azãgbe kple nuɖiɖeame li na wo katã. " Nyagblɔla 9:11.
"The swift do not always win the race, nor do the mighty win the battle, " says the Bible, "because time and unexpected events overtake them all. "​ Ecclesiastes 9:11.
Esi nènye dzila ta la, èwɔa tɔwò sinua be yeakpɔ ye via ta tso afɔku me.
As a parent, you rightly take reasonable steps to protect your child from danger.
Gake manya wɔ be nàkpɔ viwòa ta tso kuxi ɖe sia ɖe me o.
Realistically, though, it is not possible to shield your child from all of life’s adversities.
Enye nyateƒe be viwòa metsi ase nu si wòfia be dɔ nagblẽ na ame alo be ame nanɔ gakuxiwo me tom gɔme o.
Of course, your child may not be old enough to experience the loss of a job or a financial reversal.
Ke hã, àte ŋu akpe ɖe eŋu be wòanɔ te ɖe kuxi bubuwo abe, ne eya kple exɔlɔ̃ aɖe ƒe ƒomedodo me gblẽ alo ne miaƒe ƒometɔ aɖe ku ene nu.
Still, you can help him cope with other adversities​ for example, the loss of a friendship or the death of a family member.
Ne wogbe nya na viwòa le nu gbegblẽ aɖe si wòwɔ ta.
When your child receives constructive criticism.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Se aɖaŋuɖoɖo . . . ne nàdze nunya le etsɔ si gbɔna me. " Lododowo 19:20.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Listen to counsel . . . in order to become wise in your future. "​ Proverbs 19:20.
Ne ame aɖe gbe nya na viwò la, menye ŋlɔmi wɔm wòle le eŋu o; ke boŋ ele kpekpem ɖe eŋu be wòaɖe asi le nu gbegblẽ alo nɔnɔme gbegblẽ aɖe ŋu.
Constructive criticism is not bullying; it is guidance that addresses an action or an attitude that needs to change.
Ne èfia viwòa be wòalɔ̃ woaɖɔe ɖo la, aɖe vi na mi ame evea siaa.
When you teach your child to accept correction, both of you are spared much grief.
Vifofo aɖe si ŋkɔe nye John gblɔ be: "Ne ètsoa viwòwo xɔna le vodada ɖe sia ɖe si wowɔna me la, womasrɔ̃ nu gbeɖe o.
"If children are always rescued from their errors, " says a father named John, "they will never learn.
Nu gbegblẽ wɔwɔ dzi koe woanɔ, eye gbe sia gbe la, ànɔ woƒe kuxiwo nu lém.
They will jump from one problem to the next, and you will spend your life following them, stomping out the fires that they cause.
Esia ana agbea nati dzilawo kple ɖeviawo siaa. "
That makes life miserable for the parents and the child. "
Aleke nàte ŋu akpe ɖe viwòa ŋu be wòalɔ̃ woagbe nya nɛ?
How can you help your child benefit from constructive criticism?
Ne wogbe nya na viwòa, le suku alo teƒe bubu aɖe la, ɖu ɖokuiwò dzi be màgagblɔ be mesɔ be woaɖɔe ɖo o.
When your child receives it​ whether at school or anywhere else ​resist the urge to say that the correction is unfair.
Ðe ema teƒe la, àte ŋu abiae be:
Instead, you could ask:
"Èsusu be nu ka tae woɖɔ wò ɖo? "
"Why do you think the correction was given? "
"Ðe nàte ŋu awɔ asitɔtrɔ aɖewoa? "
"How can you improve? "
"Ne ègakpɔ ɖokuiwò le nɔnɔme sia me ɣebubuɣi la, nu kae nàwɔ? "
"What will you do the next time you are in this situation? "
Ðo ŋku edzi be ne wogbea nya na viwòa la, aɖe vi nɛ fifia kple ne eva tsi.
Remember, constructive criticism will serve your child well, not only now but also in adulthood.
Dzi le nyɔnuvi aɖe kum elabe nane si wòmè la gblẽ, gake dadaa le kpekpem ɖe eŋu
A mother helps her daughter who is frustrated because a cake she baked turned out poorly
NA HEHEE FIFIA
TRAIN NOW
Ame si nɔa te ɖe nɔnɔme sesẽwo kple vodadawo nu la, mana ta bɔbɔe ne eva le dɔ aɖe srɔ̃m o, ke boŋ ado dzi asrɔ̃e nyuie
A child who is able to bounce back from disappointments and mistakes is more likely to persevere when learning skills and to become proficient at them
Ðo Kpɔɖeŋu Nyui
Teach by Example
Ðe melɔ̃na ɖe nye vodadawo dzi loo alo ɖe medanɛ ɖe ame bubuwo dzi?
Do I admit my mistakes, or do I blame others?
Ðe meƒoa nu tso nu siwo me medo kpo nu le kple nu si mesrɔ̃ tso eme ŋua?
Do I talk about my failures and what I learned from them?
Ðe meɖua fewu le ame bubuwo ŋu ne woda voa?
Do I ridicule others for their mistakes?
Nu Si Míewɔna . . .
What We Did . . .
"Míekpɔa mía viawo ta tso kuxi, fukpekpe alo vodada ɖe sia ɖe me o.
"We did not protect our children from every challenge, failure, or mistake.
Esi wònye be menɔ te ɖe nɔnɔme mawo tɔgbi nu le nye ɖevime ta la, ekpe ɖe ŋunye metu nɔnɔme nyuiwo ɖo.
When I was young, enduring those things made me a better person.
Mekpɔe be mía vi eveawo tsi va zu ame siwo da sɔ, siwo nɔa te ɖe nɔnɔme vovovowo nu, elabena míewɔ vi na wo o. " Jeff.
I feel that both of our children grew up to be balanced, well-adjusted adults because they were not pampered. "​ Jeff.
"Ne nye kple srɔ̃nye míeda vo ɖe mía viawo ŋu la, míeɖea kuku na wo ɣesiaɣi.
"When my wife and I made mistakes with our children, we would always apologize.
Mekpɔe be ele be dzilawo naƒo nu tso vodada aɖewo siwo wowɔ kpɔ alo kuxi aɖewo siwo me woto la ŋu na wo viwo atsɔ afia wo be nenemae agbea le ye nye ema. " James.
I believe that parents should share their own mistakes, setbacks, and errors with their children to emphasize that it’s just part of life. "​ James.
Ale Si Wòatsɔ Agbanɔamedzi
How to Be Responsible
NU KAE WÒFIA BE WOATSƆ AGBANƆAMEDZI?
WHAT DOES BEING RESPONSIBLE INVOLVE?
Wotea ŋu kana ɖe ame siwo lɔ̃na tsɔa agbanɔamedzi la dzi.
People who are responsible are reliable.
Woléa fɔ ɖe dɔ ŋu eye wowɔnɛ ɖe game dzi.
They follow through on assigned tasks and complete them on time.
Ðevi suewo gɔ̃ hã ate ŋu asrɔ̃ ale si woatsɔ agbanɔamedzi tso woƒe ɖevime.
Even with their limited capabilities, very young children can start learning to be responsible.
Agbalẽ aɖe (Parenting Without Borders) gblɔ be: "Ne ɖevi xɔ ɣleti wuiatɔ̃ la edina be yeawɔ nu si ye dzilawo gblɔ, ne exɔ ɣleti wuienyi la, adi be yeasrɔ̃ ye dzilawo.
"A child’s capacity to cooperate begins by fifteen months, and his desire to start willingly pitching in starts at around eighteen months, " says the book Parenting Without Borders.
Le dukɔ geɖe me la, ne ɖevi xɔ tso ƒe atɔ̃ va ɖo ƒe adre la, wo dzilawo dea aƒemedɔ aɖewo asi na wo tsɔ dzea wo mamla gɔme. "
"In many cultures parents begin to hone their children’s helpfulness especially between the ages of five and seven, and children this young competently assist in many domestic tasks. "
NU KA TAE AGBANƆAMEDZI TSƆTSƆ HIÃ?
WHY IS BEING RESPONSIBLE IMPORTANT?
Wozãa nya "dzidzime siwo yina ʋuu gatrɔna gbɔna " tsɔ ɖɔa sɔhɛ siwo ʋu le aƒe me be yewoanɔ yewo ɖokui si gake agbea va kpeke wo si na wotrɔna vaa Papa kple Dada gbɔ.
The term "boomerang generation " describes young adults who leave home and try to live on their own but fall on hard times and return to Mom and Dad.
Ɣeaɖewoɣi la, nu sia dzɔna elabe womesrɔ̃ ale si woazã ga, akpɔ aƒe dzi alo akpɔ gbe sia gbe nuhiahiãwo gbɔ o.
In some cases, this happens because the youth has never been taught to manage money, run a household, or live up to daily responsibilities.
Eya ta anyo be nàfia viwòa ne wòanya agbanɔamedzi siwo wòava tsɔ ne eva tsi.
Therefore, it is best if you train your children for the responsibilities of adulthood.
Agbalẽ aɖe (How to Raise an Adult) gblɔ be: "Mèganɔ nu sia nu wɔm na wo va se ɖe esime woxɔ ƒe wuienyi eye nàtutu wo aɖo ɖa be woavae dze agbea gɔme o. "
"You don’t want to keep them dependent upon you until they turn eighteen and then dump them out into the real world, " says the book How to Raise an Adult.
FIA VIWÒA ALE SI WÒATSƆ AGBANƆAMEDZI
HOW TO TEACH RESPONSIBILITY
De aƒemedɔwo asi nɛ.
Assign chores.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Kutrikuku ɖe dɔwɔwɔ ŋu hea viɖe vanɛ. " Lododowo 14:23.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "There is benefit in every kind of hard work. "​ Proverbs 14:23.
Ðevi suewo dina be yewoanɔ yewo dzilawo ŋu awɔ dɔ.
Young children are eager to work alongside their parents.
Àte ŋu awɔ didi sia si le viwòa me ŋu dɔ ade aƒemedɔ aɖewo asi nɛ.
You can take advantage of this natural inclination by assigning your children chores around the home.
Gake dzila aɖewo medina be yewoawɔe nenema o.
Some parents are reluctant to do that.
Wogblɔna be sukudɔdeasi gbogbo aɖewo li kɔ ɖe wo dzi gbe sia gbe xoxo, eya ta nu ka tae yewoagatsɔ agba bubu akpee na wo?
They reason that their school-age children face a mountain of homework each day, so why add to their burden?
Ke hã ɖevi siwo wɔa aƒemedɔwo la kpɔa dzidzedze le suku wu, elabena aƒemedɔwo wɔwɔ nana wosrɔ̃a ale si woaxɔ dɔdeasiwo eye woawɔ wo awu enu.
However, children who do chores are more likely to succeed at school, since chores teach them to accept assignments and complete tasks.

Agbalẽa (Parenting Without Borders) gblɔ kpee be: "Ne míeŋe aɖaba ƒu didi si le ɖeviawo me be yewoakpe asi ɖe aƒemedɔwo ŋu dzi esime wonye ɖeviwo la, wova susuna be mehiã be yewoakpe asi ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu o. . . .
Besides, notes the book Parenting Without Borders, "when we ignore our children’s eagerness to participate when they are younger, they internalize the idea that contributing is unimportant . . .
Azɔ hã wova nɔa mɔ kpɔm be woawɔ nu sia nu na yewo. "
They also begin to expect that things will be done for them. "
Abe ale si agbalẽa ƒe nya fia ene la, aƒemedɔwo wɔwɔ kpena ɖe ɖeviwo ŋu be woaganye ɖokuitɔdilawo o, ke boŋ woasrɔ̃ ale si woakpe ɖe ame bubuwo ŋu.
As that quote indicates, doing chores trains children to be contributors rather than consumers, givers rather than takers.
Aƒemedɔwo wɔwɔ kpena ɖe ɖeviwo ŋu wokpɔnɛ be yewowɔa akpa vevi aɖe le ƒomea me eye agba le yewo dzi be yewoawɔe.
Chores help children realize that they have a valued place in the family​ and a responsibility toward it.
Kpe ɖe viwòwo ŋu woalɔ̃ ɖe woƒe vodadawo dzi.
Help your children take responsibility for their mistakes.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Se aɖaŋuɖoɖo, eye nàxɔ amehehe, ne nàdze nunya le etsɔ si gbɔna me. "
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Listen to counsel and accept discipline, in order to become wise in your future. "​ Proverbs 19:20.
Lododowo 19:20. Ne viwò wɔ vodada aɖe le kpɔɖeŋu me, egblẽ ame aɖe ƒe nane evɔ meɖoe o la, mègaɣla eta o.
When your children make mistakes​ for example, if your son or daughter accidentally damages another person’s property ​resist the urge to cover up what happened.
Na viwòa nakpɔ nu gbegblẽa me tsonu, le go sia me la, kpe ɖe eŋu wòaɖe kuku eye ne anya wɔ la wòaɖo nua teƒe.
Children can accept the consequences​ in this case, apologizing and perhaps even making restitution.
Ne ɖevi kpɔe be ye gbɔe vodadaa tso la, asrɔ̃ nu tso eme be
Owning up to mistakes and failures will teach your children
yeato nyateƒe alɔ̃ ɖe vodadawo dzi
to be honest and admit their errors
yeaganɔ fɔ bum ame bubuwo o
to avoid blaming others
yeaganɔ ye ɖokui nu ɖem o
to avoid making excuses
yeaɖe kuku, ne ehiã
to apologize, when appropriate
Vifofo aɖe le kpekpem ɖe viaŋutsuvi ŋu be wòade tsi ati aɖe
A father helps his son to water a plant
NA HEHEE FIFIA
TRAIN NOW
Ðevi siwo srɔ̃ ale si woatsɔ agbanɔamedziwo le ɖevime la ate ŋu ava tsɔ agbanɔamedziwo nyuie ne wotsi
Children who are taught to be responsible will be able to manage their life more effectively as adults
Ðo Kpɔɖeŋu Nyui
Teach by Example
Ðe meléa fɔ ɖe dɔ ŋu, wɔa nu ɖe ɖoɖo nu, eye menɔa game dzia?
Am I industrious, organized, and punctual?
Ðe vinyewo kpɔnɛ be mewɔa aƒemedɔwoa?
Do my children see me working around the home?
Ðe melɔ̃na ɖe nye vodadawo dzi eye meɖea kuku ne ehiã?
Do I acknowledge my mistakes, even apologizing when necessary?
Nu Si Míewɔna . . .
What We Did . . .
"Tso vinyewo ƒe ɖevime ke la, wokpena ɖe ŋunye ne mele fiẽnu ɖam.
"If I was making dinner, the children helped from a very young age.
Ne mele nu nyanyãwo ŋem la, woawo hã kpea asi ɖe ŋunye.
If I was folding laundry, they folded some too.
Ne mele nuwo ŋu tutum la, woawo hã wowɔnɛ.
If I was dusting, they dusted.
Dɔwɔwɔ dzɔa dzi na wo.
Work became fun for them.
Edzɔa dzi na wo be yewoanɔ ŋunye anɔ nu siwo wɔm mele la ke wɔm.
They were happy just to be with me, doing what I was doing.
Mɔ sia dzie woto srɔ̃ ale si woatsɔ agbanɔamedziwo. "
That’s how they learned to be responsible. "​ Laura.
Laura. "Gbe ɖeka, mena mía via ƒo ka na mía xɔlɔ̃ aɖe eye wòɖe kuku nɛ ɖe nane si wòwɔ ɖe eŋu la ta.
"Once, I had our young son call a family friend and tell her he was sorry for being rude.
Esi wònɔ tsitsim la, míena wòɖe kuku ɖe nya aɖe si wògblɔ gake megblɔe nyuie o la ta, eye esia kpe ɖe eŋu wòsrɔ̃ ale si wòaɖe kuku faa ne eda vo. " Debra.
Over the years he’s had to apologize on numerous occasions for saying honest but unkind things, but now he has learned to apologize freely when he makes a mistake. "​ Debra.
VODADA ME TSONUWO ƑE VIÐEWO
THE BENEFITS OF CONSEQUENCES
Jessica Lahey si nye nufiala ŋlɔ ɖe Atlantic magazine me be: "Ðeviwo daa vo, eye ne woda vo la, ele vevie be dzilawo naɖo ŋku edzi be nu siwo ɖeviwo asrɔ̃ tso vodada me tsonuwo me aɖe vi na wo.
"Children make mistakes, and when they do, it’s vital that parents remember that the educational benefits of consequences are a gift, " writes educator Jessica Lahey in the Atlantic magazine.

Ƒe sia ƒe la, nye sukuvi siwo ge le dodokpɔ me gake wo dzilawo mexɔ na wo o, ke boŋ wode dzi ƒo na wo be woasrɔ̃ nu geɖe wu ale be woadze agbagba ɣebubuɣi lae ‘kpɔa dzidzedze’ kple dzidzɔ eye nu va dzea edzi na wo le agbe me wu. "

"Year after year, my ‘best’ students​ the ones who are happiest and successful in their lives ​are the students who were allowed to fail, held responsible for missteps, and challenged to be the best people they could be in the face of their mistakes. "
Ale Si Ame Tsitsiwo Ƒe Mɔfiame Le Vevie
The Value of Adult Guidance
NU KAE AME TSITSIWO ƑE MƆFIAME BIA?
WHAT DOES ADULT GUIDANCE INVOLVE?
Ðeviwo hiã na mɔfiame kple aɖaŋuɖoɖo tso ame tsitsiwo gbɔ.
Children need adults in their life who can provide leadership and advice.
Esi nènye dzila ta la, wòe wòle be nàwɔ dɔ ma; le nyateƒe me la, wò agbae.
As a parent, you are in the best position to fulfill that role; in fact, it is your duty.
Ke hã ame tsitsi bubuwo hã ate ŋu afia nu viwòwo.
However, other adults can be mentors to your children as well.
NU KA TAE AME TSITSIWO ƑE MƆFIAME HIÃ?
WHY IS ADULT GUIDANCE IMPORTANT?
Le dukɔ geɖe me la, ɖeviwo metea ŋu dea ha kple ame tsitsiwo o.
In many lands, young people have little interaction with adults.
Bu nya siawo ŋu kpɔ:
Consider this:
Ðeviwo zãa ŋkekea ƒe akpa gãtɔ le suku, afi si sukuviwo sɔ gbɔ wu nufialawo kple ame tsitsi bubuwo le.
Children spend much of their day at school, where students outnumber teachers and other adults.
Ne wokpa tso suku va aƒe me la, aƒea me tsia ƒuƒlu elabe wo dzilawo yi dɔ me.
After school, some youths return to a home that is empty because both parents have to work.
Numekuku aɖe si wowɔ le Amerika ɖee fia be ɖevi siwo xɔ tso ƒe 8 va se ɖe 12 zãa gaƒoƒo ade le mama dedie nu ɖe television, haƒoƒo kple video dzi fefewo ŋu gbe sia gbe.
One study found that in the United States, children between 8 and 12 years of age spend an average of about six hours on entertainment media each day.

Agbalẽ aɖe (Hold On to Your Kids) gblɔ be: "Egbea ɖevi geɖe le tɔtrɔm ɖe wo hatiwo ŋu hena mɔfiame, wole wo hatiwo srɔ̃m eye woxɔa aɖaŋuɖoɖo le wo gbɔ tsɔ wu be woatrɔ ɖe dada, papa, nufialawo kple ame tsitsi bubuwo ŋu. "
The book Hold On to Your Kids says: "Young people are turning for instruction, modeling, and guidance not to mothers, fathers, teachers, and other responsible adults but to . . . their own peers. "
ALE SI NÀFIA MƆ VIWÒ
HOW TO PROVIDE GUIDANCE
Kpɔ vovo ɖe viwòwo ŋu.
Spend time with your children.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Mla ɖevi ɖe mɔ si wòato la ŋu; ne eva tsi hã mate ɖa le edzi o. " Lododowo 22:6.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Train a child in the way he should go; even when he grows old he will not depart from it. "​ Proverbs 22:6, footnote.
Le dzɔdzɔme nu la, ɖeviwo kpɔa mɔ be yewo dzilawo nafia mɔ yewo.
Children naturally look to their parents for guidance.
Le nyateƒe me la, numekulawo gblɔ be ne ɖeviwo le sɔhɛme ɖom gɔ̃ hã, wodea asixɔxɔ wo dzilawo ƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖowo ŋu wu wo hatiwo tɔ.
In fact, experts say that even as children enter the teen years, they tend to value the advice of their parents over that of their peers.
Agbalẽnyalagã Laurence Steinberg gblɔ le agbalẽ si nye You and Your Adolescent me be: "Dzilawo ƒe nya gakpɔa ŋusẽ ɖe wo viwo ƒe nɔnɔme kple nuwɔnawo dzi ne wole sɔhɛ me ɖom. "
"Parents remain the major influence on their child’s attitudes and behavior through adolescence and into young adulthood, " writes Dr. Laurence Steinberg in the book You and Your Adolescent.
Egblɔ kpee be: "Sɔhɛwo dina be yewoanya nu si susum yewo dzilawo le, eye woɖoa to nya siwo wogblɔna nenye be womelɔ̃na ɖe wo katã dzi ɣesiaɣi o hã. "
He adds: "Adolescents care what you think and listen to what you say, even if they don’t always admit it or agree with every point. "
Esi wònye be didi sia le wo me ta la, wɔ mɔnukpɔkpɔ ma ŋu dɔ.
Take advantage of your children’s natural inclination to look up to you.
Kpɔ vovo ɖe viwòwo ŋu eye nàgblɔ wò susuwo, nu siwo ŋu nèdea asixɔxɔe kple wò nuteƒekpɔkpɔwo na wo.
Spend time with your children and share your viewpoints, values, and experiences with them.
Di ame tsitsi aɖe si viwòa ate ŋu asrɔ̃.
Provide a mentor.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Ame si zɔna kple nunyalawo la, adze nunya. " Lododowo 13:20.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "The one walking with the wise will become wise. "​ Proverbs 13:20.
Ðe nènya ame tsitsi aɖe si ɖoa kpɔɖeŋu nyui si viwòa ate ŋu asrɔ̃a?
Can you think of an adult who might be a good role model for your adolescent?
Ne nenemae la, nu ka tae màwɔ ɖoɖo be viwòa nanɔ ha dem kplii o?
Why not arrange for that person to spend time with him or her?
Ke hã mègaɖe ta le agba si le dziwò abe dzila ene la te o.
Of course, you should not abdicate your parental authority.
Gake dzideƒonamenya siwo ame tsitsi si dzi nèka ɖo, si nènya be magblẽ nu le ye via ŋu o, agblɔ na viwòa la, ate ŋu awɔ akpa vevi aɖe le hehe si nam nèlee me.
But the encouragement from a trusted adult who you know will not harm your child can supplement the training you provide.
Le Biblia me la, esi Timoteo tsi gɔ̃ hã la, ha si wòde kple apostolo Paulo ɖe vi nɛ ŋutɔ eye wòɖe vi na Paulo hã. Filipitɔwo 2:20, 22.
In the Bible, Timothy​ even as an adult ​benefited greatly from the association he had with the apostle Paul, and Paul benefited from Timothy’s companionship.​ Philippians 2:20, 22.
Egbea megabɔ be ƒomewo nanɔ teƒe ɖeka kple wo tɔgbuiwo, mamawo, nyruiwo, tɔgãwo, tasiwo, nɔɖiwo kple ƒometɔ bubuwo o.
During the past century, many families have become somewhat fragmented, as grandparents, uncles, aunts, and other relatives may live in another part of the world.
Ne nenemae wòle le gowòme la, dze agbagba be nàna mɔnukpɔkpɔ viwò be wòade ha kple ame tsitsi siwo si nɔnɔme nyui siwo nàdi be woasu ye via si la le.
If that is true in your case, try to provide your teens with opportunities to learn from adults who have traits that you would like to see in your children.
Nyɔnu aɖe tsɔ eƒe foto xoxowo le nyɔnuvi aɖe fiam

Ne ɖevi aɖe ɖoa to ame tsitsi ƒe mɔfiame la, etea ŋu va dzea nunya eye wòdzena le eŋu emegbe be etsi le susu me
A child who looks to adults for guidance is more likely to display wisdom and maturity later in life
Ðo Kpɔɖeŋu Nyui
Teach by Example
Ðe meɖoa kpɔɖeŋu nyui si vinyewo asrɔ̃a?
Am I a good role model for my children?
Ðe menana vinyewo kpɔnɛ be nye hã metrɔna ɖe ame siwo kpɔ nuteƒe wum la ŋu srɔ̃a nu tso wo gbɔa?
Do I show my children that I too look up to those with greater experience as mentors?
Ðe mekpɔa vovo ɖe vinyewo ŋu tsɔ ɖenɛ fiana be wole vevie nama?
Do I demonstrate that my children are important to me by spending time with them?
Nu Si Míewɔna . . .
What We Did . . .
"Ɣeaɖewoɣi ne nye ŋku biã ɖe dɔ aɖe ŋu la, vinyenyɔnua gblɔna be yedi be yeaɖo dze tso nya aɖe ŋu.
"Sometimes when I am in the middle of something, my daughter will say she wants to talk.
Mekpɔa egbɔ be meɖo toe, ne ahiã be mana wòalala ɣeyiɣi vi aɖe gɔ̃ hã ale be mate ŋu aɖo toe bliboe.
I always make sure that she is a priority, even if I have to tell her to wait a few minutes so that she can have my undivided attention.
Nye kple srɔ̃nye míedzea agbagba be míaɖo kpɔɖeŋu nyui ne wòakpɔe be míawo ŋutɔwo hã míenɔa agbe ɖe nu siwo fiam míelee la nu. " David.
My wife and I also strive to set a good example so she will see that we live by the same principles we are teaching her. "​ David.
"Esi míedzi mía vinyɔnua la, nye kple srɔ̃nye míetso nya me be madzudzɔ dɔwɔwɔ anɔ aƒe me akpe asi ɖe ɖevia hehe ŋu.
"When our daughter was born, my husband and I decided that I would not work but would stay home to help raise her.
Nyametsotso ma mevem o.
I do not regret that decision.
Ehiã vevie ŋutɔ be dzilawo nawɔ wotɔ sinua anɔ wovia ŋu ne anya wɔ, ale be ɖevia nate ŋu axɔ mɔfiame nyuitɔ.
It is very important to do as much as possible to be present in a child’s life so that he or she will have proper guidance and direction.
Vevietɔ wu la, ne èli akpe ɖe viwòa ŋu la, akpɔe be ètsɔ ɖe le eme na ye. " Lisa.
More important, being there shows your child that you care. "​ Lisa.
NE WODEA HA KPLE AME TSITSIWO
SPENDING TIME WITH ADULTS
"Esi vinyewo nɔ tsitsim la, wode ha kple ame tsitsi vovovowo, eye esia kpe ɖe wo ŋu wonya nu siwo me woto.
"My children have grown up around a diverse group of adults, and this has helped them to see life through other people’s experiences.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, esi mamanye gblɔ na wo be le yeƒe ɖevime la, yewoƒe ƒomeae nye ame gbãtɔ siwo xɔ elektrikkaɖi ɖe aƒe me la, ewɔ nuku na wo.
For example, they were amazed when my grandmother told them that when she was a little girl, her family was the first one to get an electric light.
Egblɔ na wo be nutoa me tɔwo vaa yewoƒe aƒe me va tɔna ɖe dzodoƒea be yewoakpɔ ale si wosia akaɖia kple ale si wotsinɛ.
She told them that people from surrounding areas came to their house just to stand in the kitchen and watch the light being turned on and off.
Nya ma na vinyewo kpɔ ale si agbea nɔ tsã va yi.
That story made my children see how different life used to be.
Esi wose nya mawo tso wo mama gã nu la, eva na be wodea bubu eya kple ame tsitsi bubuwo ŋu.
Learning about their great-grandmother in this way also helped them to have respect for her and for other older ones.
Ne ɖeviwo dea ha kple ame tsitsiwo geɖe wu wo hatiwo la, ana woasrɔ̃ nu geɖe le agbe me. " Maranda.
When children spend more time with adults​ and less with their peers ​they are able to see life from a different perspective. "​ Maranda.
Ale Si Wòaɖe Nɔnɔme Nyuiwo Afia
The Need for Moral Values
NU KAWOE NYE NƆNƆME NYUIWO?
WHAT ARE MORAL VALUES?
Ame siwo si nɔnɔme nyuiwo le la nya nu si nye nyui kple vɔ̃ nyuie.
People with moral values have a clear sense of right and wrong.
Nu si nye nyui kple vɔ̃ le wo gome la, menɔa te ɖe nɔnɔme si me wole dzi o.
Their moral code is not based on how they feel at the moment.
Ke boŋ enɔa te ɖe mɔfiame siwo nu wonɔa agbe ɖo la dzi, ne amewo mele wo kpɔm o gɔ̃ hã.
Rather, it is founded on a firm set of principles that act as a guide for conduct​ even when others are not watching.
NU KA TAE NƆNƆME NYUIWO LE VEVIE?
WHY ARE MORAL VALUES IMPORTANT?
Ðeviwo sea nya totro gbogbo aɖewo ku ɖe nu si nye nyui kple vɔ̃ ŋu le dze siwo woɖona kple wo hati sukuviwo, ha siwo wosena, film kple television dzi wɔna siwo wokpɔna me.
Children are bombarded with distorted messages about morals, whether from the people they go to school with, the music they listen to, or the movies and TV shows they watch.
Nu siawo siwo wosena, nana wotɔtɔna le nu si wonya tso nyui kple vɔ̃ ŋu la ŋu.
Such influences can challenge their beliefs about what is right and what is wrong.
Esia nye nyateƒe vevietɔ le woƒe sɔhɛmenɔɣi.
That is especially true during the teen years.

Agbalẽ aɖe (Beyond the Big Talk) gblɔ be ɣemaɣie nye "ɣeyiɣi si me wòle be woase egɔme be wo hatiwo kple nyadzɔdzɔgblɔmɔnuwo aƒoe ɖe wo nu be woaxɔ ŋkɔ ale be amewo nalɔ̃ woƒe nya, eye ele be woasrɔ̃ ale si woatso nya me wòawɔ ɖeka kple nu si wonya be enye nyui kple vɔ̃ ɣesiaɣi, ne ema mewɔ ɖeka kple wo xɔlɔ̃wo ƒe didiwo o hã. "

By that time, says the book Beyond the Big Talk, they "need to understand the intense peer and media pressures to be popular and accepted, and they need to learn to make decisions consistent with their own values and choices, even if that means going against their friends. "
Edze ƒãa be ele be woadze hehenana ɖeviwo gɔme hafi woaɖo sɔhɛ me.
Clearly, training needs to begin before adolescence.
ALE SI NÀFIA NƆNƆME NYUIWO VIWÒ
HOW TO TEACH MORAL VALUES
Fia nu si nye nyui kple vɔ̃ ɖevia.
Establish a moral code.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Ame tsitsiwo . . . na hehe woƒe nugɔmeseseŋutetewo . . . be woate ŋu ade vovo nyui kple vɔ̃ dome. "
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Mature people . . . have their powers of discernment trained to distinguish both right and wrong. "​ Hebrews 5:14.
Hebritɔwo 5:14.
Build a moral vocabulary.
Zã nu siwo dzɔna gbe sia gbe eye nàna vovototoa nadze: "Nyateƒetotoe nye ema; nyateƒematomatoe nye ema. "
Point to everyday situations and highlight contrasts: "This is honest; that is dishonest. "
"Nuteƒewɔwɔe nye ema; nuteƒemawɔmawɔe nye ema. "
"This is loyal; that is disloyal. "
"Dɔmenyonyoe nye ema; menye dɔmenyonyoe nye ema o. "
"This is kind; that is unkind. "
Ne èwɔnɛ nenema la, eteƒe madidi o, viwòa ƒe nuwɔna asɔ kple nu si wònya.
In time, your child will connect moral values with actions.
Ðe nu si tae nane nyo alo menyo o la me.
Explain the reasons for your moral code.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, bia nyawo abe: Nu ka tae wònyo be woato nyateƒe?
For example, ask questions such as: Why is honesty the best policy?
Aleke alakpadada ate ŋu agblẽ xɔlɔ̃wo dome?
How can lying damage friendships?
Nu ka tae fififi menyo o?
Why is stealing wrong?
Kpe ɖe eŋu be wòabu nuwo ŋu nyuie ale be wòate ŋu atu ŋutete si akpe ɖe eŋu wòade vovo nyui kple vɔ̃ dome la ɖo.
Appeal to your child’s developing conscience and sense of logic.
Te gbe ɖe vi si nɔnɔme nyuiwo ɖena dzi.
Emphasize the benefits of adhering to good morals.
Àte ŋu agblɔ be: "Ne ètoa nyateƒe la, amewo aka ɖe dziwò " alo "ne ènyoa dɔme la, amewo alɔ̃ ate ɖe ŋuwò. "
You could say: "If you are honest, others will trust you " or "If you are kind, people will like being around you. "
Na ƒomea me tɔwo katã naɖe nɔnɔme nyuiwo afia.
Make your moral code part of your family identity.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Minɔ mia ɖokui me dzrom kpɔ ne mianya ame siwo ƒomevi mienye. " 2 Korintotɔwo 13:5.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Keep proving what you yourselves are. "​ 2 Corinthians 13:5.
Ele be ƒomea me tɔwo katã naɖe nɔnɔme nyuiwo afia ale be nàte ŋu agblɔ nyateƒetɔe be:
Your moral code should be part of your family, so that you can truthfully say:
"Míedaa alakpa le míaƒe ƒomea me o. "
"In our family we do not lie. "
"Míetua kɔ ame alo bluna ɖe ame ta o. "
"We do not hit others or scream at them. "
"Míedaa gbe ɖe ame gbɔ alo dzua ame o. "
"We do not approve of abusive speech. "
Esia ana viwòa nakpɔe be menye sewo koe nɔnɔme nyuiwo nye o, ke boŋ wonye nu siwo wonya na ƒomea.
Your child will see that moral values are not mere rules to follow but that they make up the family’s identity.
Dzro nɔnɔme nyui siwo nu ƒomea nɔa agbe ɖo me kple viwòa edziedzi.
Frequently discuss your family values with your child.
Zã nu siwo dzɔna gbe sia gbe nàtsɔ afia nui.
Use everyday situations as object lessons.
Àte ŋu atsɔ nu siwo nu mienɔa agbe ɖo asɔ kple esiwo dzena le nyadzɔdzɔwo me alo esiwo wòsena le suku.
You could compare your values with those presented in the media or in school.
Bia nyawo abe: "Ne wòe ɖe, nu kae nàwɔ? "
Ask your child questions like: "What would you have done? "
"Ne míaƒe ƒomeae la, anye nu kae míawɔ? " la ene viwòa.
"How would our family have handled this? "
Do ŋusẽe be wòalé nu nyui wɔwɔ me ɖe asi.
Reinforce moral values.
BIBLIA ƑE MƆFIAME: "Milé dzitsinya nyui me ɖe asi. " 1 Petro 3:16.
BIBLE PRINCIPLE: "Maintain a good conscience. "​ 1 Peter 3:16.
Kafui ɖe nɔnɔme nyuiwo ta.
Commend good behavior.
Ne viwò ɖe nɔnɔme nyui aɖe fia la, kafui ɖe eta, eye nàgblɔ nu si tae la nɛ.
If your child displays good moral values in what he does, praise him for it and explain why.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, àte ŋu agblɔ be: "Ètoa nyateƒe.
For example, you could say: "You were honest.
Melɔ̃ wò ɖe esia ta. "
I am proud of you. "
Ne viwò ʋu nu gbegblẽ aɖe si wòwɔ me na wò la, kafui tso dzi me ɖe ale si wòto nyateƒee ta, hafi nàɖɔe ɖo.
If your child confesses to having done something wrong, sincerely commend him for his honesty before you correct him.
Ðɔe ɖo ne eda vo.
Correct bad behavior.
Kpe ɖe eŋu wòakpɔ vodada aɖe si wòwɔ la me tsonu.
Help your children accept responsibility for their actions.
Na ɖevia nanya nu gbegblẽ si wòwɔ kple ale si eƒe nuwɔna mesɔ kple nɔnɔme nyui siwo nu ƒomea nɔa agbe ɖo o.
Children should know what they did wrong and how their conduct deviates from the family’s value system.

Dzila aɖewo medina be yewo vi ‘nase veve’ ɖe nu gbegblẽ aɖe si wòwɔ ta o, gake ne èkpe ɖe eŋu wòkpɔ nu gbegblẽ si wòwɔ la, akpe ɖe eŋu be dzitsinya nyui nanɔ esi eye wòanya nu si nye nyui kple vɔ̃ emegbe.

Some parents are reluctant to make their child ‘feel bad’ about misbehavior, but discussing bad behavior with your child this way will help him develop a conscience that is sensitive to right and wrong.
Nyɔnuvi aɖe kpɔe esi nɔa le nyɔnu aɖe si ƒe gakotokuvi ge la tsɔm be yeatsɔ anɛ

Ðo Kpɔɖeŋu Nyui
Teach by Example
Ðe vinyewo kpɔnɛ le nye nuwɔna kple nyagbɔgblɔwo me be menɔa agbe ɖe nu siwo nu míaƒe ƒomea nɔa agbe ɖo la nua?
Do my children see in my actions and words that I live by the values that our family has adopted?
Ðe nye kple srɔ̃nye siaa míenɔa agbe ɖe nu siwo tututu nu míaƒe ƒomea nɔa agbe ɖo la nua?
Do my spouse and I promote the same values?
Ne nyemete ŋu wɔ ɖe se aɖe dzi le ƒomea me o la, ɖe mesusuna alo gblɔna be, "Se ma mebla ame tsitsiwo oa "?
Do I justify ignoring my moral code by saying or thinking, "This is OK for adults "?
Nu Si Míewɔna . . .
What We Did . . .
"Ne ame aɖe ɖe nɔnɔme nyui aɖe fia eye nu nyuiwo do tso eme la, míetsɔa ema sɔna kple ame bubu si wɔ tiatia gbegblẽ aɖe kple nu si do tso eme, eye míezãa wo tsɔ fiaa nu mía viawo.
"We used the experiences of others to show the benefits of good morals and compared the results they had with those of people who made unwise decisions.
Ne mía viwo gblɔ tiatia gbegblẽ aɖe si wo hati aɖe wɔ la, míezãa mɔnukpɔkpɔa dzroa eme kpli wo ale be woagaɖe afɔ ma tɔgbi o. " Nicole.
When our children told us about a peer who made a poor choice, we discussed it with them so that they would not go down the same path. "​ Nicole.
"Esi mía vinyɔnua nɔ sue la, míegblɔna nɛ be tiatia eve koe li wòate ŋu awɔ, ɖeka nyo, ɖeka menyo o, eye míeƒoa nu tso ɖe sia ɖe kple emetsonuwo ŋu.
"When our daughter was very young, we would tell her that she had two choices​ one good and the other bad ​and we outlined the consequences of each.
Esia kpe ɖe eŋu wòsrɔ̃ ale si wòatso nya me.
From this, she learned to make decisions.
Esia ɖe vi nɛ ŋutɔ, elabe èɖanye ɖevi alo ame tsitsi o, àtso nya me le nuwo ŋu godoo. " Yolanda.
It was a vital lesson, since life is all about choices, no matter how old we are. "​ Yolanda.
Nu Bubu Siwo Akpe Ðe Dzilawo Ŋu
More Help for Parents
Nyɔnu aɖe le Biblia xlẽm
A woman reads the Bible
Abe ale si nàde dzesii ene la, Biblia mee aɖaŋuɖoɖo siwo dze le magazine sia me la tso.
As you might have noticed, the advice found in this magazine is based on the Bible.
Aɖaŋuɖoɖo nyuitɔ kekeake siwo aɖe vi na ƒomea me tɔ ɖe sia ɖe la le Biblia me.
The Bible contains the best guidance for sound living for each member of the family.
Mɔfiame siwo le eme ate ŋu akpe ɖe ame ŋu be wòabu nuwo ŋu nyuie eye wòatso nya me nyuie hã. Lododowo 1:1-4.
Its principles can improve a person’s thinking ability and sound judgment.​ Proverbs 1:1-4.
BIBLIA LA ÐO AGBEMEBIABIA VEVI AÐEWO ŊU, ÐEWOE NYE:
THE BIBLE ALSO ANSWERS LIFE’S BIG QUESTIONS, SUCH AS:
Nu ka tae míele agbe?
What is the meaning of life?
Mawue nana míekpea fua?
Is God to blame for our suffering?
Nu kae dzɔna ɖe ame dzi ne eku?
What happens when we die?
Míadi be wò ŋutɔ nàdi ŋuɖoɖo na biabia siawo kple bubuwo le Biblia me.

Amegbetɔwo Ƒe Dedienɔnɔ Ðo Afɔku Me
Threats to Our Safety and Security
Nyatakaka aɖe gblɔ be: "Ele eme be amegbetɔwo yi ŋgɔ egbea le mɔ̃ɖaŋununya, dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya kple ganyawo me ale gbegbe . . .
"This generation enjoys unprecedented technological, scientific and financial resources . . .
Togbɔ be ele alea hã la, edze abe fifia boŋue [dunyahehe, ganyawo kple dzɔdzɔmenuwo] dome le gbegblẽm wu ene. " The Global Risks Report 2018, World Economic Forum.
And yet this is perhaps the first generation to take the world to the brink of a [political, economic, and environmental] systems breakdown. "​ The Global Risks Report 2018, World Economic Forum.
NU KA TAE AME ŊKUTA GEÐEWO TSI DZI ÐE AMEGBETƆWO KPLE ANYIGBAA SIAA ƑE ETSƆME ŊU?
WHY ARE MANY INFORMED PEOPLE CONCERNED ABOUT OUR FUTURE AND THAT OF THE EARTH?

CONSIDER JUST SOME OF THE CHALLENGES FACING US.
Kɔmpiuta si womele zazãm o
A locked computer
INTERNET DZI NU VLO WƆWƆ: Nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ si nye The Australian gblɔ be: "Afɔku va le internet zazã le ŋkeke siawo me ŋu ale gbegbe.
CYBERCRIME: "Increasingly the internet is proving to be a dangerous place to visit.
Eva zu teƒe si ɖevigbɔdɔlawo, ŋutasẽnuwɔlawo kple ame siwo dea dzre amewo dome bɔ ɖo.
It is a haven for pedophiles, bullies, trolls and hackers, " says the newspaper The Australian.
Amewo ƒe nyatakakawo fifi to internet dzi le dzidzim ɖe edzi ŋutɔ le xexea me. . . .
"Identity theft is one of the fastest-growing crimes in the world. . . .
Internet la na amegbetɔwo ƒe vɔɖivɔ̃ɖi kple tagbɔsesẽ va dze nyuie. "

FINANCIAL INEQUALITY: According to a recent Oxfam International report, the eight richest people own the same amount of wealth as the poorer half of humanity.

CONFLICT AND PERSECUTION: A 2018 United Nations Refugee Agency report said: "We are now witnessing the highest levels of displacement on record. "

Nu Si Koŋ Akpɔ Míaƒe Kuxiwo Gbɔ
Getting to the Root of Our Problems
Èsusu be amegbetɔwo ate ŋu akpɔ ta na kuxi gbogbo siwo wɔe be ŋutifafa kple dedienɔnɔ bɔ mí si na be míaƒe etsɔme ɖo afɔku me la gbɔa?
Do you believe that mankind can solve the many problems that rob us of peace and security and that threaten our future?
Ne míedi be míakpɔ ta na kuxiawo ŋutɔŋutɔ la, ke ele be míadi kuxiawo ƒe ke.

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, Tom dze dɔ eye emegbe wòku.
To illustrate, a patient named Tom was sick and later died.
Nu ka tae wòku?
Why did he die?
Ðɔkta si gbɔ wokplɔ Tom vɛ hafi wòku la gblɔ be: "Esi wòdze dɔ teti la, meva susu me na ame aɖeke be yeadi nu si koŋ na wòdze dɔa o. "
"When his first symptoms appeared, no one thought to search for their underlying cause, " wrote the doctor whose hospital received Tom shortly before he died.
Edze abe atike siwo ana Tom ƒe lãmea naka ɖe eme koe ɖɔkta siwo kpɔ egbɔ va yi la nɛ ene.
It seems that Tom’s earlier caregivers had simply given him medication to make him feel better.
Ðe wòanye be nu ma tɔgbi wɔmee amegbetɔwo le be yewoatsɔ akpɔ xexea ƒe kuxiwo gbɔa?

Le kpɔɖeŋu me, ne dziɖuɖuwo di be yewoaɖe nu vlo wɔwɔwo ɖa la, wowɔa sewo, dea videoɖemɔ̃wo teƒewo eye wonana poliswo léa fɔ ɖe woƒe dɔwo ŋu wu.
For example, in fighting crime, governments enact laws, install video surveillance, and strengthen police forces.
Togbɔ be mɔnu siawo wɔa dɔ hã, womekpɔa kuxiawo gbɔ keŋkeŋ o.
But these measures, while effective to some extent, do not address underlying causes.
Ale si amewo wɔa nui ɖea woƒe tamebubu, seselelãme kple woƒe didiwo fiana.
After all, behavior usually reflects attitudes, beliefs, and desires.
Daniel si le Anyiehe Amerika dukɔ aɖe si ƒe ganyawo le gbegblẽm me gblɔ be: "Nu dze edzi na mí va yi.
Daniel, who lives in a South American country that has a failing economy, says: "We once had normal lives.
Míevɔ̃na be adzogliwo ava dze mía dzi o.

Gake fifiaa, du alo kɔƒe aɖeke meli si me tomefafa le o.
But now there no longer exists a peaceful town or village.
Ganyawo ƒe gbegblẽ wɔe be ale si tututu ame geɖe le la va dze ƒãa wonye ŋubiãlawo eye womedea bubu agbe alo amewo ƒe nunɔamesiwo ŋu o. "
The failing economy has revealed what many people are really like​ greedy and lacking in respect for the life or property of others. "
Ŋutsu aɖe si míayɔ be Elias si le Asia dukɔ aɖe me la si aʋa eye emegbe wova srɔ̃ Biblia kplii.
A man whom we will call Elias fled from a conflict in the Middle East and later studied the Bible.
Egblɔ be: "Ðekakpui geɖe siwo le mía de la ƒe ƒometɔwo kple subɔsubɔha siwo me wole siwo de dunyaheha aɖe dzi la de dzi ƒo na wo be woawɔ aʋaa ne woaxɔ ŋkɔ.
He states: "Many young men from my home city were encouraged by their families and the political-religious system to get involved in the war and be considered heroes.
Wogblɔ nya mawo ke na ame siwo nye woƒe futɔwo hã!
Those on the opposing side were told the very same thing!
Esiawo katã na mekpɔ ale si wòwɔ nublanui be woaɖo ŋu ɖe dziɖula siwo nye amegbetɔwo ŋu. "
All of this made me see how sad it is to put faith in human rulers. "
Biblia gblɔ be:
An ancient book of wisdom rightly states:
"Amegbetɔ ƒe dzimesusu nye vɔ̃ tso eƒe ɖevime ke. " 1 Mose 8:21.
"The inclination of the heart of man is bad from his youth up. "​ Genesis 8:21.
"Ame ƒe dzi la, alakpatɔ wònye wu nuwo katã, eye enu menya léna o.

"Out of the heart come wicked reasonings, murders, . . . sexual immorality, thefts, false testimonies. "​ Matthew 15:19.
Amegbetɔwo mete ŋu le nɔnɔme gbegblẽ siwo le mía me la nu lém o.

Le nyateƒe me la, gbegblẽm ɖe edzi koe nɔnɔmeawo le abe ale si ko wòle le kuxi siwo ŋu míeƒo nu tsoe le nyati si do ŋgɔ me ene.
In fact, those traits appear to be getting worse, as reflected in the problems mentioned in the preceding article.
(2 Timoteo 3:1-5) Eye ele alea togbɔ be sidzedze geɖe va su amegbetɔwo si eye mɔ siwo dzi míetona xɔa nyatakakawo alo ɖoa wo ɖa va nyo ɖe edzi fifia wu hã!
(2 Timothy 3:1-5) And this is so despite the vast amount of information that is available today, not to mention our unprecedented ability to communicate with others!

Are we trying to do the impossible?
ÐE MÍELE NU SI MATE ŊU ADZƆ O TEM KPƆA?

Nu ka tae?
The reason?
Elabe seɖoƒe li na nu siwo amegbetɔwo ate ŋu awɔ.
Our human limitations.

The simple truth is this: "It does not belong to man . . . even to direct his step. "

In fact, we were no more created to rule over our fellow humans than we were created to live under water or in outer space!
