Consider this: Do people in general like to have their equals tell them how to live or which moral values to live by?
Ðe amewo dina be woagblɔ ale si wòle be woabu nuwo abe fuɖeɖe alo ame si tɔgbi wòle be woatso kufia na alo ale si woahe wo viwo na yewoa?
Do people like others to dictate how they should view such things as abortion or capital punishment or how they should discipline their children?
Nya siwo dea mama amewo me la dometɔ ʋɛ aɖewo koe nye esiawo.
These are just some of the issues that divide people.
Eya ta togbɔ be asesẽ be míaxɔe ase hã la, susu le nya si Biblia gblɔ me.
So, humbling though it might be, what the Bible says makes sense.
Amegbetɔ medze o eye ŋutete mele esi be wòaɖu ame bubuwo dzi o.
We simply do not have the ability or the moral authority to rule over our fellow humans.
Ekema ame ka ŋue míatrɔ ɖo?
Where, then, can we turn for help?
Ŋuɖoɖoa koe nye be míatrɔ ɖe mía Wɔla ŋu.
The most reasonable answer is for us to turn to our Creator.
Eyae wɔ mí!
After all, he made us!
Meŋlɔ mí be abe ale si ame aɖewo susunɛ ene o.
And contrary to what some may think, he has not forgotten us.
Le nyateƒe me la, ale si wòtsɔa ɖe le eme na mí la dze le Biblia ƒe aɖaŋuɖoɖo siwo me nunya le la me.

Ne míese agbalẽ tɔxɛ ma me nyawo gɔme la, ana míadze si mía ɖokuiwo nyuie wu.
When we understand that unique book, we also understand ourselves better.
Eye akpe ɖe mía ŋu míase nu siwo gbɔ amegbetɔwo ƒe kuxiwo tso la gɔme.
And we can make sense of mankind’s sad history.
Ana míase nu si tae Germanytɔwo ƒe xexemenunyala aɖe gblɔ be, "amewo kple dziɖuɖuwo mesrɔ̃ naneke tso nu siwo dzɔ va yi me o, eye wometrɔ woƒe nɔnɔme o " hã gɔme.
We can see why, as a German philosopher once wrote, "peoples and governments never have learned anything from history, or acted on principles deduced from it. "

Daniel, quoted earlier, writes: "Every day convinces me more that humans cannot govern well. . . .

While on a school trip, some teenage boys were accused of sexually assaulting another male student.
Ðevi siawo dea suku xɔŋkɔ aɖe si menye dziɖuɖu tɔ o la le Canada.
All attended a prestigious private school in Canada.

Le nudzɔdzɔ sia megbe la, aƒetɔ Leonard Stern ŋlɔ ɖe nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ si nye Ottawa Citizen me be: "Ne sɔhɛ aɖe ƒe susu ɖa, ele suku xɔŋkɔ aɖe dem eye kesinɔnuwo le esi hã, ema mawɔe be wòanɔ agbe nyui kokoko o. "

After the incident, Leonard Stern wrote in the Ottawa Citizen newspaper: "All the advantages of intellect and education and social class do not inoculate young people against making bad moral decisions. "
Aƒetɔ Stern gblɔ kpee be: "Zi geɖe la, taɖodzinu vevi si gbɔ míekpɔa mɔ be dzilawo naɖoe nye be woafia nu si nye agbe nyui nɔnɔ wo viwo.

Nyateƒee wònye be sukudede le vevie.

But even the best secular education cannot help a person to combat wrong desires or bad inclinations.
Ekema afi kae míate ŋu atrɔ ɖo asrɔ̃ nu siwo akpe ɖe ame ŋu wòatsri nɔnɔme gbegblẽwo eye wòasrɔ̃ nɔnɔme nyuiwo?

"Lɔlɔ̃ gbɔa dzi blewu, eye wònyoa dɔme.

It does not keep account of the injury.

Love never fails. "​ 1 Corinthians 13:4-8.

Love can also move people to make sacrifices, even lifestyle changes, for the benefit of others.
Le kpɔɖeŋu me, esi ŋutsu aɖe si míayɔ be George xɔ tɔgbuiyɔvi la, edi vevie be ɖevia nanɔ ye gbɔ nɔm.
For example, when a man we will call George became a grandfather, he dearly wanted to spend time with his grandson.
Gake kuxi aɖe li.
But there was a problem.
George yɔa sigaret ŋutɔ, eye toyɔvia medina be wòanɔ sigaret yɔm le ɖevia gbɔ o.
George smoked heavily, and his son-in-law did not want him smoking around the baby.
Nu kae George wɔ?
What did George do?
Togbɔ be enoa sigaret ƒe 50 sɔŋue nye ema hã la, edzudzɔ enono le tɔgbuiyɔvia ta.
Even though he had smoked for 50 years, he gave up the habit for the sake of his grandson.
Nyateƒee lɔlɔ̃ nu sẽ ŋutɔ!
Yes, what power love has!
Biblia kpena ɖe mía ŋu be míatu nɔnɔme nyuiwo abe nyuiwɔwɔ, dɔmenyonyo kple vevietɔ lɔlɔ̃ ene ɖo
The Bible helps us to cultivate many fine qualities, such as goodness, kindness, and especially love
Lɔlɔ̃ nye nɔnɔme vevi aɖe si míesrɔ̃na.
Love is a quality that we learn.
Dzilawo wɔa akpa vevi aɖe fiaa nu wo viwo be woalɔ̃ ame.
Parents play a big role in teaching their children how to love.
Wokpɔa wo viwo dzi, kpɔa wo ta, eye wokpena ɖe wo ŋu ne nu vevi wɔ wo alo wodze dɔ.
They feed and protect their children and come to their aid when they are hurt or sick.
Dzila nyuiwo ɖoa dze kple wo viwo eye wofiaa nu wo.
Good parents talk with their children and teach them.
Wohea wo viwo hã. Esia ƒe ɖee nye be woafia nu siwo nye nyui kple vɔ̃ wo.
They also discipline their children, which includes teaching them sound principles of right and wrong.
Azɔ hã, dzila nyuiwo ɖoa kpɔɖeŋu nyuiwo na wo viwo be woasrɔ̃.
Additionally, good parents set a fine example, becoming role models for their children.
Gake nublanuitɔe la, dzila aɖewo mete ŋu tsɔ woƒe agbanɔamedzi sia nyuie o.
Sadly, though, some parents fail in their responsibilities.
Ðe esia fia be ɖeviawo ava do kpo nua?
Does this mean that their children are doomed to failure?
Gbeɖe!
Not at all!
Ame tsitsi aɖewo siwo tsi le ƒome siwo me nuwo metsɔ afɔ nyuie le o me gɔ̃ hã wɔ tɔtrɔ ɖedzesiwo le woƒe agbe me, eye wova zu dzila siwo léa be na wo viwo kple ame ɖɔʋuwo.
Even many older people, including some who grew up in dysfunctional families, have made amazing changes in their lives, becoming caring and trustworthy citizens.
Abe ale si míakpɔe le nyati si kplɔe ɖo me ene la, ame siawo dometɔ aɖewo nye ame siwo amewo buna tsã be womate ŋu atrɔ o!
As we will see in the following article, that even includes some who may have been viewed by others as beyond reform!
NYA VEVITƆ
KEY POINT
BIBLIA ATE ŊU AWƆ NU SI SUKUDEDE MATE ŊU AWƆ O, EYAE NYE BE ATE ŊU AFIA NU AME BE EƑE AGBƆNƆNƆ NANYO ÐE EDZI
THE BIBLE CAN PROVIDE WHAT SECULAR EDUCATION CANNOT​ TRUSTWORTHY MORAL AND SPIRITUAL GUIDANCE
MENYE AMEWO KATÃE ATRƆ O
NOT EVERYONE WILL CHANGE
Biblia gblɔe eme kɔ nyuie be ame aɖewo agbe be yewomatrɔ o.
The Bible frankly acknowledges that some people will simply refuse to change for the better.
Daniel 12:10 gblɔ be ame vɔ̃ɖiwo ayi edzi "awɔ nu vɔ̃ɖi. "
The wicked will continue to "act wickedly, " says Daniel 12:10.
Ðe nyateƒenya ma fia be míate ŋu akpɔ ŋutifafa kple dedienɔnɔ gbeɖe oa?
Does that reality doom our prospects for lasting peace and safety?
Ne amegbetɔwo gbɔe ŋutifafa kple dedienɔnɔ atso la, anye ne mɔkpɔkpɔ aɖeke meli o.
If the future were just in human hands, our prospects would be grim indeed.
Gake abe ale si míava kpɔe ene la, menye nenemae o.
But as we will see, that is not the case.
Le nyateƒe me la, míate ŋu aka ɖe edzi be etsɔme nyui aɖe si me ŋutifafa le la le mía lalam!
In fact, the opposite is true​ our future can be very bright!
Ricardo Kple Andres Ƒe Ŋutinyawo
The Stories of Ricardo and Andres
Biblia te ŋu nana amewo ƒe agbenɔnɔ nyona ɖe edzi wòwɔa nuku.
Education based on the Bible has amazing power to improve lives.
De ŋugble le kpɔɖeŋu eve siwo ku ɖe Ricardo kple Andres ŋu kpɔ.
Consider two examples of this: Ricardo and Andres.
RICARDO: Ƒe 15 koe mexɔ esi mege ɖe gbevuha aɖe me.
RICARDO: At the impressionable age of 15, I joined a gang.
Xɔ̃nye yeyeawo kpɔ ŋusẽ ɖe dzinye vevie.
My new friends had a big influence on me.
Le nyateƒe me la, nye taɖodzinue nye be mayi gaxɔ me ƒe ewo!
In fact, it became my goal to spend ten years in prison!
Nya ma adze bometsinya.
That may sound foolish.
Gake le afi si menɔ la, wokafua ame siwo nɔ gaxɔ me kpɔ eye wodea bubu wo ŋu vevie.
But in my neighborhood, those who had spent time in prison were admired and respected.
Eya ta medi be manɔ abe woawo ene.
And I wanted to be like them.
Ricardo zãa tu eye wònoa gbekui tsã; gake Ricardo va zu Yehowa Ðasefo fifia
Ricardo uses a gun and smokes in the past; Ricardo as one of Jehovah’s Witnesses
Nu mawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye atike vɔ̃ɖiwo zazã, gbɔdɔdɔ kple ŋutasẽnuwo wɔwɔ.
I experienced all that is associated with gang life, including drugs, sex, and violence.
Le zã aɖe me la, míaƒe gbevuhaa kple gbevuha bubu aɖe míenɔ tu dam mía nɔewo.
One night I was involved in a shoot-out.
Mesusu be woawum, gake mesi, naneke mewɔm o.
I thought I was going to be killed, but I escaped unharmed.
Esia megbe la, meva nɔ tame bum le nye agbe kple taɖodzinu siwo le asinye ŋu vevie, eye metso nya me be matrɔ.
After that, I began to think more seriously about my life and my goals, and I decided that I wanted to change.
Gake aleke mawɔe?
But how?
Ame kae akpe ɖe ŋunye?
Where could I find help?
Nye ƒometɔ geɖe mekpɔa dzidzɔ o.
Most of my relatives were unhappy.
Kuxiwo ɖe kpe na wo.
Their lives were full of problems.
Gake nyruinye kple eƒe ƒomea ya kpɔa dzidzɔ.
But that was not the case with the family of one of my uncles.
Menya be ame nyuiwoe wonye eye wowɔna ɖe Biblia me mɔfiamewo dzi.
I knew that they were good people, and I knew that they lived by Bible principles.
Le nyateƒe me la, wofiam kpɔ be Mawu ƒe ŋkɔe nye Yehowa.
In fact, I had once learned from them that God’s name is Jehovah.
Eya ta le tua dada megbea, medo gbe ɖa na Yehowa yɔ eŋkɔ gblɔ nɛ be wòakpe ɖe ŋunye.
So not long after the shoot-out, I prayed to Jehovah, addressing him by name and asking him to help me.
Nukutɔea, Yehowa Ðasefo aɖe va ƒo ʋɔ nam le ŋufɔke!
To my astonishment, the very next day, one of Jehovah’s Witnesses knocked on my door!
Eyae va zu nye Biblia nufiala.
He became my Bible teacher.
Gake kuxi gã aɖe li.
I soon faced a big challenge.
Xɔ̃nye xoxoawo ƒoa ka nam zi geɖe gblɔna nam be mava ne míaɖo gbɔdo.
My old friends often phoned, asking me to hang out with them.
Togbɔ be menɔ bɔbɔe o hã, megbena.
Though it was not easy, I said no.
Meɖoe kplikpaa be mayi Biblia sɔsrɔ̃a dzi, eye edzɔ dzi nam be nyemedzudzɔ o!
I was determined to continue my Bible study, and I am glad that I did!
Nye agbenɔnɔ trɔ kura, eye meva nɔ dzidzɔ kpɔm ŋutɔ.
My life improved dramatically, and I found true happiness.
Meɖo ŋku edzi be megblɔ na Mawu le gbedodoɖa me kpɔ be ɖe meɖoe be mayi gaxɔ me ƒe ewo ale be woade bubu ŋunye abe gbevuhamenɔla ene.
I remember telling God in prayer that I had once been willing to spend ten years in prison to earn respect as a gang member.
Gake fifia ya megblɔ na Mawu be wòana mazã ɣeyiɣi geɖe atsɔ afia nu amewo tso eyama ŋu abe ale si wokpe ɖe ŋunyee ene hena ƒe ewo ya teti.
So I asked him to allow me to serve him for at least ten years as a full-time minister in order to help others just as I had been helped.
Mawu ɖo nye gbedodoɖaa ŋu, elabe ƒe 17 ye nye esia mele gbeƒã ɖem na amewo!
God answered my prayer, for I have spent 17 years as a full-time minister!
Eye magblɔ kpee be nyemeɖo afɔ gaxɔa me o.
And I might add, I never went to prison.
Gake xɔ̃nye xoxoawo dometɔ geɖe le gaxɔ me hena ƒe geɖe.
Many of my former friends, however, are serving long prison sentences.
Wo dometɔ aɖewo ku.
Others are dead.
Ne metrɔ kpɔ megbe la, akpe koe mada na nye ƒometɔ siwo nye Ðasefoawo.
Looking back, I am most grateful to my Witness relatives.
Wolɔ̃ faa be yewoawɔ ɖe Biblia ƒe mɔfiamewo dzi, eye esia na woto vovo.
They were willing to be different, to live by the Bible.
Meva dea bubu wo ŋu wu gbevuhaa me tɔ ɖe sia ɖe.
I grew to respect them more than I ever respected anyone in the gang.
Ƒo wo katã ta la, medaa akpe na Mawu be wòfia mɔ nyuitɔ si nu manɔ agbe ɖo lam.
Above all, I am thankful to God for teaching me the very best way to live.
ANDRES: Wodzim le nuto si me ahedada bɔ ɖo, afi si wozãa atike vɔ̃ɖiwo, daa adzo, wua ame eye gbolowɔwɔ bɔ ɖo la me, eye afi mae menɔ tsi.
ANDRES: I was born and raised in a poor neighborhood where drugs, extortion, murder, and prostitution were common.
Ahanoxee tɔnye nye eye kokein nono zu numame nɛ.
My father was an alcoholic and a cocaine addict.
Dzre dzi koe eya kple nɔnye wonɔna, eye wodaa kɔ.
He and my mother were always fighting, verbally and physically.
Andres fia fi eye wònoa aha tsu tsã; gake Andres va zu Yehowa Ðasefo fifia
Andres steals and overdrinks in the past; Andres as one of Jehovah’s Witnesses
Ðevi ko menye esi mete ahanono eye mezãa atike vɔ̃ɖiwo.
At an early age, I began drinking alcohol and using drugs.
Ablɔdzi koŋue menɔna, nɔ amewo fim eye medzraa nu siwo mefina la.
I spent most of my time on the streets, stealing and then selling what I stole.
Esi menɔ tsitsim la, tɔnye di be yeana nye kpli ye dome navivi, gake mewɔe le mɔ nyuitɔ nu o, efia ale si matsɔ atike vɔ̃ɖiwo kple nu bubu siwo ŋu se meɖe mɔ ɖo o la agbã dee eye míadzra wo.
As I got older, my father, in a misguided attempt to draw close to me, taught me how to smuggle drugs and other illegal products into the country and sell them.
Esia na mekpɔ ga kaba.
I made a lot of money​ fast.
Gake gbe ɖeka la, poliswo va nye aƒe me va lém le esi mete kpɔ be mawu ame ta, eye wodem mɔ ƒe atɔ̃.
Then one day the police came to my home. They arrested me, and I was sentenced to five years in prison for attempted murder.
Gbe ɖeka ŋdi la, woɖe gbeƒã le gaxɔa ƒe nuƒomɔ̃ dzi tsɔ nɔ gamenɔlawo kpem be woava se Biblia me nuƒo aɖe si Yehowa Ðasefowo aƒo.
One morning an announcement over the prison loudspeaker invited inmates to a Bible discussion held by Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Meyi.
I decided to attend.
Susu le nya siwo mese la me, eya ta melɔ̃ be Ðasefoawo nasrɔ̃ Biblia kplim.
What I heard made sense, so I began to study the Bible with the Witnesses.
Wometɔa tsi Ŋɔŋlɔawo me nyawo o, ke boŋ wofia ale si Mawu di be míanɔ agbe wòadze eŋu lam.
They did not water down the Scriptures but showed me God’s high moral standards.
Eteƒe medidi o meva kpɔe be nyemate ŋu awɔ tɔtrɔ siwo hiã la le ɖokuinye si o, vevietɔ ne gamenɔla bubu siwo mekpɔ dzidzɔ ɖe nu si srɔ̃m mele ŋu o la do ŋɔdzi nam.
I soon realized that I could not make the needed changes without help, especially when I received threats from fellow inmates who did not like what I was doing.
Eya ta medo gbe ɖa na Yehowa be wòado ŋusẽm mawɔ nu le nunya me, eye ekpe ɖe ŋunye.
So I prayed for strength and wisdom, and Jehovah helped me.
Le nyateƒe me la, le esi mana ta teƒea, dzi nɔ ƒonye mezã Biblia tsɔ ɖe gbeƒã na gamenɔla bubuwo.
In fact, I was even able to go on the offensive, as it were, by speaking to other prisoners about the Bible.
Esi ɣeyiɣia de be woaɖe asi le ŋunye la, menɔ vɔvɔ̃m ale gbegbe be medi be mayi edzi aganɔ gaxɔa me vie!
When my release came, I was so nervous that I actually wanted to stay in prison longer!
Esi menɔ dzodzom la, gamenɔla geɖe wɔ baibai nam.
As I was leaving, a number of inmates waved goodbye.
Wo dometɔ aɖewo gɔ̃ hã gblɔ vividoɖeameŋutɔe be, "Pastor, de aƒe me nyuie. "
Some even said affectionately, "Go home, little shepherd. "
Ne mebu ale si nye agbe anɔ ne ɖe nyemeɖe mɔ na Mawu be wòafia num o la, edzia ŋɔ nam.
It scares me to think about how my life might have turned out had I not allowed God to educate me.
Medaa akpe be Mawu lɔ̃m eye mebum be nyemate ŋu atrɔ o.
I am very, very thankful that God loves me and did not consider me a lost cause.
NYA VEVITƆ
KEY POINT
NE AME BƆBƆA EÐOKUI, TOA NYATEƑE, EYE WÒDEA DZESII BE ELE BE YEAWƆ TƆTRƆWO, EYE WÒDII BE YEAWƆE LA, BIBLIA ATE ŊU AKPE ÐE EŊU.
WHEN A PERSON IS HUMBLE AND HONEST, RECOGNIZES THAT HE HAS TO MAKE CHANGES, AND WANTS TO DO SO, THE BIBLE CAN HELP HIM.
ETE ŊU KPE ÐE AME GEÐE ŊU
IT HAS AN EXCELLENT TRACK RECORD
"Seɖoƒe Manɔe Na Ŋutifafa " O
"Of . . . Peace There Shall Be No End "
Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo le dzi dem ƒo na ameƒomeviwo katã be woawɔ ɖeka ade bubu amegbetɔwo ƒe gomenɔamesiwo ŋu, eye woawɔ nu siwo magblẽ nu le woƒe nutowo me ŋu o.
The United Nations is promoting the concept of "global citizenship. " Goals include encouraging international cooperation, respecting human rights, and protecting our planet.
Nu ka tae?
The reason?

Abe ale si Aƒetɔ Maher Nasser gblɔ le nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ aɖe (UN Chronicle) me ene la, "Yame ƒe nɔnɔmewo le tɔtrɔm le xexea me godoo, nu vlo wɔhabɔbɔwo, ameŋkumekpɔkpɔ, aʋawɔwɔ si nu menya le lelém o, sitsoƒedilawo, nu vlo wɔlawo ƒe ŋɔdzidoname si le xexea me katã [kple] dɔxɔleameŋuwo " le gã dom ɖe edzi le dukɔ sia dukɔ me.

As expressed by Maher Nasser in the UN Chronicle, "climate change, organized crime, rising inequalities, unresolved conflicts, mass displacement of people, global terrorism, infectious diseases, and similar threats do not recognize . . . borders. "
Ame aɖewo gɔ̃ hã doe ɖa be dziɖuɖu ɖeka nanɔ xexea me katã.
Others have gone even further, advocating a world government.
Ame siawo dometɔ aɖewoe nye Dante (ƒe 1265-1321) si nye Italytɔwo ƒe xexemenunyala, hakpanyaŋlɔla kple dziɖuɖumegã kple Albert Einstein (1879-1955) si nye dzɔdzɔmeŋusẽŋununyala.
They include the Italian philosopher, poet, and statesman Dante (1265-1321) and the physicist Albert Einstein (1879-1955).
Dante xɔe se be ŋutifafa mate ŋu anɔ xexe sia si me dziɖula vovovowo le dzi ɖum le la me eteƒe nadidi o.
Dante believed that peace could not last in a politically divided world.
Eyɔ nya tso Yesu Kristo ƒe nyawo me gblɔ be, "Fiaɖuƒe ɖe sia ɖe si ma ɖe eɖokui ŋu la gbãna. "
A "kingdom divided against itself comes to ruin, " he said, quoting Jesus Christ.​ Luke 11:17.
Luka 11:17. Le Xexemeʋa Evelia si me woda atɔmik bɔmb eve le me megbe kpuie la, Albert Einstein ŋlɔ lɛta aɖe na Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo Ƒe Sewɔtakpekpea, si wòde nyadzɔdzɔgbalẽ aɖe me.
Shortly after World War II, which saw the use of two atomic bombs, Albert Einstein wrote an open letter to the General Assembly of the United Nations.
Egblɔ le lɛtaa me be: "Ele be Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo nawɔ ɖoɖo aɖe afɔ kpata atsɔ aɖo xexea me katã ƒe dziɖuɖu aɖe anyi si ana xexea nanɔ dedie. "
"The United Nations, " he said, "must act with utmost speed to create the necessary conditions for international security by laying the foundations for a real world government. "
Gake ɖe dunyahela siwo anɔ dziɖuɖu sẽŋu ma me la, mawɔ nu fitifiti, ado kpo nu eye womate amewo ɖe anyi oa?
But could the politicians who would make up such a powerful government be immune to corruption, incompetence, and oppression?
Alo ɖeko woawo hã ava do kpo nu abe dziɖula bubuwo enea?
Or would they be just as prone to those dark traits as others have been?
Biabia siawo na míeɖo ŋku Britaintɔwo ƒe ŋutinyaŋlɔla Lord Acton, ame si gblɔ be: "Ŋusẽ gblẽa ame dome eye ŋusẽkpɔkpɔ ɖe nu sia nu dzi la, ɖe wògblẽa ame dome kura " la ƒe nyawo dzi.
These questions call to mind the words of British historian Lord Acton, who said: "Power tends to corrupt and absolute power corrupts absolutely. "
Togbɔ be ele nenema hã, ne amegbetɔwo akpɔ ŋutifafa eye woawɔ nu aduadu ŋutɔŋutɔ la, ke ele be woawɔ ɖeka.
Even so, if the human family is to enjoy true peace and harmony, we have to be united.
Gake aleke míawɔ aɖo taɖodzinu ma gbɔ?
But how can that goal be achieved?
Ðe wòanya wɔ ŋutɔŋutɔa?
Is it even realistic?
Biblia ɖo nya sia ŋu be ɛ̃.
The Bible’s answer is yes.
Anya wɔ eye ava eme hã.
It can and will be achieved.
Le mɔ ka nu?
How?
Menye xexemedziɖuɖu siwo me dunyahela siwo wɔa nu fitifiti le la dzie wòato ava eme o.
Not by a world government made up of corruptible politicians.
Ke boŋ anye dziɖuɖu aɖe si Mawu ŋutɔ ɖo.
Rather, it will be by a government of God’s making.
Gakpe ɖe eŋu la, Mawu koe dze aɖu eƒe nuwɔwɔwo dzi.
What is more, that government will express his right to rule over his creation.
Dziɖuɖu kae nye ema?
What is that government?
Biblia na ŋkɔe gɔ̃ hã be "Mawu Fiaɖuƒe. " Luka 4:43.
The Bible even gives it a name​ "the Kingdom of God, " or God’s Kingdom.​ Luke 4:43.
"WÒ FIAÐUƑE NAVA "
"LET YOUR KINGDOM COME "
Mawu Fiaɖuƒeae nɔ susu me na Yesu Kristo esi wògblɔ le kpɔɖeŋugbedodoɖaa me be: "Wò Fiaɖuƒe nava.
Jesus Christ had God’s Kingdom in mind when he said in his model prayer: "Let your Kingdom come.
Wò lɔlɔ̃nu nava eme le anyigba dzi. "
Let your will take place . . . on earth. "
(Mateo 6:9, 10) Ɛ̃, Mawu Fiaɖuƒea akpɔ egbɔ be wowɔ Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu le anyigba dzi, ke menye amegbetɔ siwo dina be yewoaɖu dzi godoo alo amegbetɔ ɖokuitɔdilawo ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu o.
(Matthew 6:9, 10) Yes, God’s Kingdom will ensure that God’s will is done on earth, not the will of power-hungry or selfish humans.
Wogayɔa Mawu Fiaɖuƒea be "Dziƒofiaɖuƒe la. "
God’s Kingdom is also called "the Kingdom of the heavens. "
(Mateo 5:3) Nu ka tae?
(Matthew 5:3) The reason?
Togbɔ be anyigbaa dzie wòaɖu hã la, manɔ anyigba dzi hafi aɖu dzi o, ke anɔ dziƒo.
While it will rule over the earth, it will not rule from the earth but will rule from heaven.
Bu nu si nya ma fia ŋu kpɔ.
Think what that means.
Xexea me katã ƒe dziɖuɖu sia mabia gakpekpeɖeŋu tso amewo gbɔ o.
This world government will not require material or financial support.
Gbɔdzɔe ka gbegbe wòanye na ame siwo dzi wòaɖu!
What a relief that will be for its human subjects!
Abe ale si nya "fiaɖuƒe " fia ene la, fia le Mawu Fiaɖuƒea si.
As the term "kingdom " suggests, God’s Kingdom is a royal government.
Fia mae nye Yesu Kristo, ame si Mawu na ŋusẽe.
It has a King​ Jesus Christ ​who received his authority from God.
Biblia gblɔ tso Yesu ŋu be:
Concerning Jesus, the Bible says:
"Dziɖuɖu anɔ abɔta nɛ . . .
"The government shall be upon his shoulder . . .
Eƒe dziɖuɖu akeke ta, eye seɖoƒe manɔe na ŋutifafa " o. Yesaya 9:6, 7.
Of the increase of his government and peace there shall be no end. "​ Isaiah 9:6, 7, King James Version.
"Wotsɔ dziɖuɖu, bubu kple fiaɖuƒe nɛ, ne amehawo, dukɔwo kple gbegbɔgblɔ ɖe sia ɖe dolawo katã nasubɔe.
"To him there were given rulership, honor, and a kingdom, that the peoples, nations, and language groups should all serve him.
Eƒe dziɖuɖu anɔ anyi . . . enu mayi o. " Daniel 7:14.
His rulership . . . will not pass away. "​ Daniel 7:14.
"Xexemefiaɖuƒe la trɔ zu mía Aƒetɔ [si nye Mawu] kple eƒe Kristo la ƒe Fiaɖuƒe. " Nyaɖeɖefia 11:15.

Biblia la gblɔ nudzɔdzɔ ɖedzesi aɖewo ɖi, siwo ana míakpɔe be Mawu Fiaɖuƒea gogo.

" (2 Timothy 3:1-4) Traits such as these have always been manifest to some extent.

For example, Danish historian Peter Munch wrote: "The outbreak of the war in 1914 is the great turning point in the history of humanity.
Do ŋgɔ na ƒe ma la, amewo susu be nuwo le nyonyom ɖe edzi le xexea me, . . . gake nuwo va trɔ kpata ale be afɔku, ŋɔdzi kple fuléle wɔe be amewo megale dedie le afi aɖeke o. "
From a bright epoch of progress, . . . we entered an age of disaster, horror, and hatred, with insecurity everywhere. "

HOW WILL GOD’S KINGDOM TAKE CONTROL?

All who humbly apply his teachings develop personality traits that will enable them to live happily under his Kingdom forever.

HOW CAN YOU BENEFIT FROM KINGDOM RULE?

Consider just two: First, they develop strong faith in him.
Xɔse ma si ŋu kpeɖodzi le la, nana wokana ɖe edzi be Mawu Fiaɖuƒea nye nu ŋutɔŋutɔ eye adze dziɖuɖu gɔme kpuie.

Sedede ma gblɔ be: "Ale si ko miedina be amewo nawɔ na mi la, miwɔ nenema ke na wo. "
Love for neighbor moves them to apply Jesus’ words that are often called the Golden Rule.
Luka 6:31. Esi mía Wɔlaa nye vifofo lɔ̃ame ta la, edia nyui na mí ɣesiaɣi.
It states: "Just as you want men to do to you, do the same way to them. "​ Luke 6:31.
Edi be míase vivi na nu si Biblia yɔ be "agbe vavã " la.
Like a loving father, our Creator wants the very best for us.
(1 Timoteo 6:19) Menye "agbe vavã " lae míele egbea o.
He wants us to experience what the Bible calls "the real life. " (1 Timothy 6:19) Life today is not "the real life. "
Agbea le sesẽm na ame miliɔn geɖe eye wokpea fu hafi kpɔa woƒe nuhiahiãwo.
For millions, it is little more than existence​ and is perilous at that.
Be nàkpɔ ale si "agbe vavã " ma anɔ la, bu nu wɔnuku siwo Mawu Fiaɖuƒea awɔ na eteviwo dometɔ aɖewo ŋu kpɔ.

"Wò Fiaɖuƒe Nava " Gbe Si Ame Miliɔn Geɖe Dona Ða
"Thy Kingdom Come " ​A Prayer Repeated by Millions of People
Èdo gbe ɖa be Mawu Fiaɖuƒea nava kpɔa?
Have you ever prayed for God’s Kingdom to come?
Ƒe alafa geɖee nye esia amewo doa gbe ɖa be, "Wò fiaɖuƒe nava. "
Over the centuries, millions have repeated the words "Thy kingdom come. "
Nu ka tae amewo lɔ̃a gbe sia dodo ɖa?
Why have they prayed that way?
Elabe Yesu gblɔ na eyomedzelawo be woado gbe ɖa be Mawu Fiaɖuƒea nava.
Because Jesus told his followers to pray for God’s Kingdom.
Gbã la, Yesu yomedzelawo mese nu sia nu si wògblɔ tso Fiaɖuƒea ŋu la gɔme o.
At first, Jesus’ followers did not understand everything he said about the Kingdom.
Wobiae gbe ɖeka gɔ̃ hã be: "Aƒetɔ, ɖe nègbugbɔ le fiaɖuƒe la ɖom anyi na Israel le ɣeyiɣi sia mea? "
They once asked him: "Lord, are you restoring the kingdom to Israel at this time? "
Anya wɔ nuku na wo be Yesu meɖo nyaa ŋu na yewo tẽe o.
They were probably surprised when Jesus did not give them a direct answer.
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 1:6, 7) Ðe ema fia be míate ŋu anya nu si Mawu Fiaɖuƒea nye kple ɣeyiɣi si me wòava la oa?
(Acts 1:6, 7) Does that mean we cannot find out what God’s Kingdom is and when it will come?
Mefia nenema o!
Not at all!

Why Do We Need God’s Kingdom?
Tso amegbetɔ gbãtɔwo dzi la, mía Wɔla, ame si ŋkɔe nye Yehowa, koe nye Dziɖula ɖeka kolia.
At the start of human history, our Creator, whose name is Jehovah, was the only Ruler.
Eɖua dzi le lɔlɔ̃ me.
He governed in a loving way.
Etso abɔ nyui aɖe ɖe Eden na amegbetɔwo be wòanye wo nɔƒe.
He made a beautiful home​ a garden in Eden ​for humans to live in.
Azɔ hã, ena nuɖuɖu vovovowo bɔ ɖe afi ma na wo.
He also provided an abundance of food for them.
Tsɔ kpe ɖe eŋu la, ena dɔ si me dzidzeme le la amegbetɔwo be woawɔ.
In addition, he gave humans meaningful work to do.
(1 Mose 1:28, 29; 2:8, 15) Anye ne amegbetɔwo anɔ ŋutifafa me ne ɖe wokpɔtɔ nɔ Mawu ƒe dziɖuɖu si me lɔlɔ̃ le la te.
(Genesis 1:28, 29; 2:8, 15) Mankind would have enjoyed peace if they had remained under God’s loving rulership.
Adam lé atikutsetse si ŋu wode se ɖo si Xawa tsɔ nɛ la ɖe asi.
Adam holding the forbidden fruit that Eve has offered him.
Amegbetɔ gbãtɔwo gbe Mawu ƒe Dziɖuɖu
The first humans rejected God as their Ruler
Biblia ɖee fia be mawudɔla dzeaglã aɖe si wova yɔ emegbe be Satana Abosam, tso ɖe Mawu ŋu be medze aɖu dzi o.
The Bible reveals that a rebellious angel, later called Satan the Devil, challenged God’s right to rule.
Eƒe nyaa fia be Mawu ƒe mɔfiame kple dziɖuɖu manɔmee la, amegbetɔwo akpɔ dzidzɔ wu.
He implied that humans would be happier without God’s direction and rulership.
Nublanuitɔe la, mía dzila gbãtɔwo, Adam kple Xawa, dze Satana yome eye wodze aglã ɖe Mawu ŋu. 1 Mose 3:1-6; Nyaɖeɖefia 12:9.
Sadly, our first parents, Adam and Eve, followed Satan’s course and rebelled against God.​ Genesis 3:1-6; Revelation 12:9.
Esi Adam kple Xawa gbe be Mawu nagaɖu yewo dzi o ta la, wobu Paradiso-bɔ si nye wo nɔƒe kple mɔnukpɔkpɔ si su wo si be woanɔ agbe tegbee le lãmesẽ blibo me.
Because Adam and Eve rejected God as their Ruler, they lost their Paradise home and the hope of living forever in perfect health.
(1 Mose 3:17-19) Woƒe nyametsotsoa gblẽ nu le vi siwo wova dzi emegbe la hã ŋu.
(Genesis 3:17-19) Their decision also affected the children they eventually had.
Biblia gblɔ be esi Adam wɔ nu vɔ̃ ta la, "nu vɔ̃ va xexea me, eye to nu vɔ̃ me ku la va. "
The Bible says that because Adam sinned, "sin entered into the world and death through sin. "
Eyae nye be: "Amegbetɔ ɖua fia ɖe amegbetɔ dzi hena eƒe gbegblẽ. "
(Romans 5:12) Sin led to another tragic result: "Man has dominated man to his harm. "
(Nyagblɔla 8:9) Le nyaa nu la, ne amegbetɔ le nɔvia dzi ɖum la, kuxiwo koe ado gã ɖe edzi.
(Ecclesiastes 8:9) In other words, when humans rule themselves, problems are bound to come.
AMEGBETƆWO ƑE DZIÐUÐUWO VA DO
HUMAN RULERSHIP APPEARS
Nimrod tsitre ɖi dadatɔe.
Nimrod standing with an arrogant pose.
Xɔtulawo le dɔ wɔm le emegbe ɖaa.
In the background, people are constructing a building.
Nimrod dze aglã ɖe Yehowa ŋu
Nimrod rebelled against Jehovah
Amegbetɔ gbãtɔ si ɖu dzi le anyigba dzi si ŋu Biblia ƒo nu tsoe nye Nimrod.
The first human ruler mentioned in the Bible was Nimrod.
Eye edze aglã ɖe Yehowa ƒe dziɖuɖu ŋu.
And he rebelled against Jehovah’s rulership.
Tso Nimrod ŋɔli la, amegbetɔ dziɖula siwo nye ŋusẽtɔwo zã woƒe ŋusẽ le mɔ gbegblẽwo nu.
Ever since Nimrod’s day, powerful men have abused their positions of authority.
Ƒe 3,000 ye nye esi va yi la, Fia Salomo gblɔ be: "Mekpɔ ame siwo tem wole ɖe anyi la ƒe aɖatsiwo, ke akɔfala aɖeke meli na wo o.
Some 3,000 years ago, King Solomon wrote: "I saw the tears of the oppressed, and there was no one to comfort them.
Ŋusẽ le ame siwo te wo ɖe anyi la si. " Nyagblɔla 4:1.
And their oppressors had the power. "​ Ecclesiastes 4:1.
Nenema koe nuwo le egbea hã.
Things are no different today.
Le ƒe 2009 me la, Dukɔ Ƒoƒuawo ƒe agbalẽ aɖe gblɔ be, eva le dzedzem ƒãa be nu si gbɔ amegbetɔwo ƒe "kuxi akpa gãtɔ tso dometɔ aɖee nye amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo. "
In 2009, a United Nations publication said that bad rulership is increasingly being viewed as "one of the root causes of all evil within our societies. "
MAWU AÐE AFƆ KPUIE!
TIME FOR ACTION!
Xexea hiã na dziɖula kple dziɖuɖu siwo nyo wu.
The world needs better rulers and a better form of government.
Eye ema ƒe ŋugbee mía Wɔla la do!
And that is what our Creator has promised!

Even the best human governments have failed to solve mankind’s serious problems
Mawu ɖo Fiaɖuƒe, alo dziɖuɖu aɖe anyi si ava xɔ ɖe amegbetɔwo ƒe dziɖuɖuwo katã teƒe, eye "eya ɖeɖe anɔ anyi tegbee. "
God has set up a Kingdom, or government, that will replace all human rule, and "it alone will stand forever. "
(Daniel 2:44) Fiaɖuƒe siae ame miliɔn geɖe doa gbe ɖa biana.
(Daniel 2:44) This is the Kingdom for which millions have been praying.
(Mateo 6:9, 10) Gake menye Mawu ŋutɔe anye fiaɖuƒe ma ƒe fia o, ke boŋ etia ame aɖe si nye amegbetɔ kpɔ be wòaɖu dzi.
(Matthew 6:9, 10) But God will not rule this government himself. Instead, he has appointed someone who lived as a human to be the Ruler.
Ame kae Mawu tia?
Whom has God chosen?
Ame Kae Nye Mawu Fiaɖuƒea Ƒe Fia?
Who Is the King of God’s Kingdom?
Mawu na Biblia ŋlɔla geɖe ƒo nu tso Ame si ava nye Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ƒe Fia la ŋu tsitotsito.
God had several Bible writers record details identifying the One who would become the King of God’s Kingdom.
Dziɖula sia
This Ruler would be
Anye ame si Mawu tia.
Chosen by God.
"Nye ŋutɔ meɖo nye fia . . . ne matsɔ dukɔwo ana wò wòanye wò domenyinu, kple anyigba ƒe seƒewo ana wò wòazu tɔwò. "
"I myself have installed my king . . .
Psalmo 2:6, 8.
I will give nations as your inheritance and the ends of the earth as your possession. "​ Psalm 2:6, 8.
Anyi Fia David dome.
An heir of King David.
"Wodzi vi na mí, wona ŋutsuvi mí . . .
"A child has been born to us, a son has been given to us . . .
Eƒe dziɖuɖu akeke ta, eye seɖoƒe manɔe na ŋutifafa le David ƒe fiazikpui dzi kple eƒe fiaɖuƒe la me o, ne wòali kee. " Yesaya 9:6, 7.
To the increase of his rulership and to peace, there will be no end, on the throne of David and on his kingdom in order to establish it firmly. "​ Isaiah 9:6, 7.
Woadzii le Betlehem.
Born in Bethlehem.
"Oo wò, Betlehem . . . , mewòe ame si anye dziɖula . . . ado tso . . .
"O Bethlehem . . . , from you will come out for me the one to be ruler . . .
Eƒe gãnyenye ade anyigba ƒe mlɔenu ke. " Mika 5:2, 4.
His greatness will reach the ends of the earth. "​ Micah 5:2, 4.
Amewo agbee eye woawui.
Rejected by men and executed.
"Wodo vloe, eye míebui ɖe naneke me o. . . .
"He was despised, and we held him as of no account. . . .
Míaƒe dzidada tae woƒo nu ɖee ɖo; wogbãe gudugudu le míaƒe vodadawo ta. " Yesaya 53:3, 5.
He was pierced for our transgression; he was crushed for our errors. "​ Isaiah 53:3, 5.
Woafɔe tso ame kukuwo dome eye woadoe ɖe dzi.
Raised from the dead and glorified.
"Màgblẽm ɖe Tsiẽƒe o.
"You will not leave me in the Grave.
Màna wò nuteƒewɔla la nakpɔ yɔdo o. . . .
You will not allow your loyal one to see the pit. . . .
Vivisese le wò ɖusime tegbee. " Psalmo 16:10, 11.
There is happiness at your right hand forever. "​ Psalm 16:10, 11.
Nu Si Tae Yesu Kristo Ye Dze Wu
Jesus Christ Ideally Qualified
Le amegbetɔwo ƒe ŋutinya katã me la, ame ɖeka kolia dzi koe nya siawo va eme ɖo, eye ame mae nye Yesu Kristo.
In all human history, only one person has fit the description of an ideal Ruler; that person is Jesus Christ.
Le nyateƒe me la, mawudɔla aɖe gblɔ na Yesu nɔ Maria be: "Mawu atsɔ fofoa David ƒe fiazikpui la anɛ, . . . eye nuwuwu manɔe na eƒe Fiaɖuƒe la o. " Luka 1:31-33.
In fact, an angel had told Mary, Jesus’ mother: "God will give him the throne of David his father, . . . and there will be no end to his Kingdom. "​ Luke 1:31-33.
Yesu meva zu dziɖula le anyigba dzi kpɔ o.
Jesus never became a ruler on earth.
Ke boŋ anye Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ƒe Fia aɖu amegbetɔwo dzi tso dziƒo.
Rather, he is to rule mankind from heaven as King of God’s Kingdom.
Nu kae na wònye Dziɖula si dze?
What makes him an ideal Ruler?
De ŋugble le nu siwo Yesu wɔ esime wònɔ anyigba dzi ŋu kpɔ.
Consider what Jesus did while on earth.
Yesu tsɔ ɖe le eme na amewo.
Jesus cared for people.
Yesu kpe ɖe ŋutsuwo kple nyɔnuwo, ɖeviwo kple ametsitsiwo ŋu, metsɔ le afi si wotso alo ɖoƒe si le wo si me o.
Jesus helped men and women, young and old, regardless of their background or status.
(Mateo 9:36; Marko 10:16) Esi kpodɔléla aɖe ɖe kuku nɛ be: "Ne èlɔ̃ ko la, àte ŋu ana ŋutinye nakɔ " la, eƒe nu wɔ nublanui na Yesu eye wòda dɔ nɛ. Marko 1:40-42.
(Matthew 9:36; Mark 10:16) When a leper pleaded: "If you just want to, you can make me clean, " Jesus was moved with pity and cured him.​ Mark 1:40-42.
Yesu fia ale si míawɔ adze Mawu ŋu la mí.
Jesus taught us how to please God.
Egblɔ be: "Miate ŋu anye Mawu kple Kesinɔnuwo siaa ƒe kluviwo o. "
He said: "You cannot slave for God and for Riches. "
Eyi edzi gblɔ be míawɔ nu ɖe amewo ŋu abe ale si míadi be woawɔe ɖe mía ŋu ene. Mɔfiame siae wova yɔna emegbe be Sikasedede la.
He also said that we must treat others as we would like others to treat us​ a principle that has come to be called the Golden Rule.
Ena míenya hã be menye nu siwo míewɔ ɖeɖe koe le vevie na Mawu o, ke nu siwo ŋu míebuna kple ale si míesena le mía ɖokuiwo me hã le vevie nɛ.
In addition, he showed that God is interested not only in what we do but also in how we think and feel.
Eya ta ne míedi be míadze Mawu ŋu la, ke ele be míalé ŋku ɖe ale si míesena le mía ɖokui me ŋu.
So to please God, we must control what we feel in our heart.
(Mateo 5:28; 6:24; 7:12) Yesu te gbe ɖe edzi be hafi míakpɔ dzidzɔ ŋutɔŋutɔ la, ele be míasrɔ̃ nu si Mawu di tso mía si eye míawɔe. Luka 11:28.
(Matthew 5:28; 6:24; 7:12) Jesus emphasized that for us to be truly happy, we must learn what God wants us to do and then do it.​ Luke 11:28.
Yesu fia nu tso nu si lɔlɔ̃ fia ŋu.
Jesus taught what it means to love.
Yesu ƒe nyawo kple nuwɔnawo wɔ dɔ ɖe eƒe nyaselawo dzi vevie.
Jesus’ words and actions were powerful and touched his listeners’ hearts.
"Amehawo ƒe nu ku le eƒe nufiafia la ta, elabena efia nu wo abe ame si si ŋusẽ le ene. "
"The crowds were astounded at his way of teaching, for he was teaching them as a person having authority. "
(Mateo 7:28, 29) Efia wo be: ‘Woalɔ̃ woƒe futɔwo.’
(Matthew 7:28, 29) He taught them: "Love your enemies. "
Edo gbe ɖa ɖe ame siwo nɔ megbe na eƒe ku gɔ̃ hã ta be: "Fofo, tsɔe ke wo, elabena womenya nu si wɔm wole o. " Mateo 5:44; Luka 23:34.
He even prayed in behalf of some of those who were responsible for his death: "Father, forgive them, for they do not know what they are doing. "​ Matthew 5:44; Luke 23:34.
Yesu ame si kpena ɖe ame ŋu eye wònyoa dɔme ye dze bliboe aɖu xexea dzi.
Jesus is perfectly qualified to be an effective world Ruler who is helpful and kind.
Gake ɣekaɣie wòadze dziɖuɖu gɔme?
But when does he begin to rule?
Ɣekaɣie Mawu Fiaɖuƒea Aɖu Anyigba La Dzi?
When Will God’s Kingdom Rule the Earth?
Yesu yomedzela wɔnuteƒeawo dometɔ aɖewo di be yewoanya ɣeyiɣi si me Mawu Fiaɖuƒea adze dziɖuɖu gɔme.
Some of Jesus’ faithful followers wanted to know when God’s Kingdom would begin ruling.
Yesu na wonya be womate ŋu anya ɣeyiɣi si tututu Fiaɖuƒea aɖu anyigbaa dzi o.
Jesus answered their question by saying that they would not know exactly when it would rule over the earth.
(Dɔwɔwɔwo 1:6, 7) Gake do ŋgɔ la, egblɔ na eyomedzelawo be ne wokpɔ nanewo le dzɔdzɔm le ɣeyiɣi ɖeka me la, ekema ‘woadze sii be Mawu Fiaɖuƒe la gogo,’ eye ɣeyiɣia de be wòaɖu xexea dzi.

(Acts 1:6, 7) But, earlier, he had told them that when his followers saw a certain group of events happening all at once, they would "know that the Kingdom of God [was] near " and that the time for it to rule the world had come.​ Luke 21:31.
Luka 21:31. NU KAWOE YESU GBLƆ BE WOADZƆ?
WHAT EVENTS DID JESUS SAY WOULD HAPPEN?
Yesu gblɔ be: "Dukɔ atso ɖe dukɔ ŋu, eye fiaɖuƒe ɖe fiaɖuƒe ŋu.
Jesus said: "Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.
Anyigba aʋuʋu ŋɔdzitɔe le teƒeteƒewo, eye dɔwuame kple dɔvɔ̃wo ava teƒeteƒewo. "
There will be great earthquakes, and in one place after another food shortages and pestilences. "
(Luka 21:10, 11) Abe asibidɛnufliwo ene la, nudzɔdzɔ siawo katã nye kpeɖodzi si ŋu ɖikeke mele o.
(Luke 21:10, 11) Like the lines that form a fingerprint, all these events together form an unmistakable sign.
Eye abe ale si asibidɛnufliwo nana wonyaa ame si tututu tɔ asibidɛnufliawo nye ene la, nu siawo siwo katã anɔ dzɔdzɔm le ɣeyiɣi ɖeka me la, ana wòadze ƒãa be "Mawu Fiaɖuƒe la gogo. "
And just as a fingerprint identifies a person, these events happening at the same time identify that "the Kingdom of God is near. "
Ðe nudzɔdzɔ siawo le eme vam le ɣeyiɣi ɖeka me le xexea me godooa?
Have such events occurred together and become visible on a worldwide scale?
Bu kpeɖodziawo ŋu kpɔ.
Consider the evidence.
AƲAWƆWƆWO
WARS
Aʋawɔyameʋu kple aʋawɔnu bubuwo.
Fighter jets, a war tank, and missiles.
Le ƒe 1914 mea, aʋa aɖe si medzɔ kpɔ le amegbetɔwo ƒe ŋutinya me o la, fe ati!
In 1914, war broke out on a scale never seen before in all human history!
Zi geɖe la, ŋutinyaŋlɔlawo ƒoa nu tso ƒe 1914 ŋu be enye ƒe si me nuwo trɔ kpata le le ŋutinya me, elabe ɣemaɣie xexemeʋa gbãtɔ dzɔ.
Historians often refer to the year 1914 as a turning point in history because it is when the first-ever world war began.
Aʋa sia na woto aʋawɔʋuwo, yameʋu siwo wua bɔmb, tu siwo dana le wo ɖokui si, aɖiya wuamewo kple nu bubu siwo wua ame la vɛ.
That war introduced the first large-scale use of tanks, aerial bombs, machine guns, poisonous gas, and other deadly weapons.
Esia he xexemeʋa evelia, si me woto atɔmikʋawɔnuwo hã vɛ le.
It was followed by the second world war, a war that gave birth to atomic weapons.
Tso ƒe 1914 me dzi la, amegbetɔwo wɔa aʋa le teƒeteƒewo, eye wowu ame miliɔn geɖe le aʋawɔwɔwo me.
Mankind has been fighting wars in one place or another ever since 1914, and those wars have killed millions of people.
ANYIGBAƲUƲUWO
EARTHQUAKES
Anyigbaʋuʋu na xɔ aɖewo le gbagbam.
An earthquake causing buildings to crack.
Britannica Academic ka nya ta be ƒe sia ƒe la, anyigbaʋuʋu gã 100 siwo "gblẽa nu vevie " ye dzɔna.
Every year there are about 100 earthquakes that are large enough to cause "substantial damage, " says Britannica Academic.
Numekuha aɖe (United States Geological Survey) si le Amerika la ka nya ta be "le akɔntabubu siwo li xoxoxo (tso abe ƒe 1900 ene) ɖee fia be anyigbaʋuʋu gã 16 ye adzɔ ƒe sia ƒe. "
And the United States Geological Survey reports that "according to long-term records (since about 1900), we expect about 16 major earthquakes in any given year. "

Togbɔ be ame aɖewo xɔe se be anyigbaʋuʋuwo dzi ɖe edzi le esi wòle bɔbɔe be woade dzesii fifia wu ta hã la, nya lae nye be, anyigbaʋuʋu gã siwo le dzɔdzɔm le xexea me godoo na ame gbogbo siwo mele xexlẽ me o le fu kpem eye bubuwo ƒe agbe tsi eme.

Though some might attribute the apparent increase in earthquakes to better detection, the fact is that great earthquakes around the world are causing suffering and loss of life on an unprecedented scale.
DƆWUAMEWO
FOOD SHORTAGES
Fli aɖe si fia ale si nuɖuɖu le vevem.
A line graph showing a decrease in grain production.

Zi geɖe la, aʋawɔwɔ, nu fitifiti wɔwɔ, ganyawo ƒe sesẽ, agbledemɔnuwo ŋu dɔ mawɔmawɔ nyuie kple ɖoɖo nyui mawɔmawɔ ɖe yame ƒe tɔtrɔ kpata abe kuɖiɖi kple tsidzadza gãwo ene ŋu ye nana nuɖuɖu vena le xexea me godoo.
Food shortages occur worldwide because of war, corruption, economic collapse, poor management of agriculture, or lack of planning for extreme weather.
Xexeame ƒe Nuɖunyawo Gbɔkpɔha ƒe "Ƒe 2018 Nyatakaka " gblɔ be: "Le xexea me godoo la, ame miliɔn 821 mekpɔa nu ɖuna wòsua wo o, eye dɔ wua wo dometɔ miliɔn 124 ɖia tsi ɖe wo ŋu. "
The World Food Programme’s "2018 Year in Review " states: "Across the world, 821 million people are going hungry​ 124 million acutely so. "
Nunyuimakpɔɖu na ɖevi miliɔn etɔ̃ kple edzivɔ kuna ƒe sia ƒe.
Malnutrition has contributed to the death of about 3.1 million children each year.
Ema gbɔe ɖevi siwo ku le xexea me godoo la ƒe alafa memama 45 tso le ƒe 2011 me.
In the year 2011, this was the cause of about 45 percent of all child deaths worldwide.
DƆLÉLEWO KPLE DƆ VƆ̃WO
DISEASES AND EPIDEMICS
Dɔlékuiwo ƒe dzesi.
Symbols of biochemical hazards and bacteria.
Xexea Me Lãmesẽ Habɔbɔ aɖe gblɔ le agbalẽ aɖe me be: "Dɔvɔ̃woe nye nu si ɖe dzesi wu le ƒe alafa 21 lia me.
A World Health Organization publication states: "The 21st century has already been marked by major epidemics.
Dɔléle siwo nɔ anyi abe mĩŋɔŋɔ kple xeɖeɖe, dɔvɔ̃ kple asrã (yellow fever) gatrɔ gbɔ, eye dɔléle yeyewo abe SARS, dzamezã, MERS, Ebola kple Zika va do ta ɖa. "
Old diseases​ cholera, plague and yellow fever ​have returned, and new ones have emerged​ SARS, pandemic influenza, MERS, Ebola and Zika. "
Togbɔ be dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo kple ɖɔktawo srɔ̃ nu geɖe tso dɔlélewo ŋu hã la, womete ŋu kpɔ ta na dɔlélewo katã o.
Even though scientists and doctors have learned much about sicknesses, they have not been able to find a cure for all diseases.
XEXEA ME KATÃ ƑE GBEƑÃÐEÐEDƆ
A WORLDWIDE PREACHING WORK
Anyigba ƒe nɔnɔmetata si le xlã ƒom eye Biblia le ʋuʋu ɖi le exa.
The earth with an arrow encircling it and an open Bible next to it.
Yesu tɔ asi dzesia ƒe akpa bubu dzi esi wògblɔe ɖi be: "Woaɖe gbeƒã Fiaɖuƒe ŋuti nya nyui sia le anyigba blibo la katã dzi be wòanye ɖaseɖiɖi na dukɔwo katã, eye ekema nuwuwu la ava. "
Jesus pointed out another part of the sign when he foretold: "This good news of the Kingdom will be preached in all the inhabited earth for a witness to all the nations, and then the end will come. "
(Mateo 24:14) Togbɔ be xexea le kuxi sesẽwo me tom hã, ame siwo wu miliɔn enyi siwo tso dukɔwo katã me la le gbeƒã ɖem Mawu Fiaɖuƒe ŋuti nya nyuia le gbegbɔgblɔ siwo wu 1,000 me le dukɔ 240 me.
(Matthew 24:14) While the world is experiencing terrible problems, over eight million people from all nations are declaring the good news of God’s Kingdom in 240 lands and in over 1,000 languages.
Esia medzɔ le ŋutinya me kpɔ gbeɖe o.
This has never happened before in human history.
NU KAE DZESIA FIA NA MÍ?
WHAT DOES THE SIGN MEAN FOR US?
Nu vovovo siwo Yesu gblɔ be woadzɔ la le eme vam egbea.
The events making up the sign Jesus gave are happening today.
Nu ka tae wòle be míatsɔ ɖe le esia me?
Why should we be interested in that fact?
Elabe Yesu gblɔ be: "Ne miekpɔ nu siawo le dzɔdzɔm la, midze sii be Mawu Fiaɖuƒe la gogo. " Luka 21:31.
Because Jesus said: "When you see these things happening, know that the Kingdom of God is near. "​ Luke 21:31.

Jesus sitting on a throne in heaven, as King, above an earthly paradise.

Soon, the Kingdom will ensure that God’s will is done on earth
Dzesi si ŋu Yesu ƒo nu tsoe kple Biblia ƒe akɔntabubuwo kpe ɖe mía ŋu míese egɔme be Mawu ɖo eƒe Fiaɖuƒea anyi le dziƒo le ƒe 1914 me.
The sign that Jesus gave, along with Bible chronology, helps us understand that God set up his Kingdom in heaven in the year 1914.
Ɣemaɣie wòɖo Via, Yesu Kristo, wòzu Fia.

(Psalmo 2:2, 4, 6-9) Eteƒe madidi o Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ava ɖu anyigba la dzi, aɖe dziɖuɖu siwo katã tsitre ɖe Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ŋu la ɖa, eye wòana anyigbaa nazu Paradiso be amewo nanɔ edzi tegbee.
(Psalm 2:2, 4, 6-9) Soon, God’s Kingdom will rule the earth, and it will remove all rival rulerships and make the earth a paradise for humans to live in forever.
Eteƒe madidi o, kpɔɖeŋugbedodoɖa si Yesu fia, si me nya aɖewo gblɔ be: "Wò Fiaɖuƒe nava.
Shortly, the words of the model prayer that Jesus taught will be fulfilled: "Let your Kingdom come.
Wò lɔlɔ̃nu nava eme le anyigba dzi abe ale si wòle le dziƒo ene " la ava eme.
Let your will take place, as in heaven, also on earth. "

(Matthew 6:10) What, though, has the Kingdom been doing since it took power in 1914?
Eye nu kawoe míakpɔ mɔ na ne Fiaɖuƒea va le amegbetɔwo dzi ɖum bliboe?
And what can we look forward to when the Kingdom takes complete rulership of mankind?
Nu Kae Mawu Fiaɖuƒea Awɔ?
What Will God’s Kingdom Accomplish?
Yesu fia eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo be woado gbe ɖa abia be Fiaɖuƒea nava.
Jesus taught his disciples to pray for the Kingdom to come.
Enya be Mawu medi be nu gbegblẽ siawo nanɔ dzɔdzɔm le anyigba dzi o, eye enyae be Mawu Fiaɖuƒea koe nye dziɖuɖu si ate ŋu ava ɖɔ kuxi siawo ɖo.
He knew that the terrible things happening on the earth are not what God wants and that God’s Kingdom is the only government that can fix these problems.
Nu kae Mawu Fiaɖuƒea awɔ?
What will God’s Kingdom accomplish?
NU SI MAWU FIAÐUƑEA WƆ XOXO
WHAT GOD’S KINGDOM HAS ALREADY DONE
Le nyati si do ŋgɔ me la, míeƒo nu tso dzesi si Yesu na la ŋu.
In the preceding article, we considered the sign Jesus gave.
Dzesi ma nye kpeɖodzi siwo na míenya ɣeyiɣi si me woɖo Mawu Fiaɖuƒea anyi le dziƒo eye be Yesu Kristoe nye eƒe Fia.
That sign provides visible proof that God’s Kingdom has been established in heaven with Jesus Christ as King.
Biblia gblɔ be ne Yesu dze dziɖuɖu gɔme la, anya Satana kple eƒe gbɔgbɔ vɔ̃wo ɖa le dziƒo.
The Bible says that on taking Kingdom power, Jesus would expel Satan and his demons from heaven.
Eye fifia anyigba la dzi koe woakpɔ ŋusẽ ɖo, eye esia nye susu aɖe si tae nuwo gblẽ ɖe edzi tso ƒe 1914 me. Nyaɖeɖefia 12:7, 9.
Their activity is now restricted to the earth, which is one of the reasons why things have become so bad since the year 1914.​ Revelation 12:7, 9.
Togbɔ be xexea ƒe nɔnɔme le fievo dom ɖe edzi hã la, Yesu, si nye Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ƒe Fia la wɔ nu siwo ɖe vi na anyigbadzinɔlawo katã.
Despite worsening world conditions, Jesus, as King of God’s Kingdom, has done things to help people around the earth.
Esi wole Biblia fiam amewo le xexea me godoo abe ale si Yesu gblɔe ene ta la, ame geɖe srɔ̃ ale si woawɔ ɖe Biblia ƒe mɔfiamewo dzi le woƒe agbe me gbe sia gbe.
Thanks to the worldwide Bible educational work that Jesus foretold, many are learning and applying Bible principles in their daily life.
(Yesaya 2:2-4) Ame miliɔn geɖe srɔ̃ ale si woada asɔ le dɔwɔnyawo me, ana woƒe ƒomegbenɔnɔ nanyo ɖe edzi, eye woase vivi na nu siwo le wo si evɔ womazu kluvi na nu mawo o.
(Isaiah 2:2-4) Millions have learned to have a balanced view of work, to improve their family life, and to enjoy material things without becoming slaves to them.
Ame siawo le nu siwo aɖe vi na wo la srɔ̃m, eye wova le ame siwo tɔgbi adze anye Mawu Fiaɖuƒe teviwo la zum.
These people are learning to benefit themselves now and are becoming the kind of people God wants as subjects of his Kingdom.

Nu kae nye nu nyuitɔ si wòle be nàwɔ?
What would be the wise thing to do?
Àɖo ta teƒe aɖe si le dedie la godoo.
Head for a safe place, certainly.

In a sense, all of us are living in the path of a devastating "storm, " which Jesus called a "great tribulation. "

(Matthew 24:21) We cannot simply get out of the path of that tribulation.
Gake míate ŋu awɔ nane atsɔ akpɔ mía ɖokuiwo ta.
But we can do something to protect ourselves.
Nu kae míawɔ?
What is that?
Le Yesu Kristo ƒe Todzimawunyaa me la, ena mɔfiame sia be: "Miyi edzi mianɔ Fiaɖuƒe la kple Mawu ƒe dzɔdzɔenyenye dim gbã. "
In his Sermon on the Mount, Jesus Christ gave this direction: "Keep on, then, seeking first [God’s] Kingdom and his righteousness. "
(Mateo 6:33) Aleke míawɔ esiae?

Di Mawu Fiaɖuƒea gbã.
Seek first the Kingdom of God.
Esia fia be míatsɔ Mawu Fiaɖuƒea aɖo nɔƒe gbãtɔ wu nu bubu ɖe sia ɖe.
This means that we should view God’s Kingdom as being more important than anything else.
(Mateo 6:25, 32, 33) Nu ka tae wòle be míawɔe nenema?
(Matthew 6:25, 32, 33) Why should we view it that way?
Elabena amegbetɔwo mate ŋu akpɔ ameƒomea ƒe kuxiwo gbɔ o.
Because humans are just not able to solve mankind’s problems.
Mawu Fiaɖuƒea koe ate ŋu awɔ dɔ sia ade goe.
Only God’s Kingdom can accomplish that difficult job.
Di Mawu ƒe dzɔdzɔenyenye.
Seek his righteousness.
Ele be míawɔ míatɔ sinua awɔ ɖe Mawu ƒe se kple mɔfiame dzɔdzɔeawo dzi.
We should try our best to live by God’s righteous laws and principles.
Nu ka tae?
Why?
Elabena ne míawo ŋutɔwo míedi be míatso nya me le nyui kple vɔ̃ ŋu la, nu gbegblẽwo koe ado tso eme.
Because if we decide for ourselves what is right and what is wrong, the results will be bad.
(Lododowo 16:25) Azɔ hã, ne míewɔ ɖe Mawu ƒe mɔfiamewo dzi la, menye ɖeko míaƒe nu adze Mawu ŋu o, ke boŋ aɖe vi na míawo ŋutɔwo hã. Yesaya 48:17, 18.
(Proverbs 16:25) On the other hand, if we live by God’s standards, we not only please God but also benefit ourselves.​ Isaiah 48:17, 18.
Miyi edzi mianɔ Fiaɖuƒe la kple Mawu ƒe dzɔdzɔenyenye dim gbã.
Keep on seeking first God’s Kingdom and his righteousness.
Yesu xlɔ̃ nu be ame aɖewo atra mɔ asusui be ne yewoƒo ga gbogbo aɖewo nu ƒu la, ana yewoanɔ dedie.
Jesus warned that some might get sidetracked, thinking they can find security in making as much money as possible.
Ame bubuwo aɖe mɔ dzimaɖitsitsi ɖe agbe ŋu navu tsyɔ wo dzi ale gbegbe be womakpɔ ɣeyiɣi aɖeke kura atsɔ adi Mawu Fiaɖuƒea o. Mateo 6:19-21, 25-32.
Others may let anxieties of life overwhelm them to the point that they have no time to seek God’s Kingdom.​ Matthew 6:19-21, 25-32.
Ke hã, Yesu do ŋugbe be woakpɔ ame siwo le Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ƒe akpa dzi la ƒe nuhiahiãwo gbɔ na wo fifia, eye woase vivi na yayra siwo ava le etsɔme la tegbee.
However, Jesus promised that those who support God’s Kingdom will have what they need now and enjoy endless blessings in the future.​ Matthew 6:33.
Mateo 6:33. Togbɔ be Yesu ƒe nusrɔ̃la siwo nɔ agbe le ƒe alafa gbãtɔ me di Mawu Fiaɖuƒea kple Mawu ƒe dzɔdzɔenyenye gbã hã la, womekpɔ eteƒe woɖe vevesese kple fukpekpewo katã ɖa o.
Even though Jesus’ disciples in the first century were seeking first God’s Kingdom and his righteousness, they did not see the end of all pain and suffering in their lifetime.
Gake wokpɔ wo ta.
But they were protected.
Le mɔ ka nu?
How?
Esi wonɔ agbe ɖe Mawu ƒe nudidi dzɔdzɔewo nu ta la, womekpe fu siwo ame siwo menɔa agbe ɖe Mawu ƒe sewo nu o la kpe o.
They lived by God’s righteous standards, and that protected them from the difficulties suffered by those who ignored what God said.
Xɔse sẽŋu si nɔ wo si be Fiaɖuƒea ava la kpe ɖe wo ŋu wonɔ te ɖe nɔnɔme sesẽwo nu.
Their strong faith that the Kingdom would come helped them to face even the severest of problems.
Eye Mawu na "ŋusẽ si gbɔ dzɔdzɔmetɔ ŋu " la wo be wotsɔ nɔ te ɖe kuxiawo nu. 2 Korintotɔwo 4:7-9.
And God gave them "the power beyond what is normal " so that they could cope.​ 2 Corinthians 4:7-9.

(Kolosetɔwo 1:23) Ðe ame aɖewo gale dɔ ma wɔm egbea?

Yes!

So they do all they can to live by Jesus’ words: "This good news of the Kingdom will be preached in all the inhabited earth for a witness to all the nations, and then the end will come. "​ Matthew 24:14.

Wodea ha kple ame siwo de Fiaɖuƒea dzi
Associate with those who support the Kingdom
Ŋutsua le gbe dom ɖa hafi axlẽ Biblia.
The man is praying before reading the Bible.
Ðee fia Mawu be yedi be yeasubɔe
Show God that you want to serve him
Wò hã àte ŋu awɔe nenema.
You can do the same.
Ne èdi Mawu Fiaɖuƒea kple eƒe dzɔdzɔenyenye gbã la, àɖe dzi ɖi fifia, àva kpɔ ŋutifafa eye ànɔ dedie le etsɔme.
By seeking first God’s Kingdom and his righteousness, you will find refuge and protection now and enjoy lasting peace and security in the future.
Mawu Fiaɖuƒe La Nu Kae Wònye?
God’s Kingdom​ What Is It?
Ŋutsu aɖe nɔ anyi ɖe zikpui dzi le Biblia xlẽm le dɔwɔƒe aɖe ŋgɔ.
A man reading a Bible while sitting on a bench in front of a government building.
Ame geɖe doa gbe ɖa be Mawu Fiaɖuƒea nava, gake ɖe nèbia ɖokuiwò be nu kae nye Mawu Fiaɖuƒea, eye dɔ kae wòava wɔ kpɔa?
Many people pray for God’s Kingdom to come, but have you ever wondered what God’s Kingdom is and what it will do?
BU NYA SI BIBLIA GBLƆ ŊU KPƆ:
CONSIDER WHAT THE BIBLE SAYS:
Nu kae nye Mawu Fiaɖuƒe la?
What is God’s Kingdom?
Enye dziɖuɖu aɖe si le dziƒo eye eƒe Fiae nye Yesu Kristo. Yesaya 9:6, 7; Mateo 5:3; Luka 1:31-33.
It is a heavenly government ruled by Jesus Christ as King.​ Isaiah 9:6, 7; Matthew 5:3; Luke 1:31-33.
Nu kawoe Mawu Fiaɖuƒea awɔ?
What will God’s Kingdom accomplish?
Ahe nu vɔ̃ɖi wɔwɔwo katã ava nuwuwui eye wòana ame siwo le anyigba dzi la nakpɔ ŋutifafa mavɔ. Daniel 2:44; Mateo 6:10.
It will put an end to all bad things and bring lasting peace to people on earth.​ Daniel 2:44; Matthew 6:10.
Nu kae wòfia be woadi Fiaɖuƒea gbã?
What does it mean to seek first the Kingdom?
Efia be ame nade Mawu Fiaɖuƒea dzi, eye wòaka ɖe edzi bliboe be Fiaɖuƒe mae ana Mawu ƒe lɔlɔ̃nu nava eme le anyigba dzi. Mateo 6:33; 13:44.
It means to support God’s Kingdom and to trust that only it will make conditions on earth the way God wants them to be.​ Matthew 6:33; 13:44.
Ne Srɔ̃wò Wɔ Ahasi
When a Spouse Is Unfaithful
"Ðeko medi be maku esi srɔ̃nye gblɔ nam be yele asi ɖem le ŋunye esi wòkpɔ ɖetugbui aɖe ta.
"I wanted to die when my husband said that he was leaving me for a younger woman.
Enye nu madzɔmadzɔ si wòwɔ ɖe ŋunye vevietɔ ne meɖo ŋku nu siwo gbegbe metsɔ sa vɔ ɖe eta dzi. " Maria, Spain.
It all seemed so unfair, especially when I remembered the sacrifices I had made for him. "​ Maria, Spain.
"Esi srɔ̃nye gbem le vome la, ɖeko wòwɔ abe nanee ku le menye ene.
"When my wife suddenly left me, it seemed that something died inside me.
Nu siwo míenɔ mɔ kpɔm na kple nu siwo míeɖo be míawɔ la katã dome gblẽ.
Our dreams, our hopes, and our plans had been destroyed.
Ɣeaɖewoɣia nye nuxaxaa dzi kana ɖena vie, gake kasia ko vevesesea gatrɔ va. " Bill, Spain.
There were days when I thought I was free from anxiety, only to find myself back in the depths of despair. "​ Bill, Spain.
AME ƒe dzi gbãna ne srɔ̃a wɔ ahasi.
MARITAL unfaithfulness is devastating.
Le nyateƒe me la, srɔ̃tɔ aɖewo tea ŋu tsɔna kena wo srɔ̃ si dze agɔ si trɔ dzi me la, eye wo dome gavivina.
True, some mates have found that they can forgive a repentant spouse and rebuild their relationship.
Ne srɔ̃tɔawo lɔ̃ be yewoanɔ yewo nɔewo gbɔ alo agbe yewo nɔewo o, ame si dzi wodze agɔa le la sea veve eteƒe didina.
But whether the marriage survives or not, those who discover that their mate has been unfaithful invariably suffer intense agony.
Aleke ame siawo awɔ anɔ te ɖe vevesesea nu?
How can such ones deal with their fragile emotions?
MAWUNYAKPUKPUI SIWO ATE ŊU AKPE ÐE ŊUWÒ
BIBLE VERSES THAT CAN HELP
Togbɔ be enyea dzigbãnya hã la, Biblia faa akɔ na srɔ̃tɔ si dzi wodze agɔa le.
Despite the heartache, many innocent spouses have found comfort in the Scriptures.
Wova kpɔnɛ be Mawu le yewoƒe nuxaxa kple aɖatsiwo kpɔm eye wòsea veve ɖe yewo nu.
They have learned that God sees their tears and shares their pain.​ Malachi 2:13-16.
Malaki 2:13-16. "Ne metsi dzodzodzoe akpa la, èfaa akɔ nam henana mekpɔa gbɔdzɔe. " Psalmo 94:19.
"When anxieties overwhelmed me, you comforted and soothed me. "​ Psalm 94:19.
Bill gblɔ be: "Esi mexlẽ mawunyakpukpui ma la, mekpɔe le susu me ɖaa be Yehowa le akɔ fam nam abe ale si vifofo si sea veve ɖe via nu wɔnɛ ene. "
"As I read that verse, I imagined Jehovah soothing my pain tenderly, as a compassionate father would, " recalls Bill.
"Èwɔa nuteƒe na ame si wɔa nuteƒe. " Psalmo 18:25.
"With someone loyal you act in loyalty. "​ Psalm 18:25.
Carmen, ame si srɔ̃ mewɔ nuteƒe o ɣleti geɖe gblɔ be: "Srɔ̃nye mewɔ nuteƒe o.
"My husband had not been loyal, " explains Carmen, whose husband had been unfaithful for months.
Gake meka ɖe edzi be Yehowa ya awɔ nuteƒe nam.
"But I could trust in Jehovah’s loyalty.
Mado ŋukpem gbeɖe o. "
He would never let me down. "

"Migatsi dzimaɖi le naneke ŋuti o, ke boŋ le nu sia nu me la, mito gbedodoɖa kple kokoƒoƒo . . . dzi miana Mawu nanya miaƒe dzimedidiwo; eye Mawu ƒe ŋutifafa, si ƒo gɔmesesewo katã ta la, adzɔ miaƒe dziwo . . . ŋu. " Filipitɔwo 4:6, 7.

"Do not be anxious over anything, but in everything by prayer and supplication . . . let your petitions be made known to God; and the peace of God that surpasses all understanding will guard your hearts. "​ Philippians 4:6, 7.
Sasha gblɔ be: "Mexlẽ kpukpui sia zi geɖe.
"I read this text over and over again, " says Sasha.
Esi medo gbe ɖa edziedzi ta la, Mawu na mekpɔ ŋutifafa. "
"As I prayed more and more, God gave me peace in my life. "
Ame siwo katã ƒe nya míegblɔ va yi la se le wo ɖokui me kpɔ be yewoana ta.
All those quoted above felt like giving up at times.
Gake woɖo ŋu ɖe Yehowa Mawu ŋu eye eƒe Nyaa do ŋusẽ wo.
But they trusted in Jehovah God and drew strength from his Word.
Bill gblɔe ale: "Xɔse si nɔ asinye la na taɖodzinu nɔ nye agbe ŋu togbɔ be edze abe nu sia nu dome gblẽ ene hã.
Bill put it this way: "My faith gave meaning to my life when everything else seemed to have collapsed.
Togbɔ be meto ‘bali doblukɔ tsiɖitsiɖi me hã,’ Mawu nɔ kplim. "
Though I walked for a time ‘in the valley of deep shadow,’ God was with me. "​ Psalm 23:4.
Psalmo 23:4.
How Some Have Coped
Nu Kae Akpe Ðe Ŋuwò Nàdo Dzi?
Meditate on comforting scriptures.
De ŋugble le Biblia me nya fakɔnamewo ŋu. Bill gblɔ be: "Mexlẽ Hiob kple Psalmowo ƒe agbalẽawo. Eye mete fli ɖe akpa siwo sɔ ɖe nye nɔnɔmea nu la te.
"I read the book of Job and then the Psalms, " explains Bill, "underlining every passage that seemed to fit my own circumstances.
Meva kpɔe be Biblia ŋlɔla siawo hã to vevesese kple dzimaɖitsitsi siawo tɔgbi me abe nye ke ene. "
I realized that these Bible writers had experienced the kind of pain and anxiety that I was feeling. "
Ðo to hadzidzi siwo faa akɔ na ame.
Find consolation in music.
Carmen gblɔ be: "Ne metsi zãdomadɔlɔ̃e la, meɖoa to hawo.
"When I could not sleep at night, I listened to music, " Carmen remembers.
Esia fa akɔ nam ŋutɔ. "
"This was a great source of comfort. "
Daniel gblɔ be: "Mesrɔ̃ dzita ƒoƒo eye esia kpe ɖe ŋunye megaɖo ɖokuinye me. "
Daniel says: "I learned to play the guitar and found that the harmony needed for the music helped me recover my inner peace and harmony. "
Ƒo nu tso ale si nèle sesem le ɖokuiwò me la ŋu.
Talk about your feelings.
Daniel gblɔ be: "Memam be maƒo nu tso nye seselelãmewo ŋu o.
"I was not used to talking about my feelings, " Daniel says.
Gake xɔlɔ̃ nyui aɖewo le asinye siwo gbɔ meyina ɣesiaɣi míeɖoa dze.
"But I had some good friends, and I reached out to them every day.
Meƒoa nu tso nye vevesesewo ŋu na wo alo ŋlɔa wo ɖe lɛta me na wo.
I unburdened my feelings on them, both in writing and in conversation.
Esia kpe ɖe ŋunye ŋutɔ. "
That really helped. "
Sasha gblɔ be: "Kpekpeɖeŋu si nye ƒomea nam la ɖe vi nam ŋutɔ.
Sasha says: "The help of my family was crucial.
Nɔnye nɔa ŋunye ɣesiaɣi.
My mother was always there for me.
Ne nya aɖe le asinye magblɔ la nɔnye ɖoa tom.
If I wanted to talk, she was there to listen.
Tɔnye hã na mese le ɖokuinye me be mele dedie eye wòkpe ɖe ŋunye megaɖo eme vivivi. "
My father also made me feel secure, and he helped me recover at my own pace. "
Nɔ gbe dom ɖa.
Persist in prayer.
Carmen gblɔ be: "Medoa gbe ɖa edziedzi.
"I prayed constantly, " says Carmen.
Mese le ɖokuinye me be Mawu megblẽm ɖi o, eɖoa tom eye wòkpena ɖe ŋunye.
"I felt that God was near to me, listening to me, and helping me.
Mete ɖe Mawu ŋu le ɣeyiɣi sesẽ ma me. "
Through this terrible time, I drew closer to God. "
Ne Mègadi Be Yeanɔ Agbe O
When You Feel You Cannot Go On
Adriana si tso Brazil gblɔ be: "Seselelãme siawo nu gbe tsotso.
"These feelings were relentless, " admits Adriana, from Brazil.
Eya ta mesusui be ne mewu ɖokuinye la anyo wu. "
"So I concluded that it would be better to end my life. "
ÐE NU te ɖe dziwò vevie kpɔ si na be mègadi be yeanɔ agbe oa?
HAVE YOU ever felt so bad that you no longer wanted to live?
Ekema àse ale si Adriana se le eɖokui me la gɔme.
Then you may understand how Adriana felt.
Nu te ɖe edzi vevie wòlé blanui eye mɔkpɔkpɔ bu ɖee.
She suffered from acute anxiety and felt sad and hopeless.
Adriana yi kɔdzi eye wokpɔe be blanuiléledɔe nɔ fu ɖem nɛ.
Adriana was diagnosed with clinical depression.
Bu Japan ŋutsu aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Kaoru si nɔ edzila tsitsi siwo dze dɔ dzi kpɔm hã ŋu kpɔ.
Consider, too, a Japanese man named Kaoru, who cared for his sickly, aged parents.
Egblɔ be: "Ɣemaɣi la, dɔ te ɖe dzinye vevie le dɔ me.
"At the time, I was overwhelmed by extreme pressure at work, " he explains.
Eteƒe medidi o nuɖuɖu megadzroam o, eye nyemegadɔa alɔ̃ o.
"In time I lost my appetite, and my sleep was terribly disturbed.
Eya ta meva nɔ susum be makpɔ gbɔdzɔe ne meku. "
I came to think how relieved I would be if I could just die. "
Nigeria ŋutsu aɖe si ŋkɔe nye Ojebode gblɔ be: "Meléa blanui ɣesiaɣi ale gbegbe be avi koe metsɔnɛ na, eya ta menɔ mɔnu dim be maɖe nye agbe ɖa. "
A Nigerian man named Ojebode says, "I was always sad to the point of shedding tears, so I looked for a means to end my life. "
Míeda akpe be Ojebode, Kaoru kple Adriana mewu wo ɖokuiwo o.
Thankfully, Ojebode, Kaoru, and Adriana did not take their lives.
Gake ƒe sia ƒe la, ame gbogbo aɖewo wua wo ɖokuiwo.
But every year hundreds of thousands do.
AFI SI NÀKPƆ KPEKPEÐEŊU TSOE
WHERE TO FIND HELP
Ŋutsuwo koŋ ye wua wo ɖokuiwo, elabe ekpea ŋu na wo dometɔ geɖe be woabia kpekpeɖeŋu.
Most people who commit suicide are men, many of whom felt too ashamed to ask for help.
Yesu gblɔ be ame siwo dze dɔ la hiã gbedala.
Jesus said that sick people need a physician.
(Luka 5:31) Eya ta ne èle sesem le ɖokuiwò me alea la, míeɖe kuku megakpe ŋu na wò be nàbia kpekpeɖeŋu o.
(Luke 5:31) So if you have such feelings, please do not be ashamed to seek help.
Ame geɖe siwo blanuiléledɔ le fu ɖem na la kpɔe be esi yewoyi kɔdzi la ena wòka ɖe eme na yewo.
Many people who suffer from depression have found that medical treatment can help them to cope.
Ojebode, Kaoru kple Adriana siaa yi kɔdzi eye esia kpe ɖe wo ŋu wote ŋu le te nɔm ɖe nɔnɔmea nu.
Ojebode, Kaoru, and Adriana all received professional help and now cope much better.
Dɔktawo zãa atikewo alo ƒoa nu na dɔnɔa loo alo zãa mɔnu evea siaa tsɔ daa dɔ na ame si le blanuiléledɔ lém.
Doctors may use medication or talk therapy or both to treat depression.
Ele be ame siwo le dɔ sia lém ƒe ƒometɔwo kple xɔlɔ̃wo nase nu gɔme na wo, agbɔ dzi ɖi na wo eye woalé be na wo.
Those who suffer also need the empathetic support of patient, caring family and friends.
Xɔlɔ̃ nyuitɔ kekeake si ate ŋu anɔ ame sie nye Yehowa Mawu, ame si naa kpekpeɖeŋu nyuitɔ to eƒe Nya Biblia dzi.
The best friend anyone can have is Jehovah God, who provides wonderful help in his Word, the Bible.
ÐE KUXI SIA NU AVA YI KURAA?
IS THERE A PERMANENT SOLUTION?
Zi geɖe la, ehiã be ame siwo le blanuiléledɔ lém la nanɔ atike dzi eteƒe nadidi eye woawɔ asitɔtrɔwo be wòakpe ɖe wo ŋu woanɔ te ɖe enu.
Victims of depression often need prolonged treatment and have to learn how to cope by making adjustments to their lifestyle.
Gake ne dɔ sia le ŋuwò la, àte ŋu anɔ mɔ kpɔm na etsɔme nyui aɖe abe Ojebode ene.
But if you struggle with depression, you can look forward to a bright future, as does Ojebode.
Egblɔ be: "Mele mɔ kpɔm na ɣeyiɣi si me Yesaya 33:24 si gblɔ be ɣeyiɣi aɖe ava si me ame aɖeke magagblɔ le anyigba dzi be ‘mele dɔ lém o’ la nava eme. "
He says, "I look forward to seeing the fulfillment of Isaiah 33:24, which foretells the time when no one on earth will say ‘I am sick.’
Na ŋugbe si Mawu do be yeana "anyigba yeye, " afi si "vevesese " maganɔ o la nafa akɔ na wò abe ale si wòfa akɔ na Ojebode ene.
" Like Ojebode, take comfort in God’s promise of "a new earth, " where "pain " will be no more.
(Nyaɖeɖefia 21:1, 4) Ŋugbedodo ma fia be tagbɔdɔ kple blanuiléledɔ aɖeke maganɔ anyi o.
(Revelation 21:1, 4) That promise includes an end to all mental and emotional pain.
Wò vevesesewo nu ayi tegbee.
Your painful feelings will be gone forever.
Wò vevesesewo ‘magava susu me na wò alo ava dzi me na wò’ gbeɖe o. Yesaya 65:17.
Never again will your painful feelings "be called to mind, nor will they come up into [your] heart. "​ Isaiah 65:17.
Mawunyakpukpui Siwo Ate Ŋu Akpe Ðe Ŋuwò
Bible Verses That Can Help
Mawu nya ale si nèle sesem le ɖokuiwò me.
God understands your feelings.
"Nye, Yehowa wò Mawu, melé wò nuɖusi ɖe asi, . . . le gbɔgblɔm na wò be: ‘Mègavɔ̃ o.
"I, Jehovah your God, am grasping your right hand, . . . saying to you, ‘Do not be afraid.
Makpe ɖe ŋuwò.’ " Yesaya 41:13.
I will help you.’ "​ Isaiah 41:13.
Yehowa sea ale si míesena le mía ɖokui me gɔme wu ame bubu ɖe sia ɖe eye edi be yeakpe ɖe mía ŋu.
Jehovah understands our feelings better than anyone else, and he wants to help us. Meditate on God’s Word.
Xlẽ Mawu ƒe Nyaa nàde ŋugble le eŋu.
"[Elijah] asked that he might die.
"[Eliya bia] be yeaku hegblɔ be: ‘ . . .
He said: ‘ . . .
Oo Yehowa, ɖe nye agbe ɖa.’ " 1 Fiawo 19:4.
O Jehovah, take my life away.’ "​ 1 Kings 19:4.
Ojebode gblɔ be: "Esi mede ŋugble le Mawu ƒe Nyaa ŋu la, eɖe vi nam.
"Meditating on God’s Word helped me, " says Ojebode.
Meva kpɔe be nyagblɔɖila Eliya hã se le eɖokui me kpɔ abe ale si mele sesem le ɖokuinye me ene. "
"I realized that the prophet Elijah once felt just as I did. "
Srɔ̃ nu tso Biblia me kpɔɖeŋuwo me.
Learn from Bible examples.
"[Nye Yesu] meɖe kuku ɖe [wò, Petro ta] be wò xɔse nu nagatsi o. " Luka 22:32.
"I [Jesus] have made supplication for you [Peter] that your faith may not give out. "​ Luke 22:32.
Esi apostolo Petro gbe nu le Yesu gbɔ zi etɔ̃ megbe la, nu te ɖe edzi vevie eye wòfa avi hehehe.
After the apostle Peter denied Jesus three times, his feelings were hard for him to bear and he wept bitterly.
Kaoru gblɔ be: "Nu si me Petro to kpe ɖe ŋunye mekpɔe be Yehowa kple Yesu de dzesi ale si Petro se le eɖokui me.
"Peter’s experience, " says Kaoru, "helped me to see that Jehovah and Jesus cared about Peter’s feelings.
Esia do ŋusẽm. "
This encouraged me. "
Wò vevesesewo ‘magava susu me na wò alo ava dzi me na wò’ gbeɖe o. Yesaya 65:17
Never again will your painful feelings "be called to mind, nor will they come up into [your] heart. "​ Isaiah 65:17
Susu Nyuiwo Li Siwo Tae Wòle Be Nànɔ Agbe
Why Life IS Worth Living
Ƒoe Eva hiã be woako Faizal awɔ dɔ le eƒe dzi ŋu esi srɔ̃a ku ƒe ɖeka megbe ko.
Faizal required major heart surgery just over a year after his wife died.
Egblɔ be: "Esi mexlẽ Hiob ƒe agbalẽa la, mekpɔe be susu aɖe tae Yehowae na wotsɔe de Biblia me ɖo.
He says: "When I read the book of Job, I know Jehovah put it there for a reason.
Ne míele nu xam vevie eye míexlẽ nu tso ame aɖe si hã xa nu nenema kpɔ ŋu le Biblia me la, efaa akɔ na mí ŋutɔ. "
When we find an example in the Bible that we can relate to, it is a way of soothing our pain of heart. "
Egblɔ kpee be: "Susu nyuiwo li siwo tae wòle be míayi edzi anɔ agbe. "
He adds: "Life is still worth living. "
Ðevi koe Tarsha nye esime dadaa ku.
Tarsha was young when her mother died.
Egblɔ be: "Wɔlaa nyanya nana tameɖoɖo kple mɔkpɔkpɔ nɔa agbea ŋu, eye wònana ame kpɔa dzidzɔ togbɔ be anɔ kuxiwo me tom hã.
She says: "Knowing our Creator is what gives life purpose, hope, and joy despite all the things we may have to deal with.
Míeka ɖe edzi be Yehowa alé mí ɖe te eye wòakpe ɖe mía ŋu míanɔ te sesĩe gbe sia gbe. "
Jehovah is more than capable of sustaining us and helping us to get through each day. "
NYATI SIWO do ŋgɔ ƒo nu tso nɔnɔme sesẽ vovovo siwo wɔnɛ be agbenɔnɔ sesẽna ŋu.
THE PRECEDING articles show how various traumatic events can make life seem unbearable.
Esi nèle dzi dom le nɔnɔme sesẽ siwo me tom nèle me la, ɖewohĩ àsusu be agbea maganya nɔ o, alo ame aɖeke metsɔ ɖeke le eme na ye o.
As you carry your own personal burden, you may wonder if life is worthwhile or whether anyone even cares about you.
Ka ɖe edzi be Mawu ya nya fu siwo kpem nèle.
Be assured that God does care about your distress.
Èxɔ asi le Mawu ŋkume.
You are precious to him.
Psalmo 86 ŋlɔla gblɔ ale si wòka ɖe Mawu dzii. Egblɔ be: "Mayɔ wò le nye xaxagbe, elabena àtɔ nam. "
The writer of Psalm 86 expressed confidence toward God: "I call on you in the day of my distress, for you will answer me. "
(Psalmo 86:7) Gake awɔ na wò be, ‘Aleke Mawu atɔ nam "le nye xaxagbe "?’
(Psalm 86:7) You may wonder, though, ‘How will God answer me "in the day of my distress "?’

Togbɔ be Mawu maɖe wò kuxiawo ɖa enumake o hã la, eƒe Nya Biblia ka ɖe edzi na wò be Mawu ate ŋu ana wò susu nadze akɔ anyi be nàte ŋu anɔ te ɖe kuxiawo nu: "Migatsi dzimaɖi le naneke ŋuti o, ke boŋ le nu sia nu me la, mito gbedodoɖa kple kokoƒoƒo kpakple akpedada dzi miana Mawu nanya miaƒe dzimedidiwo; eye Mawu ƒe ŋutifafa, si ƒo gɔmesesewo katã ta la, adzɔ miaƒe dziwo kple miaƒe tamesusuwo ŋu. "

Although God may not take away your problems immediately, his Word, the Bible, assures you that he can give you inner peace to help you cope: "Do not be anxious over anything, but in everything by prayer and supplication along with thanksgiving, let your petitions be made known to God; and the peace of God that surpasses all understanding will guard your hearts and your thoughts. "
(Filipitɔwo 4:6, 7) Míeɖe kuku de ŋugble le ale si mawunyakpukpui siwo gbɔna la ka ɖe edzi na mí be Mawu léa be na mí la ŋu.
(Philippians 4:6, 7, footnote) Please consider how the following Bible verses give us assurance of God’s tender care.
Mawu Léa Be Na Wò
God Does Care About You

Ke boŋ eɖe eme be: "Eteƒenɔlae menye, eye [Mawu ye] dɔm ɖa. "
About 3,500 years ago, the Bible stated that the earth is suspended "upon nothing. "
(Yohanes 7:29) Esi Yesu nɔ nu ƒom kple eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo dometɔ ɖeka la, eyɔ Yehowa be "Fofonye kple mia Fofo, nye Mawu kple mia Mawu. "
(Job 26:7) This differed greatly from the myths that described the earth as floating on water or being carried by a giant tortoise.
(Yohanes 20:17) Esi Yesu ku la, Yehowa gbɔ agbee wòyi dziƒo, eye wòna ŋusẽ gã aɖee le Eƒe ɖusime. Mateo 28:18; Dɔwɔwɔwo 2:32, 33.
Some 1,100 years after the book of Job was written, people continued to believe that the earth could not just hang in midair; it had to have something to rest upon.
Yesu Kristo Ate Ŋu Akpe Ðe Ŋuwò Nàte Ðe Mawu Ŋu Yesu va anyigba dzi va fia nu mí tso Fofoa ŋu.
Only three hundred years ago, in 1687, Isaac Newton published his work on gravity and explained that the earth is held in orbit by an invisible force.
Yehowa ŋutɔ gblɔ tso Yesu ŋu be: "Ame siae nye Vinye, si gbɔ nyemelɔ̃a nu le o.
This scientific milestone confirmed what the Bible had stated more than 3,000 years earlier!
Miɖo toe. "
Prophetic Truth
(Marko 9:7) Yesu nya Mawu nyuie wu ame bubu ɖe sia ɖe.
Icon of Babylon’s walls and open gate
Yesu ɖe Mawu ƒe nɔnɔmewo fia le mɔ deblibo nu.
How accurate are the Bible’s many prophecies?
Yesu srɔ̃ Fofoa ƒe nɔnɔmewo pɛpɛpɛ ale gbegbe be wòte ŋu gblɔ be: "Ame si kpɔm la, ekpɔ Fofo la hã. "
Consider one example: Isaiah’s prophecy about the fall of Babylon.
(Yohanes 14:9) Esi Yesu srɔ̃ Fofoa ƒe lɔlɔ̃ eye wòɖee fia le nyagbɔgblɔ kple nuwɔnawo me ta la, eto edzi he amewo ɖe Mawu ŋu.

The Prophecy: In the eighth century B.C.E., the Bible writer Isaiah declared that Babylon​ which was only later to become the capital of a powerful empire ​would be overthrown and eventually become uninhabited.
Egblɔ be: "Nyee nye mɔ la kple nyateƒe la kpakple agbe la.
(Isaiah 13:17-20) Isaiah even named the man who would carry this out​ Cyrus.
Ame aɖeke mevaa Fofo la gbɔ o, negbe to dzinye ko. "
He also described Cyrus’ strategy, stating that rivers would "dry up. "
Yehowa le ame siwo le abe wò ene, siwo di be yewoanya nyateƒe si ku ɖe ye ŋu la dim.
And he foretold that the city gates would be left open.​ Isaiah 44:27–45:1.
Yesu fia eyomedzelawo be woado gbe ɖa ale: "Mía Fofo si le dziƒowo, wò ŋkɔ ŋuti nakɔ.
The Fulfillment: Some 200 years after Isaiah’s prophecy, a Persian king attacked Babylon.
Wò Fiaɖuƒe nava.
His name?
Nu kae wòwɔna?
Cyrus.
Eye nu ka tae wòle be míado gbe ɖa be Fiaɖuƒea nava? Yesue nye Mawu Fiaɖuƒea ƒe Fia.
Because Babylon was heavily fortified, Cyrus turned his attention to the Euphrates River, which ran through the city.
Luka 1:31-33: "Nàna ŋkɔe be Yesu.
His men dug a canal upstream to divert the river into a marshland.
Eya anye gã, eye woayɔe be Dziƒoʋĩtɔ la ƒe Vi, eye Yehowa Mawu atsɔ fofoa David ƒe fiazikpui la anɛ, aɖu fia ɖe Yakob ƒe aƒe la dzi tegbee, eye nuwuwu manɔe na eƒe Fiaɖuƒe la o. "
This dropped the river level enough to make it possible for Cyrus’ army to march through the thigh-deep water of the riverbed, which adjoined the city walls.
Fiaɖuƒeae nye nyati vevitɔ si Yesu ɖe gbeƒãe.
Incredibly, the Babylonians had left the gates that faced the river open!
Yesu na dzesi eƒe nusrɔ̃lawo be wòakpe ɖe wo ŋu woanya ɣeyiɣi si me Fiaɖuƒea ava.
Cyrus’ army entered Babylon through the open gates and overthrew it.
Mateo 24:7: "Elabena dukɔ atso ɖe dukɔ ŋu, eye fiaɖuƒe ɖe fiaɖuƒe ŋu, nuɖuɖu ave le teƒeteƒewo, eye anyigba aʋuʋu le teƒeteƒewo. "
However, one detail remained: Did Babylon become uninhabited?
Fifia Yesu ƒe nusrɔ̃lawo le gbeƒã ɖem Fiaɖuƒea le anyigba blibo la katã dzi.
For some centuries, people continued living there.
Mateo 24:14: "Eye woaɖe gbeƒã Fiaɖuƒe ŋuti nya nyui sia le anyigba blibo la katã dzi be wòanye ɖaseɖiɖi na dukɔwo katã, eye ekema nuwuwu la ava. "
But today, Babylon’s ruins​ near Baghdad, Iraq ​testify to the prophecy’s complete fulfillment.
Mawu Fiaɖuƒea Ŋu Nyateƒenyawo Ele teƒe aɖe koŋ.
Yes, the Bible is reliable even when it discusses future events.
DANIEL 2:44; MATEO 4:17.
